PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Rt Hon. Sir Billy Snedden) took the chair at 2.15 p.m., and read prayers.

PETITION.PRESENTERS: CHILD; JOHNSON; JONES; KEATING; MCLEAY; MCMAHON; MILTON; MORRIS; SCOTT
PETITION.NAMEIDS: HF4; 6G7; FG7; NH4; 4I4; DL7; DI4; HI4; 7J4
PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines
PETITION.PARA: The Clerk-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows and copies will be referred to the appropriate Ministers:
Proposed Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines
To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
Many Australians depend almost exclusively upon Trans-Australia Airlines for the provision of essential air services.
The Federal Liberal Party policy objective of selling Trans-Australia Airlines within 4 years is contrary to the national interest.
Sale of Trans-Australia Airlines would inevitably result in:
(i) the creation of a private monopoly of major airline services in Australia;
(ii) higher domestic air fares.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will reject outright any proposal to sell Trans-Australia Airlines.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mrs Child,Mr Les Johnson,Mr Charles Jones,Mr Keating,Mr Leo McLeay,Mr Les McMahon,Mr Milton,Mr Morris and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Excise on Beer
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

1. The hotel industry in Australia is long-established and a valuable part of the community of this nation, providing places where the people may partake of the three basic needs of life: a place to eat, a place to drink, a place to sleep.
2. The hotel industry is accepted throughout the nation as occupying an important place in the social and economic activities of Australia.
3. The hotel industry is almost entirely within the private sector and makes a large contribution to the government in taxes of various kinds.
4. The hotel industry has a need to sustain an appropriate level of turnover and growth, to make profit, and to sustain and improve the level of employment.
5. The hotel industry of Australia is gravely concerned at published reports that the Government intends to increase excise charges on beer in the forthcoming Budget.
6. Sales of beer constitute the major source of income of most of the industry's 5,811 hotels in Australia.
7. The very steep rises in beer excise in 1975 and 1978 severely retarded the growth of the Australian hotel industry.

8. Any further increases in excise on beer in the 1981 Budget would further retard the industry at a time when growth is essential to maintaining economic viability and the ability to serve the constantly growing needs of the community.
9. Such is its significance as a community requirement, beer occupies a place on the Consumer Price Index, and any alteration to its costs to the community would have an inflationary effect.
10. Any increase in excise would result in and force the hotel industry to pass on such increases to the consumer by way of higher prices for beer.

11. Higher excise would be only the starting point for an upward spiral in beer prices because of the presence of other factors, such as State Licence Fee taxes, which are directly linked to excise rates.
12. The hotel industry of Australia already is gravely handicapped by heavy excise and other tax imposts, its growth is at a standstill; and, inevitably must decline if beer excise is increased.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives:
(1) Recognise the importance and place of the Australian hotel industry in the social and economic life of the nation.

(2) Accept that the viability of the hotel industry is essential to the maintenance of employment opportunities and stability of the industry is essential to enable it to continue to provide for the hotel needs of the nation in this period of growing population and increasing tourism.
And further, that Honourable Members of the House of Representatives resist and reject any move to increase excise on beer.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Bourchier,Mr Hyde,Mr Les McMahon and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Taxation: Child Care Expenses
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
A substantial contribution to Australia's economy by the payment of taxation and to the quality of life of fellow Australians is made by parents in the work-force who have pre-school children.
Taxation relief for adequate child-care is necessary to enable these parents to avail themselves of child-care facilities in order to take paid employment.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that tax-payers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other tax-payers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Beazley and Mr Tambling.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Parliament of the Commonwealth of Australia, in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully calls for:
The immediate and unconditional withdrawal of any proposals to deny unemployment benefits to unemployed people under 18 years old.
That the level of benefits for all unemployed people, and including people receiving sickness benefits and pensions, be raised to at least 120 per cent of the poverty line.

That future employment policies be devoted to job creation and the restoration of full employment rather than the evasion of this responsibility by hiding the unemployed in short term training and education schemes.
Public acknowledgement of the fact that unemployment is the result of insufficient jobs and not the fault of any minority group, the education system or the unemployed themselves.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Unemployment Benefit
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of Parliament assembled in the House of Representatives. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:

Taxpayers who incur child-care expenses in order to earn income should be able to have those expenses exempt from income taxation in the same way as other taxpayers can deduct business expenses from their assessable income.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Confidential Medical Records
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we are gravely concerned by the invasion of privacy caused by Government agents seizing patients' medical records.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled should:
Legislate to protect the private and confidential nature of medical records from scrutiny except on the express and informed consent of the patient or an order from a presiding judge.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Malcolm Fraser and Mr Dean.

PETITION.TITLE: Funding of Children's Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That funding in the area of children's services, which has been reduced by almost 40 per cent in real terms over the last five years, should be restored forthwith to at least the real value of funding allocated in the 1975-76 Budget. And further, that annual Budget allocations in the area of children's services should be spent in full for the purposes designated.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Mr Les McMahon and Mr Scott.

PETITION.TITLE: Toxic Shock Syndrome
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned showeth that your petitioners are gravely concerned by the threats to women's health and lives posed by Toxic Shock Syndrome, and urge the following steps to be taken as a matter of urgency:

(1) Tampons, sanitary napkins, vaginal deodorants and similar sanitary products to be re-classified under Therapeutic Agents (not under ''Cosmetics'' as at present), in order to bring them under the scrutiny of the Australian Drug Evaluation Committee. We believe manufacture must be under the strictest hygienic conditions.

(2) After re-classification, we urge an immediate government-funded inquiry into all aspects of manufacture and content of these products. This must lead to: (i) contents of product and instructions for correct usage to be shown on packaging; (ii) removal of synthetic fibres, chemicals or ingredients that are potentially or actually harmful to users.

(3) Allocation of extra funding for ongoing research by the National Health and Medical Research Council into these products, results of this research to be made public to ensure all health workers and potential users are fully informed. This campaign of public education would necessitate multilingual distribution of the information where appropriate.
Your petitioners, therefore, humbly request that Parliament take immediate and positive action to avert possible threats posed to women's health by implementation of the above measures.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Service Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

(1) That merchant seamen have in the past served in theatres of war; they have been decorated for valor following war action; they have been prisoners of war and should therefore be entitled to similar pension rights and medical benefits as regular servicemen.
(2) That by being denied the entitlements, such as pension and medical benefits, which other war veterans receive, they are thereby being discriminated against.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Government amend the Repatriation Act (1920) Section 100 (d) (iv) to take account of war related service by merchant seamen during World War 2.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Labelling of Cosmetics
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.

That the Industries Assistance Commission, because of the Commission's terms of reference, seems unable to impose any regulation or recommend any regulation which might restrict the activities of Cosmetic Companies which produce cosmetics in which animal ingredients have been used, or for which animals were subjected to research.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will:
Legislate to require comprehensive labelling of perfumes, cosmetics and toilet preparations to indicate:
(1) whether a product contains any animal derivative. If so, the ingredient and source should be indicated.
(2) whether the research and development of that product or any of its ingredients involved experimentation on animals.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Use of Live Animals in Research
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That continued use of animal ingredients in cosmetic products, and the inhumane use of animals in scientific research for cosmetic products is abhorrent and barbaric.
2. That no central records exist on such inhumane use of live animals for experimentation purposes, yet research institutions in several Australian States engage in such a practice.
3. That there exists no uniform legislation between the States concerning responsible standards of research conduct, indeed, in some States there is a complete lack of legislation altogether.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House of Representatives will enact legislation to require:
(a) the Australian Bureau of Statistics to produce annual statistics on the numbers of live animals involved in research, and provide information as to research purpose;

(b) the National Health and Medical Research Council to develop humane and responsible standards of conduct for researchers using live animals in all Government, Industry and Educational Research Laboratories.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Moreton Island: Sand Mining
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
1. That sandmining on Moreton Island poses a threat to the natural ecology or environment.

2. That Moreton Island is included on the interim list of the Australian Heritage Commission, and the Federal Government is urged and indeed it must, under the Australian Heritage Commission Act 1975, take into consideration the protection of the island.
3. That the Queensland Government has recently renewed a further mining lease against the advice of conservationists.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the House will request the Government to refuse requests for export permits covering mineral sand products.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: El Salvador
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the present government of El Salvador has been responsible for the deaths of at least 10,000 people in 1980 alone; and that it has been condemned as one of the worst human rights violators in the world by organisations such as Amnesty International and the US Conference of Catholic Bishops.
Therefore we humbly request that the government of the Commonwealth of Australia:
(i) urge the government of the United States of America to immediately cease all military aid to the government of El Salvador;
(ii) support the freedom of the Salvadoran people against the governing military dictatorship.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Family Law Act
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth that allegations have been made by litigants that unjust decisions in relation to ancillary matters are being made at the Family Court of Australia.

We call on the Government to amend section 79 (1) of the Family Law Act to allow all Family Courts to be open and publication of details of proceedings permitted, provided names of parties and other identifying information is prohibited from disclosure.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tertiary Education Fees
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That students express concern that fees for tertiary education will be re-introduced.
That such a decision will severely restrict the access of rural students to tertiary education.
That all students have a right to equal access to tertiary education.
That such a decision will adversely affect the employment potential of young Australians.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:
That any proposal for the re-introduction of tertiary fees be the subject of a full public inquiry and full debate.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Trade Unions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of certain citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we are gravely disturbed by the actions of militant unions and the ACTU, the failure of the President of the ACTU to assist positively in settling the dispute which has caused massive losses to Qantas our National Airline, and we applaud the action of the Government in using RAAF planes to rescue Australians stranded abroad.

Your petitioners therefore humbly pray that the Federal Parliament and the Government should be of firm resolve not to permit such unions to hold the country to ransom and continue to take a forceful and resolute stand against such union militancy.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Anti-discriminatory Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives of the Australian Parliament in Canberra assembled. The petition of certain citizens respectfully showeth:

That currently discrimination in the provision of work, in appointment to jobs and in promotion exists in Australia on particular grounds including, inter alia, grounds of race, ethnic origin, marital status, pregnancy, sex and/or sexual preference; and
That currently discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits is exercised against particular groups of individual-in particular, against married women.
Your petitioners therefore humbly pray:

That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in Commonwealth employment, in employment of individuals under federal awards, in employment of persons by statutory bodies and quasi-governmental organisations, and in employment of all persons in areas over which Commonwealth and Australian Capital Territory equal opportunity legislation should have jurisdiction; and
That appropriate laws be formulated and passed to outlaw discrimination in the provision of unemployment benefits to all persons without regard to sex and/or marital status.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Staging of American B52 Bombers
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned in the Northern Territory respectfully showeth:
That the proposed use of Darwin Airport as a refuelling and Rest and Recreation base for American B52 bombers:

Jeopardises the welfare of the citizens of Darwin and of all Australians, in that it establishes a stronger potential of Darwin being a nuclear target in any conflict between the USA and another power.
Impedes the sovereignty of the Australian nation in that Australian citizens would have neither control nor knowledge of whether B52s:
(a) carried nuclear weapons
(b) were engaged in bombing missions against another State.
Violates the Australian people's independence and links this nation irreconcilably with United States foreign policies thereby destroying the potential for independent Australian defence policy.

Violates democratic procedures in committing the Australian nation to participation in future wars without due consultation and informed assessment by Australian citizens and further increases the militarisation of the Indian Ocean thereby increasing the likelihood of super power conflict in this region.
Jeopardises the welfare of the Citizens of Darwin, in that noise pollution and the threat of accidental radioactive fallout will increase substantially to the residents.
Negates the potential of the Australian nation to establish itself as a nation of peace in the Pacific region and violates Australia's commitment to the Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty.

Your petitioners therefore pray that the members of the House of Representatives will ensure that the Prime Minister withdraws the offer of Darwin, or any other location in Australia, as a base or depot for American B52 bombers. And that furthermore will ensure that any request of such usage by the U.S. Government be rejected.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Capital Territory: High Speed Transit Traffic
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of undersigned electors of the Division of Canberra respectfully showeth:

That traffic on Athllon Drive, which was built as a temporary measure to make do until Erindale Drive was constructed, is causing noise in excess of acceptable levels, and serious safety problems. The heavy volume of traffic transiting Beasley Street between Athllon Drive and Yamba Drive is also causing serious noise and safety problems in an area containing a school, a major sporting complex and a retirement village. One person has been killed and there have been other serious accidents.

Your petitioners, therefore, humbly pray for an immediate, thorough-going and substantial review of the problems caused by the routing of high speed transit traffic to and from the Tuggeranong Valley through the southern Woden suburbs; and that an effective and comprehensive solution be instituted without delay.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Treasurer's attention been drawn to the report in today's Canberra Times that the Australian Taxation Office has been unable to collect almost $1,000m in assessed tax because of staff shortages and that hundreds of millions of dollars in tax remains undiscovered because of a lack of staff? Is it a fact that each tax investigation officer employed generates revenue for the Government of around $200,000 a year, that is, at least ten times the officer's salary? Is it a fact that, as the Auditor-General's recent report has shown, staff shortages created by arbitrary staff ceilings have cost the Government considerably in terms of lost revenue and reduced control over spending? Finally, how does the Treasurer expect the ordinary pay-as-you-earn taxpayer to believe that legislation such as a revamped section 260 will reverse the clear trend towards tax being optional for the rich when the Government refuses to back up such legislation with the necessary staff to enforce it?

—My attention has been drawn to that article. I can describe the figure used in the article only as being quite fanciful and having no basis in fact. Quite obviously, the number of people employed in certain activities of the Taxation Office does have an effect on revenue collections. That is particularly so in the area of the field audit operations of the Taxation Office, which is not concerned primarily with the detection of the sophisticated forms of tax avoidance to which the honourable member's question was directed. As he should know, the detection and countering of that kind of behaviour is more the province of the legislative sections of the Taxation Office and more a function of the rapidity with which tax avoidance schemes can be dealt with by legislation and, in particular, of whether an omnibus anti-avoidance provision such as section 260 can be introduced. In other words, sophisticated tax avoidance is best countered by sophisticated legislative response and does not necessarily depend upon the total number of people employed.

—Is the Minister for the Capital Territory aware of the statement issuing from a meeting of 118 leaseholders of the Belconnen Mall that they would support its sale by strata title? Does the Minister propose to make every effort to conduct the sale on those lines? Would present tenants have first refusal for the area they occupy?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hodgman The Hon W.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I am aware of a meeting held last night of shopkeepers operating at the Belconnen Mall, and I understand that over 200 people attended. At the meeting it was resolved that a request would be made to me for strata titles to be issued and for the shopkeepers to purchase the premises they currently occupy. I further understand that a deputation from the Australian Association of Independent Businesses, specifically representing the Belconnen Traders Association, will be seeing me later today. In implementing the Government's decision to sell the Belconnen Mall and to wind up the Canberra Commercial Development Authority, a national consultant from the private enterprise sector is to be retained to advise and assist the Government. The proposal put forward by the honourable member is indeed a most interesting one, and I will be giving it most careful consideration, along with other proposals that no doubt will be coming before me.
—Can't you make up your mind?
—Outrageous!

—I am surprised that members of the Labor Party are not interested in this, because it is a very important question in Canberra at the moment. Whilst there is no legal obstacle to subdividing the complex and issuing independent strata titles, I must point out that that would be a most unusual course of action to follow for a major shopping complex. I am informed that nowhere in Australia has a major retail shopping centre been subdivided in the manner proposed. However, I am informed that this has been done in other countries. I indicate that the matter will be given most serious consideration.

ANSWER.PARA: Before concluding, I will make two further comments. In principle it can be stated, and is clearly stated, that the concept of private ownership accords with the Government's philosophy and the motivation behind the decision to release the Belconnen Mall to the private sector. I note the interest of the private sector, of both large and small private enterprise organisations, in the disposal of the Mall. The question of the price per unit, arrangements for management and maintenance of the common areas including escalators, stairs, car parks and pedestrian areas and access to the 172 shops in the complex are all matters which will have to be given the most careful consideration. Lastly, I draw attention to a statement made last night by the Leader of the Australian Labor Party in the House of Assembly. He said that if the Australian Labor Party wins the 1983 Federal election it will immediately repurchase the Belconnen Mall. Once again the Labor Party shows how completely out of touch it is with the real world of private enterprise. The views which it has expressed are totally opposed by the private sector and in particular the Belconnen Traders Association. The decision of the Government to release the Belconnen Mall to the private sector has been overwhelmingly accepted and approved in the Australian Capital Territory.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Health. I refer the Minister to the Hospitals and Health Services Commission's 'Discussion paper on Paying for Health Care', which, like the present Government's new health measures, expounds the user pays philosophy. I refer him also to the fact that the paper isolates higher prices for medical and hospital care as being responsible for over half-58 per cent-of the increase in health expenditures. Does the Minister not agree that the higher costs his announced policy forecasts for hospital accommodation, for transfers from public to private hospital sectors, for health insurance premiums and for reintroduced hospital charges will in fact further escalate the cost of the Australian health care system and that these increased costs will in fact benefit not the consumers of health services but the providers?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the House and the people of Australia must be aware that the cost of health care in all modern and developing countries is escalating quite rapidly. This is because of the developments in health technology, medical techniques and the sorts of institutions which are required and which are being utilised. What the Government has sought to do is to make people, both practitioners of health care and receivers of health care, more aware of the total costs in this area. It must not be thought for a moment that the health insurance costs cover anywhere near the real cost of a bed in, say, a public hospital, which cost is averaging between $150 and $200 per bed day, depending on the State. The cost per intensive bed day is naturally a very great deal more. Both State and Commonwealth governments subsidise the cost of health care very considerably. We not only subsidise it by direct payments to the States for hospitals but we also subsidise it-this has been announced-by payments for institutions such as nursing homes.

ANSWER.PARA: The thrust behind the Commonwealth's approach to this whole problem of cost containment is to ensure that bodies such as the States accept responsibility for their constitutional requirements for the provision of health care-that is the general or public hospital system. It was very clearly pointed out in the Jamison Commission report that in fact there was a duplication of administrative arrangements for public hospitals. Surely, when one body has the constitutional responsibility to administer the public hospital system and the public health system it must and does provide an impetus for that administration to be as efficient and effective as possible. At the same time, if in some way we can bring home to the receivers of health care and the providers of health care the costs of the services that are being provided, then in this way the whole community will have a better idea of the enormous cost of modern health care.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House whether he told the Premiers on Monday at the Premiers Conference that the Commonwealth would cut income tax in the year 1981-82?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Premiers were not told that. They were told that it was the Government's objective to get into a position where realistic tax cuts would be feasible. It was emphasised that expenditure restraint not just by the Commonwealth Government but by all governments would be necessary if this were to happen in a way that Australians would find acceptable. I think it was pointed out at the Premiers Conference that slightly over 50 per cent of all the dollars finally spent by governments are spent by State and local governments combined. Because of the weight and importance of State and local governments in relation, therefore, to the demands of government on the resources of Australia, their participation, and especially the States' participation, in the program of expenditure restraint is essential if Australia's taxpayers are to get the best possible deal. There is not the slightest doubt that, if the Commonwealth Government acceded to the requests of all Premiers, people's earnings could be paid to the State governments and there would be no need for those earnings to pass through the pockets of the individuals concerned because the governments would absorb the lot. I do not think anyone would regard that as a particularly sensible arrangement-certainly not the taxpayers, who were not even seeing their own income.

ANSWER.PARA: At Premiers conferences it is essential for the Federal Government to have very much in mind the interests of Australian taxpayers. At Premiers conferences the Commonwealth is the only government that speaks as though it has those interests in mind, because always there are requests put upon it to spend more funds. There is one Premier, in particular, who a few months ago recommended massive taxation reductions for the Commonwealth.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is that?

—I daresay he will recognise himself. Those massive taxation reductions either would have been vastly inflationary by increasing our deficit or would have involved massive reductions in government expenditure-much greater reductions than the Review of Commonwealth Functions has been able to achieve. I think it was pointed out at the time, that if Premiers believed there ought to be tax reductions as a result of Commonwealth Government decisions, they would need to bear some part of that burden. At the Premiers Conference we made some progress, as a result of the final decisions, in achieving expenditure restraint, and therefore I believe the policy that we have urged upon the Premiers is intact and on course. It involves greater restraint in the Commonwealth's expenditure and in the expenditure of the States, and I hope that that policy will be followed through in their Budgets later in the year and in our Budget later in the year. All of this is very much in the interests of Australian taxpayers. It is the only way in which to make realistic tax reductions possible.

ANSWER.PARA: Having said that as briefly as possible, I might add that half tax indexation does apply from 1 July, and that will cost half a billion dollars. From 1 July those who take out health insurance for themselves and their families at the standard or base rate will be able to claim a rebate for that expenditure in July of the year following that for which the rebate is claimed. Obviously those two things mean a reduction in the taxes that would otherwise be payable. As to other decisions that might be made, we will have to wait and see what is possible after the final expenditure and revenue figures become available to us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Health to his statement of last week which, because of hasty preparation, had a certain imprecision with regard to costs. Is he now able to tell the House what is the likely cost to the Government of increasing the private hospital bed day-subsidy for surgical patients to $28, the savings in costs of reducing the number of disadvantaged persons eligible for bulk billing, and the additional cost to the funds of increasing the medical benefit to the insured population from 75 per cent to 85 per cent?

—The likely cost of increasing the bed day subsidy for surgical beds in private hospitals from $16 a day to $28 a day will be about $22m. The savings in cost in the disadvantaged area will be, from memory, approximately $8m to $10m. What was the third cost?
—The increase from 75 per cent to 85 per cent.
—I cannot recall precisely what that figure will be but I will supply the honourable member with it.

—I address my question to the Minister for Communications. Following the announced abolition of the Australia Post Courier Service, has the Minister seen reports about the new Australia Post Express service? Can he inform the House about this new and expanded service which, it is said, should meet all the requirements of those clients previously using the Australia Post Courier service?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Prime Minister announced in the House the other day, the Australia Post Courier service is to be terminated. It is true that one of the charges of Australia Post is to provide an expeditious mail service. That is a responsibility which all members of the House would expect Australia Post to continue to fulfil. It is a responsibility which involves mails being delivered as soon as possible after they are dispatched to the destination identified on them. I was disappointed to see the letter reported in this morning's Press which suggests that Australia Post has in mind that the new service will be identical to the old. There is a necessity, as I have explained, for an express mail service. To that degree and with articles that are within the ambit of Australia Post's responsibilities, it will remain Australia Post's responsibility.

ANSWER.PARA: It is intended, however, that a range of articles that were previously, as I understood, advertised as being carried by Australia Post Courier will not henceforth be carried. They include articles that, in Tasmania at least, were advertised as being across a wide range of articles and certainly not only those in the more restricted categories-those restricted for postage. The objective being to expedite mail deliveries, I hope that Australia Post looks at the degree to which private contractors can undertake to the maximum the work of speeding these mail deliveries. I do not know whether it was stated in the letter that was apparently written by Australia Post that it intends to extend the contract service. It is certainly the Government's objective to ensure that the private sector participates to the maximum in whatever way it can to ensure that Australia Post pursues and completes its task.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister for Health been drawn to the report in the Australian Financial Review of 5 May 1981 indicating that the Commonwealth Government wanted the following charges levied for public hospital services: A $15 fee for out-patient services, $80 a day for public ward beds and $110 a day for intermediate ward beds? Are these the 'appropriate in-patient and out-patient charges' referred to by the Minister in his statement of 29 April? If not, what were the 'appropriate charges' used in his calculations?
—Those are the charges which the Commonwealth has used for the basis of its calculations.

—I wish to add to the answer which I gave to the honourable member for Bonython. The saving of between $8m and $10m concerning disadvantaged persons relates both to the lifting of the refund figure for health insurance from 75 per cent to 85 per cent plus the changes to the system of definition of 'disadvantaged'.

—Is the Minister for Transport aware of the important role of the regional airline carriers in Australia? Is he aware that such carriers are the lifeline of many residents outside the capital cities and off the main trunk routes? Will he therefore do everything possible to ensure that these carriers are not disadvantaged or discouraged in any new two-airline agreement?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hunt The Hon R.J.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the great importance of regional airlines to aviation generally and certainly to regional areas throughout Australia. I am very concerned that East-West Airlines Ltd, which plays a very big part as a regional airline operating over a fairly vast network, has been going through a fairly difficult time due to a number of factors. The first was the disastrous commercial decision to take over Connair Pty Ltd in the Northern Territory. It has also suffered a downturn in revenue due to the continuing drought over a wide area of New South Wales. It has decided to suspend what was a profitable route, the Alice Springs-Sydney route, that it established some time ago, because of competition from larger aircraft operated by Ansett Airlines of Australia and Trans-Australia Airlines.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I must say that I was surprised at some of the statements made by the chairman of East-West yesterday. They are misleading in that they allege that the new two airlines agreement will militate against regional airlines. Nothing could be further from the truth. Under the existing airlines agreement there is no definition of any route which is to the advantage of or which will be served by a regional airline.

Under the new two airlines arrangement the trunk routes and the prescribed routes are defined. They are prescribed in the following way: A regional operator will have the opportunity to operate over what are called prescribed routes in the new agreement. Prescribed routes can be trunk routes or part of trunk routes. Prescribed routes are defined in the agreement as including intrastate routes, intraterritorial routes, from a regional centre to anywhere in Australia, routes over which the airlines operated as at 1 July 1981 and a route over which neither TAA nor Ansett has provided a service at the request of the Minister or to the satisfaction of the Minister. There is no need to consult over the first four of those categories, but in respect to the latter category there is a need to consult with a major airline.

The opportunity is there for East-West to continue to expand. Indeed, honourable members will recall that Ansett Airlines made an arrangement with Bush Pilots Airways Pty Ltd to take over some of its unprofitable F27 routes in Queensland. East-West claims to have a specialty in handling F27 services. East-West I think would do its cause much good if it were to negotiate with TAA and the other major airline to see whether it can take over some of the routes that the major airlines are not operating efficiently or satisfactorily from their point of view. I hope that East-West will take a leaf out of the book of Bush Pilots which has taken a very bold initiative in Queensland. Rather than grumble and grizzle about a new airlines agreement that has not yet come into force, it ought to get on with the job and run the airline.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Health specify more clearly what were the criteria which led the Government to its definition of the disadvantaged for the purposes of free health cover? In particular, is the Minister aware that the income levels which he has given in defining the disadvantaged are such that no single person who is employed, even on the minimum wage, is eligible? Furthermore, is he aware that very few married couples are eligible since the limit of $160 is barely above the minimum wage and would be exceeded by many poor persons working overtime to keep their families?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Naturally I have consulted with my colleague, the Minister for Social Security, in relation to the definition of the disadvantaged. The honourable member has confined his remarks to only one of the categories. He has not mentioned that migrants and refugees in their first six months in Australia will be eligible for treatment. He has not mentioned that unemployed and special beneficiaries and their dependants who qualify within the pensioner health benefit limits will be eligible for free medical care.

ANSWER.PARA: Whilst the honourable gentleman says that not many people fall into the other category, in fact, on my information it will apply to a million Australians. As about 2 million people hold pensioner health benefit cards, this means that about 3 million Australians will come within the ambit of this scheme to help those in genuine need in this country. I do not believe that can be said to be at all ungenerous.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Bradfield having addressed a question to the Treasurer-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The question is out of order.

—I refer the Minister for Health to his ill-defined plans for health provision for the socially disadvantaged. Given that individuals will fall in and out of employment and that individuals will fluctuate around the arbitrary income level, I ask: Firstly, will they require reclassification on each occasion they change status; secondly, will identity cards be regularly issued and recalled; and thirdly, will retrospective classification of persons as socially disadvantaged be allowed after medical services or hospital admission?

—The question again concerns that third section of the disadvantaged classifications which I mentioned. Those classifications will be for six-month periods. Therefore, people who may move in or may move out just over a short period-in other words, those who could be classified as, say, itinerant workers-will have to be so classified only each six months. The period of the classification lasts for six months. If treatment takes place after that six-month period, of course it is perfectly in order for the person again to apply for such classifications.
—Are you going to index the amounts?
—Order! I ask the honourable member for Port Adelaide to cease his constant interjection.
—I think he can hear me.
—Order! I warn the honourable member for Port Adelaide.

—I turn to the last part of the honourable gentleman's question. People who fall into these categories do not have to be so registered before treatment. In fact, it is one of the features of the Government's scheme that people who go along either to a hospital or to a doctor are billed for the services that are provided to them. They can then go to a Department of Social Security office, and if they come within the classifications as defined the costs of their treatment will be dealt with in the way that has been outlined by the Government.

—Is the Minister for Foreign Affairs able to confirm that two widely separated provinces in mainland China are suffering from the effects of natural disasters-one from severe flooding and the other from prolonged drought? Has the Chinese Government taken, for it, an unprecedented course and sought international aid to ease the massive malnutrition and disease resulting from these natural disasters? Finally, has the Australian Government been approached for assistance?

—I can confirm that two Chinese provinces, the provinces of Hubei and Hebei, have been severely affected by flooding and drought respectively, as the honourable gentleman has said. The Chinese Government has sought international aid through the United Nations Disaster Relief Organisation, UNDRO. I can further confirm that UNDRO has approached the Australian Government for assistance for the flood and drought victims concerned. Bearing in mind the humanitarian aspects of the disaster, I have approved the following response to the Chinese appeal: In the first case the provision of medical supplies valued at $A100,000, and in the second case the provision of 10,000 tonnes of wheat currently valued at $A1.5m. Both the Chinese authorities and UNDRO have been informed of Australia's offer and arrangements are being made for the delivery of our assistance in accordance with the wishes of the Chinese Government.

—Can the Minister for Health inform the House who, under the new health arrangements, has responsibility for funding and oversight of the following programs: Aboriginal health centres, women's refuges and the family planning programs?

—There will be a statement made in the House later about Aboriginal medical assistance. Women's refuges come within the absorption area which has already been announced by the Government. The family planning programs again come within the Community Health Program.

—I ask the Minister for Primary Industry: What is the effect upon the Australian meat producer of the marketing of meat from European Economic Community countries? Is there any further action that can be taken by Australia to prevent the so-called dumping of EEC meat on world markets?

—For some time the Australian Government has expressed concern to the European Economic Community about the effect of a common agricultural policy on agricultural production within the Community and the follow-on dumping on to Third World markets that occurs as a result of the overproduction of meat. Indeed, the concern of the Government has been at the highest level. On visits to the EEC the Deputy Prime Minister has expressed our concern in the strongest of terms. As I have pointed out to the House before, other countries are equally concerned at the common agricultural policy. Third World countries that attended the Bangladesh meeting of agricultural Ministers, which I attended a couple of months ago, drew attention to the fact that they are unable to develop their agricultural programs appropriately because they are getting so-called aid or assistance from the EEC in the form of food and fodder and this is causing a retardation of their agricultural programs. It is fair to say that there is concern amongst a wide range of countries. All we can do is continue to expose the falsity of the common agricultural policy and the agricultural program of the EEC and continue to hope that common sense will come to the Commission of the EEC in due course.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: HEALTH CARE FOR THE DISADVANTAGED PERSONS

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Health: Firstly, under the new health scheme will doctors be permitted to charge pensioners and disadvantaged patients more than 85 per cent of the schedule fee? Secondly, what will the practical position be for patients attending private doctors who have no card identifying them as being disadvantaged but who claim to be eligible for such a classification?

—As to the charging procedures of doctors, the present system will continue. Of course, what happens is that doctors very seldom charge pensioners more than 85 per cent of the schedule fee and very seldom claim the $5 which they can claim under the arrangements. In relation to the second part of the question, I have already mentioned this afternoon that people who claim to be within the disadvantaged groups do not necessarily have to be so classified before attending a medical practitioner or a hospital. If they are within that category and do become sick but have not been so classified, they can go to the doctor and the doctor makes a charge. Once they have been classified as disadvantaged patients, the account can be taken to a registered health fund and a pay doctor cheque can be issued or they can pay directly and receive a cheque from the health insurance fund.

—I address my question to the Minister for Transport. Is it a fact that the Air Hostesses Association has asked the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission to ratify a pay increase of $15 a week as a result of the settlement of last week's strike? Is such an increase within the wage indexation guidelines? Are air hostesses becoming too expensive to justify their role as highly paid waitresses? Will the Government consider altering the Air Navigation Regulations to allow safety officers to serve on passenger aircraft in place of air hostesses? Would that allow the airline companies to reduce air fares?

—The air hostesses or flight attendants dispute was settled before the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. It was settled within the wage indexation guidelines. I understand that the airlines have entered into a three-year agreement with the flight attendants or air hostesses. So, that agreement, I think, would be binding on both the airlines and the hostesses.

—I ask a question of the Prime Minister. I refer to the Prime Minister's meeting with the Premiers last Monday at which the Prime Minister was able to force the States to accept a cut of $280m in funds from tax revenue for the coming year. I ask: Is it a fact that Cabinet had agreed to limit these cuts in State finances to $210m and not $280m? Does the Prime Minister have any advice on what effect this additional reduction of $70m will have in squeezing State finances and especially on State sponsored employment? Finally, will the Prime Minister assure the House that this windfall saving of $70m, at the States' expense, will now be used to limit the 17,000 jobs his Government intends to abolish under the decisions announced to Parliament last Thursday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Fraser The Rt Hon J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —It has been the practice of this Government for the Treasurer and the Prime Minister to be given guidelines by Cabinet decision in relation to the negotiations with Premiers at Premiers conferences. So long as it comes out within the guidelines, that can be finally consummated without reference back to the Cabinet. The negotiation with the States was achieved within the guidelines. Obviously there is expressed to the Treasurer and to the Prime Minister a general preference as to the end of the guidelines on which the Government would prefer the negotiations to conclude. What was achieved last Monday was thoroughly in accord with the Cabinet's directions to the Treasurer and to me in relation to that matter. Therefore, there is no question of any additional windfall gain. What was saved was within the expectation of Cabinet when the decision was first made.

ANSWER.PARA: The last part of the honourable gentleman's question shows again that he fails utterly to understand the basic philosophical difference between the Australian Labor Party and the Government in relation to the management of the Australian economy. With every program that is proposed by the Opposition there is the underlying belief that, if the Government spends more, if the Government spends up big and if the Government puts more people on its own payroll, all Australians will be better off. The falsity of that Labor Party approach was demonstrated in Australia in the early 1970s. It has been demonstrated around the world time and again as countries have got into very great difficulties as the result of big spending governments. At a time when we have been exercising expenditure restraint for over five years now, we have been able to move our inflation rate below the average of our trading partners. The employment growth in Australia over the last two years, of over 300,000, is much more than governments would ever be able to provide on their own account. It has come about because we believe in smaller government and taxes being lower than they would otherwise be, strengthening the Australian economy and thus adding to jobs and growth and the well-being of Australian families. Until the Australian Labor Party understands that there is a basic difference in approach, it will never be able to propose policies that will advance the well-being of the Australian people.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr Hyde having addressed a question to the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs-

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr MOORE

TALK.START.PARA: —I have read with--

INTERJECT.PARA: Mr Lionel Bowen-I take a point of order. Is this not anticipating debate? Is this matter not listed in the program for debate under the companies legislation?

TALK.START.PARA: —The question put in its general form is capable of discussion in the overall debate. The Minister can answer the question in the debate.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications. I refer to the section of the Review of Commonwealth Functions report which deals with Telecom Australia and the suggestion that there is to be a sale to the private sector of functions of Telecom as well as the interconnect market. Is it not a fact that the interconnect market relates to the satellite? Is this a subtle way of saying that the satellite and all its potential will be given over to the private sector? For example, does it mean that the whole of data transmission will now be the business of the private sector? As that is the most profitable sector of the satellite, does it not mean that Telecom will have to increase its charges in other directions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —The interconnect market basically is not the satellite peculiarly, as I understand the definition of the word. All sorts of words are used to define it. It is the add-on market. It is all those bits of equipment that go into the point in the wall of a house, office or installation where the telephone network actually plugs into each of the outlets around Australia. The interconnect market under the current jargon, as I have learned it, covers a whole range of equipment from videotex machines through to teledex and all the bits of electronic equipment, including computers, that are capable of being pinned in.

ANSWER.PARA: As far as the satellite is concerned, it is the Government's intention that 49 per cent of the body to be established to operate that satellite should be owned by the private sector. The way and form in which that body will function and operate is still to be determined by the Government and is, of course, a matter for discussion with those involved and interested and ultimately for presentation and consideration by this House before it is finally ratified.

The intention in the Review of Commonwealth Functions report is that where very significant funds are required for the development of this interconnect market a judgment needs to be made as to whether or not those funds might more properly be raised in the private sector and that area operated privately. We see the demand for money to complete the network system around Australia to provide telephones and to provide adequately services that are the monopolised responsibility of Telecom as the prime capital requirement of Telecom. We are concerned that if funds are diverted into all those other areas which might be profitable it will be less possible for the telephone services that must be the prime responsibility of Telecom to be provided adequately. Therefore the decisions taken by the review committee chaired by my colleague the Minister for Industry and Commerce will in fact ensure that Telecom is more adequately able to meet its prime task, not hindered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the Treasurer aware of a claim made on a radio program this morning in which it was stated that government in Australia is still smaller than in many other developed countries such as the United States of America and West Germany? Is that claim correct? What would be the effect on Australia if government were allowed to expand beyond its present level?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of that claim. I listened to it very carefully. I always listen very carefully to views put forward by the honourable member for Gellibrand. They are very instructive on occasions as to where the Labor Party stands on the position of the public sector. Just as he made very clear in his now famous speech to the Labor economists what he thinks of a larger public sector, he again nailed his colours to the mast this morning and said that the Labor Party stands for bigger government. We do not mind the honourable member for Gellibrand doing that as often as he likes. We on this side of the House believe that the national economic need at the moment and the demands of the Australian people are for less and not more government.

ANSWER.PARA: It is no argument in favour of the Labor Party position on the size of government to say that government in Australia is smaller than in other countries. All that means is that many of the policies which are successfully in place in this country are not being emulated sufficiently in other parts of the world. The policies of smaller government which this side of the House has followed so successfully over the last five years have resulted in the strength of the Australian economy becoming the envy of many parts of the industrialised world. It is no accident that the rate of growth of the Australian economy is stronger than the average of the industrialised world. If this is a consequence of the size of our government being smaller than that of the rest of the industrialised world, it is a case for making the size of our public sector still smaller.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to section 12DD of the Remuneration Tribunals Act 1973, I present the Academic Salaries Tribunal's review of salaries of part time tutors, demonstrators and supervisors. The Tribunal's determination and report will be taken into account in the normal way in providing funds for recurrent expenditure by universities and colleges of advanced education.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —For the information of honourable members I present the report of the Industries Assistance Commission on canned ham, short term assistance.
—Pursuant to section 15 of the Housing Assistance Act 1978 I present the annual report for the year 1979-80.
—Mr Speaker, I claim to have been misrepresented.
—Does the honourable gentleman wish to make a personal explanation?
—Yes.
—He may proceed.

—It has been commented publicly and again today in the House by the Minister for the Capital territory (Mr Hodgman) that it would be the intention of a Labor government after 1983-I note for the record that the Minister was gracious enough to acknowledge that there is no doubt about that-to reacquire a particular public authority undertaking which the Government intends to dispose of. For the record and so that there will be do doubt in the future, let me state our attitude on this. It is simply that we will consider the desirability of purchasing public undertakings disposed of by the present Government according to whether the purchase is or the purchases are economically feasible and socially desirable in the circumstances at the time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Assent reported.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received letters from the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) and the honourable member for Dundas (Mr Ruddock) proposing that definite matters of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion today. As required by Standing Order 107, I have selected the matter which, in my opinion, is the most urgent and important, that is, that proposed by the honourable member for Gellibrand, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The severe implications of the Government's action in failing to provide adequate funds to the States.
I therefore call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last Monday the Fraser Government revealed phase 3 of its plan to dismember the Australian public sector. In the previous week we saw the enactment of the first two phases with the announcement of a further revison to health financing arrangements and the results of the so-called razor gang's efforts in reducing government expenditures. This week we saw phase 3-a severe reduction in funds for the States imposed by the Commonwealth at the Premiers Conference. Of course, these are far from being the first attempts by the Fraser Government to reduce government expenditure, but the extent and implications of these three announcements are such as to mark a change of policy. What we are now witnessing is an attempt to bring about increased privatisation of the Australian economy by dismembering the public sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look more closely at what happened at the Premiers Conference. In doing this we have to rely on newspapers because so far the Treasurer (Mr Howard) has made no statement to the Parliament or produced even a Press statement that I am aware of, or that his office can give my office. For information we have to rely on what has been published in the newspapers. We have to bear in mind the background to the Premiers Conference. It was called to consider the formula to be used in the future for deciding the amounts to be allocated to States by way of general revenue payments. This is one of four forms of payments to the States. These general revenue payments to States are funds to be spent as the States like, which is mostly on recurrent expenditures. Past funding arrangements for general revenue grants provided for a percentage-just under 40 per cent-of the previous year's personal income tax receipts to be paid to the States. There was a guarantee for the four years from 1976-77 to 1979-80 that the States would get no less than the previous formula would have given them. That was a formula which became known as the Whitlam formula. This guarantee was relied on by the States in each of the four years because the percentage of tax sharing would not have given them as much as that provided under the Whitlam formula. In 1980-81 there was only the guarantee that the States would get no less in real terms than they had been given in the previous year.

Last Monday the States and the Commonwealth were considering the funding arrangements for 1981-82 and future years. As was reported in the papers, it was decided that for 1980-81 a substantial real decline in revenue grants would occur and for 1982-83 and subsequent years there would be a change in the tax sharing base from income tax to total tax receipts. It was decided also that there would be a continuance of the reduced level of payments incorporated in 1981-82 by fixing the 1981-82 payments as a percentage of total tax. If we look at the detail of the real reduction in 1981-82 we see that the States receive an increase of only 9 per cent in general revenue payments. This is an increase of 9 per cent when the inflation rate, as measured by the consumer price index, is 9.5 per cent. That is not the inflation rate relevant to the States in this matter. What is relevant to the States in regard to these kinds of payments is the implicit deflator for Government consumption expenditure because the States spend this money on goods and, in particular, on wages-which account for 70 per cent of expenditure.

The implicit deflator for government consumption expenditure is not running at 9.5 per cent, which is the rate for the last 12 months in the consumer price index, but 13.3 per cent. This is the inflation rate relevant to the expenditures which the States have to undertake with this money. The States have been given an increase of 9 per cent general revenue payments. Therefore, there is a very substantial difference between what was granted by the Commonwealth to the States and the inflation rate faced by the States in respect of those expenditures. Of course the implicit deflator figure could increase even more in the next 12 months as the inflation rate goes up. However, over the last 12 months the rate of increase has been 13.3. per cent.

In addition, of course, there has been an increase in the population. The rate of increase is 1.2 per cent. Therefore we have a 13.3 per cent inflation rate and a 1.2 per cent population increase, which means that the States have to meet an increase of 14.5 per cent in expenditures at the current level of services-and they have been given a 9 per cent increase in general revenue grants to meet this. Obviously, there is an enormous disparity. If there is no further increase in the rate of inflation, there has been a real cut of 5.5 per cent. There has not been a minor 0.5 per cent reduction but a 5.5 per cent reduction in the real grant per head of population. It is a very severe cutback indeed. It is not a minor cutback but a severe cutback which will have severe implications for the operations of the States. I should note in pasing that in addition to that, apparently an extra one per cent was given to compensate for the abolition of some specific purpose grants to the States. Of course, that made the overall increase 10 per cent but, since that was only compensating for cuts in other areas, it cannot really be included in this analysis. If we are looking at general revenue grants we should compare a 9 per cent increase with a 14.5 per cent requirement at the current inflation rate. That severe reduction must be looked at not only on its own but also in terms of the reductions which have occurred in the past. The fact is that this Government has already brought about a substantial, if not severe, reduction in payments to the States over the last five years.

General revenue grants have been the main growth area in Commonwealth payments to the States. They account for a little under 50 per cent of total payments to the States. Two of the other three forms of payments to the States have fallen in real terms over the last five years. In the last five years general revenue grants have increased in real terms by 19.4 per cent, general capital grants have fallen by 38.6 per cent, specific purpose recurrent payments have increased by 12.5 per cent and specific purpose capital payments have fallen by 54 per cent. In the area of capital payments-that is, general capital grants and specific purpose capital payments-there have been declines of 38.6 per cent and 54 per cent. So, overall there has been a considerable decline in the funds made available to the States. There has been a 6 per cent decline in real terms or, if one takes account of the increase in population of some 6 per cent over that five-year period, there is a decline of more than 12 per cent in real terms per head of population in the payments by this Government to the States. A 12 per cent decline is a very considerable decline indeed, especially when one bears in mind the fact that the payments by the Commonwealth to the States account for 70 per cent of the revenues available to the States. If 70 per cent of the funds available to the States are cut by 12 per cent, quite obviously a considerable reduction is brought about in the capacity of the States to perform. Of course, they have had to cut back in various areas.

That is only what has happened in the past. In addition to that we have now a new phase in which the major growth area-the area of general revenue grants; the one area which has shown a considerable increase over the last five years-has been reduced in real terms. That reduced rate will be incorporated in the increase in future years. This brings about a whole new ball game for the States, especially as in addition to that they have already been warned that there will be little joy in the other areas of payment apart from general revenue grants. They have been told not to expect anything great to happen-not that they would, on past experience-in the other three areas of payment to them. They have been told that their infrastructure borrowing approvals are likely to be cut back, so they will not be able to borrow as much for infrastructure development.

As a result of the decisions made last week in respect of hospital financing arrangements and the razor gang decisions, they have also been given a whole new array of responsibilities which they are expected to fund and which they have been compensated for to only a minor degree in the decisions announced on Monday. So, the States have been given a whole array of messages that their funds will be severely cut. They have been given more responsibilities and less finance and have been told that there will be less finance available in the future. This is all on top of the considerable reduction of 12 per cent in real terms per head of population, which reduction has occurred in Federal funding to them over the last five years.

The effect on the States of these cutbacks will be severe. Quite obviously the States will have to reduce expenditures or increase taxes and charges, or both. If we were to look at the aspect of reduced expenditures, we should examine the areas where States spend their money. The States spend their money, firstly, on education; secondly, on health; thirdly, on roads; fourthly, on law, order and public safety; and, fifthly, on social security and welfare. They are the five major areas of State expenditures. If there is a severe reduction in the funds available to them, those are the areas in which the cutbacks must be made. Let there be no doubt that this Government is deliberately bringing about, not only through its own direct actions but also through its indirect actions in respect of cutting back funds to the States, further cutbacks in these social infrastructure areas-if one might broadly term it as such-of education, health, roads, law and order and social security. In respect of increased taxes and charges, quite obviously the Government expects there will be some increases in State taxes and charges. The Treasurer said so. On the Australian Broadcasting Commission's lunchtime news broadcast yesterday he was reported as saying:
Some price increases and rises in State charges will be unavoidable.

There we have the Treasurer saying that he expects, as a result of the decisions which he forced on the States, that they will have to jack up their rates and charges. Of course, that will not only have an impact on the people who pay them but also it will have more general impacts which I will come to in a moment. Certainly in the hospital area there is no doubt that the charges will increase. I understand that the States were told by the Commonwealth that they would have to increase their public hospital charges by 60 per cent for public wards, from $50 a day to $80 a day. Whilst the Government has not denied that yet, as far as I am aware it has not affirmed it either. It has been reported and I understand that to be the case. The Commonwealth also expects that the States could utilise stage 2 of new federalism, which will be incorporated in the future arrangements. It allows for the States applying an income tax surcharge. So we could well have, as a result of the Government's decisions, the States applying an income tax surcharge. This means that we would have double income tax. The States clearly are reluctant to impose such a tax but they may be forced into the situation, if these cuts go on, where they have little alternative.

The effect on the economy generally is that it will cause increased unemployment. About 70 per cent of government recurrent expenditure is spent on wages. If the Government cuts back on that funding obviously it will have less money to spend on wages and so jobs will have to go. We will not just lose the 17,000 jobs as a result of the so-called razor gang's activities, we will clearly lose more jobs as a result of the Government's cutbacks in funding to the States. I ask the House to bear in mind that in the 12 months to April of last year-according to the latest figures which are available, because the Government stopped the publishing of figures which relate to the period after that-one-third of employment growth in the wage and salary earner area came from State government employment. That growth simply will not occur in the future because this Government is ensuring that it will not by cutting back these funds to the States.

Obviously we will get increased inflation from the increased charges which the Treasurer expects to occur. Obviously we will have less economic growth because there will be less expenditure in the government area. At present one of the major stimuli to economic growth is, in fact, the increase in the public sector as occurred in this current financial year. That will clearly not occur next year because of various decisions taken by the Government, including this decision to cut back funding to the States. There are several reasons for these reductions. Firstly, there is the sheer ideological belief by the Treasurer and his cohorts that the public sector is too large and needs to be cut back because of the feeling in their blood that it prefers a larger private sector. That, I think, is the overwhelming motivation which they have. In addition to that, the Government says that the States are doing well. This is obviously a false claim.

The Government said in a paper given to the States at the Premiers Conference which was held on Monday that the States had been able to increase their services by some 3 per cent per annum per capita over the last five years because that had been the rate of growth in the States' recurrent expenditure on goods and services. Of course, that was only recurrent expenditure. If one looks at the total expenditure and includes capital, one finds there was a mere one per cent growth over that period. Capital expenditure declined by 5.7 per cent in real terms per head over that period. The Government has said that there is physical crowding out, that the public sector is too large and that there is no room for the private sector to grow. The Government does not give any proof of that. As I have said elsewhere and as the Treasurer mentioned at Question Time in reply to a Dorothy Dix question, the fact is that Australia's public sector is one of the smallest in the Western world. Many countries which have much larger public sectors than Australia have shown much faster rates of economic growth than Australia over the post-war period. The size of the public sector apparently has been no inhibition in those countries achieving that.

Finally, the Government says that there is financial crowding out, that a large public sector causes high interest rates. The fact is that in the last three years the public sector borrowing requirement has declined from 5.7 per cent of gross domestic product to 3.4 per cent. Interest rates have gone up enormously while the public sector borrowing requirement, a factor which the Treasurer said we must look at, has gone down considerably as a proportion of GDP. How does he square that with his argument that we have to reduce the size of the public sector to get interest rates down? Of course, the Government also wants to make room for income tax cuts. There are other ways of providing for income tax cuts other than dismembering the public sector.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This matter of public importance relates specifically to the Premiers Conference and the reasonableness or otherwise of the arrangements settled on Monday for revenue-sharing between the Commonwealth and the States. I wish to spend a little time reminding the House that the purpose of the Premiers Conference last Monday which was convened at the request of the States was to talk about the long term arrangements which will prevail after 1 July this year between the Commonwealth and the States regarding general revenue-sharing. I make it quite clear that the arrangement entered into in 1976 after the election of the Fraser Government, contemplated a review of those arrangements within four years. As a result of an agreement between the Commonwealth and the States last year the arrangements were continued for a further year, with a short term guarantee.

SPEECH.PARA: I mention that at the outset because some suggestions have been made from various quarters that in some way the new arrangements represent an abrogation by the Commonwealth of the commitments in the agreement entered into in 1976. Plainly that is quite wrong. It was always part of the agreement that the arrangements would come under review. During that review it was open to either party to argue that there should be fundamental changes to the arrangements. I reject completely the charges made in some State quarters that because the outcome of Monday's conference represented a significant change in certain areas of the original agreement in some way the Commonwealth has broken the agreement. Nothing could be further from the truth. In the new arrangements we have continued the concept of revenue-sharing. We have rejected a reversion to the old formula approach which was productive of at least as many arguments in the days when it operated and perhaps more than the arguments which have inevitably arisen between the Commonwealth and the States under the new revenue-sharing arrangements.

I think it is fanciful to imagine that we could ever have a Premiers conference in which there was not some level of disagreement between the Commonwealth and the States.
