If the representatives of seven governments meet around a table and only one of those governments is the provider and the other six are the spenders of the money it is inevitable that the spenders will want more from the provider than the provider feels it responsible or possible to give. That is the truth and the inevitable circumstance surrounding Premiers Conferences.

We approached this Conference with a desire to see the revenue-sharing arrangements persist. We approached this Conference with a view to achieving a long term arrangment which was workable. Overall we approached it with a view to achieving an arrangement which was consonant with Australia's present economic needs. That means that we approached the Conference having very much in mind the considerations that affected the Government's deliberations in its recent Review of Commonwealth Functions. We approached it, recognising that the demand of the Australian people at present is for less and not more government. If the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) says that the Government is in the business of reducing the size of the public sector then I am quite prepared on behalf of the Governmenmt to plead guilty to that charge. We are concerned to reduce those aspects of the public sector which are unnecessary, unnecessarly expensive, and unnecessarily duplicate the activities of the private sector.

Our commitment to that goal is very firm and very obvious. It has been in evidence very much in recent weeks and was in evidence last Monday. We believe the community need and the community sentiment at present are to have smaller government and to allow individuals greater command over decisions affecting the disposition of the resources that they control and the incomes that they earn. This does not mean a turning of the back upon areas of essential government responsibility. Rather it means turning our back on those areas which involve waste and duplication, turning our back on areas of unnecessary expenditure, applying far more rigorously the principle of directing welfare assistance to those who need the help most. It aids the vulnerable and the weak in our community little if we are to hitch our star to the concept of universal benefits.

There is nothing antagonistic to the interests of the vulnerable and the poor in this community in the new health arrangements. Rather what the new health arrangements recognise is that there is something quite wrong and something quite indefensible about an arrangement that enables a person, irrespective of income or assets, to walk in to the out-patients department of any public hospital in Australia and be treated for nothing. If that is humanitarian and if that is looking after the interests of the vulnerable in the community, those who argue that have a different concept of need and vulnerability than those who sit on this side of the House have. Because, to the extent that we require people who are able to pay for the provision of services so to pay, government is in a better position to give greater help to those people who really need help. That lies very much at the heart of the sort of priorities that this side of the House has and, of course, lies at the heart of the differences that exist in priorities between this Government and the other side of the House.

As I said at the outset, the approach that the Government adopted at the Premiers Conference is very much consistent with the approach that we have adopted in a number of other areas in recent weeks. The honourable member for Gellibrand spoke about a figure of 13.3 per cent as being the relevant inflation figure-I do not think I get him wrong-that one has to take into account in order to determine whether we have given the States a fair deal in general revenue payments. I understand that the honourable member chooses the figure of 13.3 per cent because that is the implicit deflator for government expenditure. I say to the honourable member for Gellibrand and to the House that not even the Premiers claimed that 13.3 per cent was the appropriate figure to use. One of the reasons that it is not the appropriate figure to use is that, being the implicit deflator for government expenditure, the base contains as a very significant component of defence expenditure, for which costs are rising at a very sharp rate. So is expenditure and rightly so. It will go up by 7 per cent in real terms next year and it will go on rising until it reaches about 3 per cent of gross domestic product. Everybody knows that defence expenditure is borne totally by the Commonwealth Government. To use in a debate on the reasonableness of the financial provision for the States a deflator that includes as one of its major components an item of expenditure of which not 1c is borne by the States is to use quite the wrong figure and quite the wrong measurement. That, of course, is probably the reason that the States and their representatives, the Premiers, on Monday did not use that figure. I reject the figure given by the honourable member for Gellibrand as being a reasonable bench-mark. It is neither relevant nor appropriate.

The honourable member talked about the pattern of payments to the States by the Fraser Government over the last five years. When we look at those payments I think we ought to remind ourselves what has happened to the pattern of overall government expenditure during that period. Of course, the levels of payments to the States were very high in 1976 because levels of all forms of government expenditure were very high in 1976 when this Government came to office. The levels had grown on average by about 10.5 per cent in real terms over the previous three years. Of course, payments to the States had been no exception. We inherited an arrangement and we applied an arrangement that involved a guarantee that provided a betterment factor of 3 per cent, that is, a guaranteed increase in real terms of 3 per cent in general revenue payments over the period that that guarantee operated.

Betwen 1976 and 1980-81 expenditure by the States in real terms through general revenue payments grew by 7.8 per cent, 7.5 per cent, 3 per cent, and 3.6 per cent and 0.3 per cent. That was a consequence of the quite generous arrangements that were adopted in 1976. As long ago as the Premiers Conference last year the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) and I both indicated to the States that it would not be possible for us to continue an arrangement that was as generous as that, an arrangement which had enabled most State governments to provide tax reductions in a number of their Budgets during that period. We do not criticise the governments for doing that but we remind them of what we told them, and I remind the House too because it is relevant to the question of whether the States were being treated reasonably during that period. It is also relevant to the sorts of priorities that will have to be applied by the States as a consequence of the new arrangements that have been entered into.

The honourable member for Gellibrand upbraded me for saying yesterday that some State charges may rise. Unlike the honourable member for Gellibrand, I do not believe that it is possible always to prevent certain increases in charges and costs. It is unreal to imagine that one can. Of course, as a consequence of some of the new health arrangements we expect that certain charges made by the States will rise. Indeed, the basis of the arrangements that have been proposed in respect of hospitals is to take into account the assessed revenue raising capacity of the States in the hospitals area. This is not an inflationary approach. This is not an irresponsible approach. Rather it is an approach that recognises, and recognises very directly, certain realities. One of the realities is that services as expensive as health services cannot continue to be provided on the basis that, irrespective of need, they will be provided free. All that does, as I mentioned earlier, is to make available to people in the community who can well afford to pay for the health services themselves the same level of services as are made available to the poor and the vulnerable who are supposed to be the major concern of the people who sit opposite.

I remind the House that the Premiers Conference was a very significant part of the Government's program of getting the balance between the public and private sector in our community into proper perspective. We believe that as a consequence of the arrangements worked out at the Premiers Conference it is within the capacities of States through the ordering of their own priorities to make their judgments because under our federalism arrangements there are fewer tied grants, there is less direction, there is less dictation, there is a lesser emphasis by the Commonwealth Government on its own priorities and there is a greater flexibility on the part of the States to set their priorities and to make their decisions as they should. It has been a consistent theme of this Commonwealth Government to provide the States with a much greater flexibility. That is once again the case in respect of the decisions we have made to absorb certain payments into the general revenue grants to the States.

This side of the House, this Government, stands for reducing the size of the public sector in a fashion which protects those programs which are needed to protect those in the community who really need assistance but reducing it in such a way as allows individuals to make a greater range of choices over the resources they own and over the incomes that they earn. We have that commitment and we are pursuing that path because we believe that is the economic need of Australia at present. We believe that that is the requirement of the Australian people. We believe that that type of society and that type of approach will more likely provide to the great majority of Australians the sort of incentive and the sort of climate for self-endeavour, self-fulfilment and self-achievement which are the basis of national economic prosperity.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howe Mr B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is now beginning to face up, or at least it is forcing the States to face up, to the consequences of its own failure. It has simply failed, after five years in office, to produce a consistent pattern of broadly based and balanced growth. Given its commitment to fiscal conservatism, it has now nowhere else to go and it has to cut deeply into the social wage. It has commenced what will be a bitter attack on the people and on the working families of Australia. The trend, of course, has been there. Commonwealth payments to the States have fallen by 12 per cent to 14 per cent over the last five years. Even including infrastructure, there has been a fall of 7 per cent in total funds available to the States.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government commenced its term of office in 1975 with an attack on Labor's urban and regional programs which meant severe cutbacks in special purpose grants. It has sought to restrain the growth in Commonwealth spending in fields such as social security, health, public housing and education. In each of those areas, all crucial to any notion of equity on welfare in the community, it has not sought to reduce overall costs but simply to reduce the Commonwealth's responsibility. The aptly named razor gang is now on about a more profound savaging of those programs and, in some cases, their elimination as national programs. Through the cutbacks in general revenue grants it is seeking to ensure that the States slash programs in the area of the social wage while pressing them to introduce as widely as possible the user-pays principle, which will mean that those who can afford to pay for services will get them, those who cannot either will not get the services or will get them in an emasculated and depreciated form.

The savageness and insensitivity of the Government's action will shock many, but not us. We know from bitter experience that the Government is led by people whose experience is limited to the public schools, elite clubs, squatters' balls and corporate boardrooms. It is backed by a back bench of half-baked Friedmanite pseudo-economists who have been encouraged by restrictions to speaking engagements at blue-rinse-set socials and Apexian seminars, where novelty is required more than any serious contribution to economic policy. Indeed, it is the lack of a firm policy base for these cost cutting proposals which must cause thoughtful people the most profound concern. There is little feeling in the coalition party room for the consequences of the Government's decisions. There is little feeling for the problems which have arisen and which will arise in relation to the restructuring of the Australian economy around a renewed emphasis by corporate investors, if not by the Government, on resource development and the development of high technology industries.

It does not appear to be recognised that while long term gains may flow from this restructuring, there are certainly short term and will be future long term costs. It is the short term costs which have caused the Government to move towards such draconian measures. The Commonwealth, which has been unable to encourage economic growth, and therefore growth in revenues, at a fast enough rate, is now setting out to eliminate or reduce social programs. Having already encouraged the view that we are not one nation but a mere collection of States, it is seeking in two principal ways to shift the burden of the current transition onto the States. Firstly, it is seeking to move financial responsibility to the States for higher taxes; that is, it is seeking to press the States to take on the odium of double taxation. Secondly, it is seeking to give the States the responsibility for more of the welfare bill or, alternatively, for reducing social expenditure.

The States certainly cannot win in these circumstances, and the people will lose, whatever the States try to do. But after all, the name of the game is to ensure that people are forced to reduce their standard of living without their being able to point to this unpopular Government as being responsible. Thus the States will continue to be given assistance in areas of physical infrastructure and support for the corporate sector. However, they will have funds reduced which would enable them to maintain basic housing, education, health and transport programs. We ought not for a moment buy the rubbish we have just heard from the Treasurer (Mr Howard) about how these programs will not turn on the question of basic services and basic equity in the community. These proposals are about inequity. If they are accepted by the Australian community we will be accepting a concept of two Australians, and we ought to recognise that.

One should not attempt to see any rationality in this program but rather the rationalisation of political opportunism. The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), in political trouble, is implementing a program which he believes will save him and his Government. The reality of the cutbacks, as the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) has pointed out, is quite clear. Under general revenue grants, real cuts of the order of 5.5 per cent will be achieved in the next financial year. Many social programs will be affected, but let me single out some of those for special attention. Firstly, let us take health. In this area the Government has granted the same level of funding in real terms for the next financial year, less the amount the States could be expected to collect from the introduction of user charges for people in in-patient and out-patient facilities. This means that patients will have to pay or get into expensive health insurance schemes. Insurance premiums will go up because the States are being forced to increase their charges at the behest of the Commonwealth.

The States are being pressed by these measures to move towards a rationalisation of hospital programs, particularly in the public sector. On the other hand, increased subsidies for private beds will mean that the States will see private beds increasing while public beds do not increase and, in fact, decrease. Furthermore, the Commonwealth funds will come through in a way in which the States will have to choose between the funding of hospitals and the need to take responsibility for community health centres, school dental programs and other community programs. This difficult choice will be compounded by the greater pressure which can be exerted by high technology hospitals against the much weaker community health and dental health programs. In addition, the States are to get the full responsibility for much of public health, including occupational health. The Commonwealth will transfer to the States the Commonwealth Laboratories' responsibility for many of the testing facilities at Commonwealth level and for a number of public health programs. Finance will be reduced even for a road safety program.

Secondly, the area of education will be sharply affected by the razor gang proposals. Not only will it be affected by the reduction of funds for school capital works but also it will be fighting for funds from necessarily reduced State Budgets. The partial demolition of the Schools Commission will mean that resources will be lost for curricula planning, assessment of needs of schools, and the maintaining of some equity between the public and private sectors of education. The States are being forced to rationalise territory education or pay for it themselves, particularly in the area of colleges of advanced education. State members will have to pay the political price, not the members of this Government. The elimination of schools of engineering is staggering in view of the Government's commitment to resource-based development, and the rationalisation of teacher education is being carried out in a way which absolves the Commonwealth from the responsibility. There is considerable debate about what the demand for teachers will be, with shifting demographic patterns, and there is no question at the present time, at least in Victoria, that many more teachers could be helpfully employed if needs-based staffing were introduced. In areas such as education the States have already been involved in activities designed to rationalise. We will have a reduction in the quality of education which will take us back rapidly to the darkest days of the 1960s. Again, Australia is on a path different from that of almost every developed country.

Another area which over a number of years has felt the sharpness of the razor is the area of public housing. Net payments to the States, expressed in 1980-81 prices, have seen a dramatic decline since the Fraser Government was elected. Net funds have fallen from $515m in 1974-75 to $75m in the current financial year and will fall still further in the next financial year. As was pointed out by the Victorian Minister of Housing, Mr Kennett, total State repayments are likely to exceed the grant from the Commonwealth for the first time this year; that is, the States will be paying back more to the Commonwealth than they will actually receive. They will have no net money from the Commonwealth to spend in terms of meeting current housing needs. One could go on to talk about transport and the absurdity of a Government which is getting $3 billion from oil revenues cutting out the urban public transport grants which might do something about energy conservation within Australia.

Essentially, what the Fraser Government is on about is making Australians the peasants of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries. We are going to have the worst living standards in the developed world. The Treasurer shakes his head, but of course the Government is cutting out the compilation of the statistics which will enable us to measure these things. In terms of school retention rates, we have an appalling record. We have the lowest public housing sector of any country in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. No Federal government in the world is currently placing less emphasis on urban public transport in the face of the energy crisis than this Government is. In terms of health, we are being taken back to the 1950s. The Australian people will not put up with it. Members of the Government parties, wherever they go in Australia, will find increasing hostility. The Prime Minister will be swept out. I believe the whole of Cabinet will also be swept out because what they are doing is outrageous.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lusher Mr S.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have been subjected in this place to another tirade from one of the greatest of the left wing ideologues. Never having made any money himself and never having had a need to survive in the real world, the honourable member for Batman (Mr Howe) continues to pursue this profligate philiosophy of hand-outs and big spending.
—You talk about hand-outs. What rubbish!
—He has a big spending mentality that throws all responsibility to the wind.
—The Country Party should talk about hand-outs.
—He brands himself for what he is, and he helps to make a major contribution to putting his party on the Opposition benches and keeping them there for years to come.
—You would take every cent you could get out of the public purse.
-Order!
—I congratulate him on the contribution he has made.
—Let's hear a little sense.

—Order! The honourable member for Hume will resume his seat. The honourable member for Batman will cease interjecting. The honourable member for Hume might address himself to the subject matter before the House.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. I suggest that the honourable member for Hume cease his derogatory remarks about the honourable member for Batman. I do not see that what the honourable member for Batman may or may not have earned in the past has anything to do with what he might say in this debate.
—Order! There is no point of order. The Chair has not read anything of an offensive nature in the remarks of the honourable member for Hume. I call the honourable member for Hume.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I congratulate the honourable member for Batman on his contribution to this debate, because he has done more than many of his colleagues to ensure that this Government stays on these benches for years to come. I cannot let go by the opportunity to make passing reference to the fact that the honourable member for Batman refers to this Government attempting to make Australians the peasants of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development. We only have to look at the record of what this country is achieving in terms of any standards of the OECD to realise that the policies of this Government, on any standard are taking Australia far in front of those countries with which we choose to compare ourselves. If we look at the situation that existed in 1973, 1974 and 1975, we will see that that Government of which the honourable member was a party was using the international situation as an excuse for the disastrous performance on the part of Australia at that time. This Government is demonstrating not only that we are able to do as well as other countries but also that we can do better. Under the Whitlam Government we did not do as well but worse than other countries. That is the reality of the situation.

SPEECH.PARA: This morning the Opposition spokesman on these matters said on the radio that the Australian Labor Party stands for bigger government. He said that as recently as this morning. The story does not change because Commonwealth outlays doubled in a couple of years under the Whitlam Administration, and tax went the same way. I remember a very interesting interview with the then Leader of the Opposition, Mr Whitlam, who subsequently became Prime Minister. He was asked: 'How will you finance your programs and your promises, Mr Whitlam?' He answered: 'By the inflationary growth in taxation'. That is the philosophy that the Labor Party has been following ever since, and it is the only bankrupt philosophy that it has been able to put forward in the last couple of election campaigns and in debates such as we are engaging in today.

The Australian people have had enough of big government, big taxation, and government interference and regulation in the lives of individuals and corporations. This Government is rejecting the Labor Party's philosophies and the Australian people are backing this Government. We only have to look at the opinion polls that came out today to see exactly what is happening in the community. The Labor Party is out of step and it ought to understand that. The philosophy of this Government is clear. It is the philosophy expressed by the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to the South Australian Liberal Party before Christmas. We are now seeing this philosophy being implemented. It has taken us five years to do so but the disruption that was caused between 1972 to 1975 meant that we had no option but to tread softly and to implement change cautiously. However, we are implementing it and we are now starting to see the benefits of it.

Three major decisions were made last week. I regard last week as one of the watersheds of Australian economic management. Changes were announced on the matter of health, the Review of Commonwealth Functions made its report and decisions were taken at the Conference. Brilliant decisions were made on those occasions, decisions that the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Government can stand proudly behind because they are the sorts of decisions that will put this country right on the road to recovery and keep it way out in front of all these profligate spending socialist economies with which the Opposition wants us to compare ourselves.

We must reverse the process of the late 1960s and the early 1970s whereby governments used the power of the purse to buy into areas of traditional State responsibility-areas such as health, transport, education and housing. The theory then rife was that there should be standardisation and not differences among the States.The Australian Schools Commission is the greatest example of that. The theory was: 'Let us not have any competition among the States. Let us impose a common standard on all the States and make sure that every school achieves the same standard and does not get beyond it'. I reject that proposition, and I believe this Government rejects it. We must remove duplication and Commonwealth interference in areas for which we have no constitutional responsibility, other than through the back door of a section 96 grant. For my money the smaller the section 96 grants and the bigger the revenue sharing grants, the better I like it. The Government is moving in that direction and that is the way in which it should continue to move. That is the way in which we will achieve the sort of growth that we need in this country-not with the dead hand of governments trying to direct people, not with the dead hands of bureaucrats in ivory towers trying to determine where every dollar of the taxpayers money is to be spent.

We must remove waste, where waste is defined as expenditure for which there is no justification in terms of need. Any government is expected to respond to needs, not to wants. The Opposition's hand-out mentality is that all one has to do is to ask for something and big brother government will hand it out. I reject that and the Government rejects that. It is about time the Opposition came to its senses and realised that the people are fed up with that philosophy. We must clear the way to reduce the level of taxation by eliminating duplication, waste and unnecessary government involvement in the economy and in the market-place. This Government is taking the right steps along that path.

As the Treasurer so rightly stated, we must get the right balance between the Government's share of the gross domestic product and that of the private sector. We must provide room in the economy for the private sector to grow. Governments have no money. They have only the money that they take from people. The more money they take from people, the less money people and businesses have to invest and spend according to their priorities. The influence of the Labor Party in the Federal sphere and in the State sphere has been throttling this economy over the years. The revenue forgone by this Government, following a long series of reductions in taxation over the last five years, is a significant amount of money, and it must continue to be a significant amount of money. We must give people responsibility for spending their incomes. What reason for incentive is there if people work harder and governments of the philosophy that the Opposition aspire to and espouse take that money and tell them that they know better how to spend it. I would have preferred a full restoration of the economy before any tax cuts were made, but I give credit to the Government for achieving both at the same time. It is one of those occasions on which I was wrong and the Government was right.

The States have a responsibility to play their part in this process. In the past they have just not done so. They have had real increases in their expenditure every year. The States must examine their activities, as the Federal Government has. They must reduce their Public Service, as the Federal Government has. They must accept their constitutional responsibilities and not hide behind the Commonwealth apron-strings and the section 96 grants. The States must accept the odium of raising funds if they want to take the credit for spending funds. There is no doubt whatsoever that the States were fat after the years of Whitlam profligate spending and they have not reduced their spending. As I said, they have had real increases every year and have gone into even further extravagances as is evidenced by the incredible situation in New South Wales, which I know the Minister at the table is as violently against as I am, having been involved in political organisations. The New South Wales State Government is whinging about the amount of money it is getting from the Federal Government and yet it is introducing legislation into its Parliament to provide for the public funding of elections. If there is one thing that is the paragon of privacy and of freedom of the individual it is the way he votes in an election for the party of his choice. Yet there will be a situation in New South Wales, at least, where the public purse will determine payments to political parties for elections and for party political purposes. The matter of public importance introduced by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) is a farce and a sham. It ought to be thrown out of this place for what it is.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The discussion is now concluded.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The main purpose of this Bill is to amend the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 to incorporate in that Act the new provisions of the revised General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Anti-Dumping Code and the GATT Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code. These codes were included in a number of understandings reached in the Tokyo round of the multi-lateral trade negotiations concluded in December 1979. The Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act 1975 is based on the principles and requirements of the original GATT Anti-Dumping Code. Australia acceded to that Code in 1975. The Government announced on 25 June 1980 that Australia should accede to the revised GATT Anti-Dumping Code. This decision took into account the views of State governments, industry associations and other interested groups within the community.

The Bill contains the minor amendments which are necessary before Australia can accede to the revised code. The amendments empower the Minister to accept undertakings from exporters to raise their export prices to undumped levels. Retrospective dumping duties may be imposed where the undertakings have been violated. The amendments also include additional criteria for assessment of normal values of goods in countries where the Government substantially influences domestic prices. Other amendmenets are based on measures contained in the Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code. Principally, they empower the Minister to accept undertaking by governments of the exporting country to offset the effect of any subsidy and to impose retrospective countervailing duties. They also include additional criteria for determining the amount of subsidy in the case of goods exported from countries where the Government substantially influences prices.

No final decision on the question of Australia's accession to the GATT Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code has been announced. However, the proposed amendments are desirable in themselves. The Government is of the view that the amendments will strengthen the powers to protect Australian industry against any injurious effects of subsidised imports. The Bill also proposes further amendments designed to remedy deficiencies which have become apparent during administration of the Act since 1975. These amendments are technical and modify both dumping and countervailing provisions. They are expected to enhance the Government's ability to protect Australian industries against dumped or subsidised imports. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr West) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

This Bill is associated with the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Amendment Bill 1981. Its main purpose is to amend section 45 of the Customs Act 1901 to vary the time for which the Customs may retain securities taken for the purposes of the Customs Tariff (Anti-Dumping) Act. The amendments are consistent with the provisions of the revised General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade Anti-Dumping Code and the GATT Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code. Both Codes provide for the taking of securities as provisional measures pending finalisation of inquiries into allegations of injurious dumping and subsidisation. To conform with the Anti-Dumping Code the provisions of the Customs Act 1901 will need to be amended to allow securities to be held for a period of four months and for the period to be extended to six months if so requested by the exporter of the goods. For the Subsidies and Countervailing Measures Code the period of retention is extended from three months to four months. I commend this Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr West) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Moore, and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Moore The Hon J.C.

TALKER.NAME: Mr MOORE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.

The Customs Tariff Amendment Bill 1981 now before the House proposes amendments to the Customs Tariff Act 1966. The Bill, which contains 18 schedules, is necessary to enact tariff changes which have been introduced into the Parliament at various times since May 1980, by Customs Tariff Proposals Nos. 8-20 (1980) and Proposals Nos. 1-5 (1981). In the main, the amendments give effect to decisions by the Government in respect of the following reports by the Industries Assistance Commission and the Temporary Assistance Authority: Apples and Pears; Certain Goods Made From Carbon or Graphite; Certain Soft Sided Containers; Certain Works Trucks and Stackers; Cheese; Chemical Products (Part B); Continuation of Assistance for Insulators; Crushing or Grinding Machines; Electric Motors, Generators and Rotary Converters; Fluorescent and Filament Lamps; Gearboxes, Gears and Shaft Couplings; Iron and Steel Industry; Manufactured Tobacco; Metal Cans and Canisters of Iron or Steel; Musical Instruments and Parts and Accessories Therefor; Polymeric Plasticisers and Certain Polyester Polyols; Tanned and Finished Leather; Dressed Fur; and Textiles, Clothing and Footwear.

Honourable members will recall that when the tariff proposals were introduced into the House, a comprehensive account of the IAC's recommendations and Government decisions were outlined each time. Other amendments contained in the Bill provide for: Amended tariff preference rates for certain goods from developing countries; changes arising from Australia's commitment to the South Pacific Regional Trade and Economic Co-operation Agreement; and the addition of certain goods to Schedule A of the New Zealand-Australia Free Trade Agreement. The only amendments not already included in the proposals make provision for the removal of all remaining preferential rates for goods from United Kingdom and Ireland with effect from 1 July 1981 and for some changes of an administrative nature. A summary of amendments for each schedule setting out the nature of the changes has been prepared and copies are available from the Table Office. I commend the Bill to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr West) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRIAL RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT INCENTIVES AMENDMENT BILL 1981

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 8 April, on motion by Mr Thomson:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is an important Bill which extends and expands Australia's contribution to industrial research and development; and, one might add, not before time. A fundamental contradiction runs through the legislation. We, on the Opposition side, award it the sound of one-hand clapping, so far as it goes; but it does not go far enough. The Bill is grossly inadequate in scope. As I will indicate later and as will be eloquently put by the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi), the Bill's timing is very odd. It utterly contradicts the philosophy which was set out last Thursday in the report of the 'Razor Gang'. There are an extraordinary number of inconsistencies in the legislation. The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) has indicated that the purpose of this legislation is to encourage industrial research and development. The Minister in his second reading speech said:

SPEECH.PARA: Funding has risen from $14m in 1977-78 to $54m in 1980-81-nearly a four-fold rise within three years, despite the need for continuing expenditure restraints.
Actually if we take the factor of inflation into account it is more like a 2.7 increase. The sum is equivalent to $37.8m in 1977-78 dollars. The Minister went on:
The rationale for government assistance rests on the proposition that there are disparities between the private and national returns from research and development expenditure. The market--
These are the Minister's words, not someone from the Labor Party-

does not provide enough incentives for firms to undertake research and development. The result is a national under-investment in industrial research and development and a tendency for firms to concentrate on relatively short term industrial research and development. The fundamental purpose of the program is to correct this market failure.
We applaud what the Minister said. The Minister went on:

Against this background, the Government has decided that, in future, an industrial research and development project will be supported only where it involves a substantial degree of risk or where a firm is unable to gain enough of the profits generated by the industrial research and development to justify the project.
The Minister went on:

To compensate for inflation as well as to strengthen the incentive to firms to undertake the industrial research and development, the Government proposes to increase ceilings from $500,000 to $750,000 per year for project grants and from $25,000 to $40,000 per year for commencement grants. The grants will remain taxable.

So the Government gives with one hand and takes away with the other. If we look at that famous document, the ministerial statement entitled Review of Commonwealth Functions, then look to see what has happened to the Department of Science and Technology and look in particular at attachment C which sets out the number of Commonwealth bodies which are to be abolished, we find that of the 18 bodies that are to be abolished 11 belong to the Department of Science and Technology. They include such areas as the Information Technology Council, the Advisory Committee on International Scientific and Technological Activities, the Australian Inventions Advisory Committee and the Technology Transfer Advisory Board. When we go back to other parts of the 'Razor Gang' report we find that there will no longer be a science adviser within the Department of Foreign Affairs-one of those listening points where we might expect to get information which could be brought back to our national advantage. Australia's scientific participation in the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation, for example, where there is a lot of information to be had, is to cease.

If we look at the provision under the Defence Department we find a Government decision in respect of defence science, research and development for direct Commonwealth involvement to be reduced. The private sector and universities are to be encouraged to perform activities. With what? When there has been an enormous cut-back in expenditure at the tertiary level, on what does the Government expect them to carry out these prodigies of research in defence when notoriously such research is extraordinarily expensive? We find somewhere else under the rationalisation of colleges of advanced education in the education sector that an amount has been earmarked to rationalise activities for the expansion of technological and business studies. How much do honourable members think the Government has offered? The amount is $5m. The Government is really big-hearted. Its argument normally is 'leave it to the market'.

Many of the very high-minded objectives that have been outlined by the Minister for Science and Technology in all candour and honesty, because he is perhaps the most candid and honest of the Ministers that we have in the present Government, have been destroyed or prejudiced by the 'Razor Gang'. It is virtually the old Department of Productivity which has been eliminated with the Department of Science and Technology. All the functions that were related to the former Department of Productivity have gone. These functions were very significant because they are the very parts of the Government which might have enabled Australia to assist its fight-back capacity, to assist us to move into high technology areas.

There are extraordinary inconsistencies and contradictions between what the Government says and what it is actually doing. Sometimes it is hard to tell whether the Government is following the ideas of Milton Friedman or of Marty Feldman. The Government says that it has based its legislation partly on the report of the Committee of Inquiry into Technological Change in Australia. I think the CITCA report showed the lowest level of intellectual vitality of any report put out, even by this Government. This intellectually disreputable report dodged every major issue, particularly on questions of technology transfer. In the technologically advanced world there is no country as disadvantaged as is Australia. The starvation of education and research by the Fraser Government is condemning Australia to third rate status in the technologically advanced world.

Australia's future stability and development as a technologically advanced liberal democracy are already threatened by five factors: First, the prevailing lack of intellectual vitality; second, a contracting education base; third, an inadequate investment in research and development; fourth, absence of a entrepreneurial spirit; and fifth the absence of risk capital for new ventures. The Parliament is poorly informed on matters relating to science and technology and the media expresses total disinterest in the discussion of new ideas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is this relevant to the Bill?
—It is absolutely central to the Bill.
—This is not relevant.

—It is utterly relevant. Australia has the worst informed legislature in the democratic world, lacking the resources or the intellectual curiosity to initiate a national debate on where we are going and how we are getting there.
—Even though it has the benefit of your knowledge?

—Yes, but we are on the wrong side of the House. Parliament has retreated into an embarrassed silence on the social impact of technological change, indistinguishable from a catatonic trance, but the media has never noticed or taken the matter up. I have referred several times lately to biotechnology which seems likely to be the area of greatest economic potential in the 1980s. Australia could make a major contribution in this area. Nevertheless, the subject has been almost totally neglected. Senior Ministers of this Government feel no shame at their total ignorance. I point out, for example, the recent report on the Australian Research Grants Scheme for 1980-81. The Australian Research Grants Committee will no longer exist in its present form. It is to be merged with the Queen Elizabeth II Advisory Committee, although what it advises Queen Elizabeth II on is not really clear. I notice in the provisions for grants approved for 1980-81-the total expenditure provided is $16m-in the areas that might be related to the biotechnology industry, including work on recombinant DNA, the total is $59,395. This is less than $60,000 for an area which will be perhaps the most dramatic area of economic growth in high technology for the 1980s.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to the House the very close relationship between expenditure on education and the quality of research and development. It is a matter of profound concern to the Opposition that Australia has a very poor performance in expenditure in research and development, although the primary culprit is the private sector rather than the government. Government expenditure relatively speaking is far higher than private sector expenditure. Here we have what is described as a private enterprise government and we find that private enterprise is dragging the chain. Very few technologically advanced countries have such a small proportion of total gross domestic product directed from the private sector towards research and development. There are obvious reasons for that.

There is a fundamental contradiction between the expressed goals of the Government and what is actually happening in the area of research and development. I want to set out these two fundamental principles. The first is that in manufacturing and information based industries Australia cannot sell what it does not own. In industrial research and development areas the commanding heights are overwhelmingly not in Australian hands. In trying to get an internationally competitive motor industry in Australia it is necessary to ask whether it is possible to sell what we do not own. To what extent for example, is there Australian ownership in the motor car industry? I strongly urge those honourable members who have not read that very important book by Sir Laurence Hartnett Big Wheels and Little Wheels to do so. He tells the real horror story of the selling out of Australia's own car. There was an intention to produce a car using Australian intellect, capacity and human resources but in fact it was sold out completely.

What do we find in the Australian motor car industry? General Motors has 100 per cent overseas equity, as do Ford, Chrysler, Leyland, Nissen, Volvo and Renault. These are the firms which manufacture or assemble in Australia. Australian Motor Industries Ltd has 50 per cent Australian equity and is the only area where Australia has a share. It would be necessary to ask General Motors or Ford: 'What is the prospect for intensive work in research and development in this country?' They would argue: 'But what is the purpose of doing such research and development here? We are an international corporation. If we can get the research and development done on the Commodore car in Germany, and essentially we are using the German car as a prototype for the Commodore, what would the purpose be and to what end would there be independent Australian research and development?' That is the tragedy of the situation here in Australia.

The second proposition I want to make is that Australia cannot have a dynamic economic expansion in areas dependent on research and development if it has a shrinking educational base. It is not possible to expand and contract at the same time. I draw the attention of the House to the very disturbing figures which appeared in the last Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development economic report on Australia published in 1980. It is possible to extract from the report a table of full time school enrolments of 15 to 19-year-olds. I seek the leave of the House to incorporate the figures in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The table read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. I point out that in the United States 73.7 per cent of 15 to 19 year-olds are in full time enrolment. In Japan the figures is 70.9 per cent and in Switzerland 70.1 per cent. Australia is No. 14 on the list with only a 45 per cent involvement in full time enrolment. I put it to the House that it is quite impossible for Australia to develop the quality of life and level of imagination and invention to be found in other countries unless it develops a higher quality of education.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw the attention of the House to a very important document which has been insufficiently examined in the House. It is the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Science and the Environment entitled 'Industrial Research and Development in Australia' which was published in May 1979. The Committee made this comment on page 227 that:

Sometime during the last ten years, Australian Industry lost its entrepreneurial drive. Throughout the inquiry, witnesses remarked that while Australian managers recognise the value of conducting research and development activities, they are overall, reluctant to take financial risks. They lack what may be termed entrepreneurial spirit. Several witnesses said that they saw management's attitude to research and development as 'timid and parsimonious', generally lacking the confidence and long-range planning necessary for a sustained investment in research and development. One witness went so far as to call this caution 'a national characteristic'. Another witness observed that, while Australian investors had distinct tax advantages over their U.S. counterparts (U.S.: 50% capital gains tax, compared to Australia . . .) they are still reluctant to commit money to ''risky'' enterprises.
The Committee also made this point on page 301:

It is generally accepted that the development phase of any innovation is the most costly, requiring 5 to 10 times initial research costs. From this it follows that there is little economic sense in spending $1 million on a research project unless there is a reasonable hope of obtaining a further $10 million to carry the project through development to commercial fruition. It is at this point that application of our native Australian inventive genius fails. The relative figures for 1976-77 of 44 per cent GERD to applied research compared with 25 per cent for experimental development reflect this dismal fact.

I point to the fact that notwithstanding the television programs The Inventors and What Will They Think of Next Australia has in world terms a comparatively small number of patents granted. There are two standard tests: One is the number of patents granted per million population each year and the second is the number of patents granted per thousand million dollars of GNP. I seek leave of the House to incorporate two tables extracted from the Senate report on industrial research and development in Australia.
Leave granted.
The tables read as follows-

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. Switzerland, which heads the table for the number of patents granted worldwide per $1,000m of GNP, has 1,030 patents per $1,000m whereas Australia has 60 patents. Switzerland has 2,486 patents worldwide per million population whereas Australia has 132 patents.
—Even Liechtenstein would have more than us.

—That is so. As I have remarked before, I think it is in part as a consequence of our consciousness of our minority status in the English speaking world. To some extent Australia has the advantage of being in a very large and very rich economic community but we accept much too readily a kind of junior status in the sense that we believe that when there are major developments in key industries Australia can buy them off the shelf. That is certainly the view taken by many Australian managers. That is a great tragedy.

SPEECH.PARA: The final paper I wish to incorporate in Hansard is a very revealing answer given to a parliamentary question in the previous Parliament when the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) asked the Minister for Productivity-a portfolio which is now defunct-the number of patents registered in Australia every year and those granted to overseas patentees. I seek leave to incorporate that question in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PARLIAMENTARY QUESTION No. 6289
Mr Hayden asked the Minister for Productivity, upon notice, on 20 August 1980:
(1) What is the number of patents (a) registered in Australia and (b) registered in Australia which are granted to overseas patentees, in each year since 1969-70.
(2) What were the total Australian (a) payments and (b) receipts, for royalties and copyrights for the same period.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr Newman

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

INTERJECT.PARA: (1) Total patents granted in Australia and Australian patents granted to overseas patentees are as tabled hereunder:

(2) The Department of Productivity does not maintain figures of Austalian payments and/or receipts for royalties or copyrights. Copyright is administered by the Attorney-General's Department. However, I draw the honourable member's attention to the Australian Bureau of Statistics publication 'Research and Experimental Development-Private Enterprises-1976-77', which provides the following information for that year: (a) total payments made for patent royalties were $37.363m; (b) total receipts for patent royalties were $4.599m.

The Department of Science publication 'Project Score' gives for 1973-74 the figure of $76.98m as the purchase of rights to technical know-how (e.g. patents licences and royalties) by the business enterprise sector. No figures were given for receipts.
For the year 1976-77, the figure given for all sectors is $67.3m for the purchase of technical know-how and $10.9m as receipts from the sale of technical know-how.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the House. In 1978 total patents granted numbered 9,038, of which 8,337 were granted to overseas owners. In 1979, 6,479 patents were granted, of which 6,012 were granted to overseas owners. Australians are in a very dependent position. In terms of technology transfer we are essentially part of the Third World. That is a national scandal. Some 94 per cent of Australia's payments in 'know-how', that is to say payments on royalties, goes overseas. For all practical purposes we are a technological colony of the United States and Japan. On the basis of what happened with the 'Razor Gang' I think the Fraser Government includes economic Quislings who have sold out our technological sovereignty or who, even worse, are indifferent to the question of our technological sovereignty.

SPEECH.PARA: As I mentioned earlier, I am concerned about the contraction of Australia's educational base. The report of the Williams Committee of Inquiry into Education, Training and Employment, which was discussed for a bare 40 minutes in this House in 1980 suggested the extent of the contraction of Australia's educational base. It found that in New South Wales, the State of the honourable member for Berowra (Dr Edwards), 17 per cent of school leavers were not able to read or could read only 'at a level below satisfactory comprehension of simple passages', and a further 32 per cent read 'at levels of comprehension below the levels required for a fully literate adult life'. This revelation by the Fraser Government's own committee has been received with massive indifference. I ask the Minister how Australia can expect to compete with nations that are ahead of us not just in the number of patents they have but also in the development of technology which we do not have the educational base to develop. I move:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House-
(1) expresses its concern at- (a) the low level of Government investment in research and development compared to other technologically advanced nations;
(b) the failure of the Government to encourage significant private sector investment in research and development;
(c) the low level of Australian innovation as measured by the number of patents taken out each year by Australian individuals and companies;
(d) the failure of the Government to stimulate Australian innovation in electronics, biotechnology and other high technology industries, and
(e) Australia's disadvantageous position in relation to technology transfer;

(2) condemns the Government for losing national control over significant industries based on high levels of research and development, including motor manufacturing, electronics, the computer industry and petrochemicals, and

(3) rejects those parts of the report of the Review of Commonwealth Functions (the 'Lynch Committee') which eliminate or downgrade Commonwealth instrumentalities concerned with the collection, dissemination and application of information about high technology in industry, thereby reducing Australia's fight back capacity in high technology areas'.

Of course, the Lynch Committee is genially known, even by itself, as the 'Razor Gang'. Before I conclude there are two points that I want to make. I want to commend the Minister for the fact that the grants approved by the Australian Research Grants Scheme are not narrowly technical. I applaud the fact that they are broad and cover areas in the humanities. A point I have made very often is that we should reject the often expressed concern in the business world that too many students are undertaking 'soft' subjects such as literature, philosophy and physical science rather than 'hard' subjects such as mathematics, physics and chemistry. I think this expresses the naive view that exact sciences are rigorous and studies based on value systems are not. No doubt the humanities are taught in an insufficiently rigorous way in Australia, and teacher training has much to answer for, but Australia's future will depend as much on its politicians, writers, artists and humanities teachers as on its engineers and chemists. Our primary emphasis in education must still be on the general rather than the specific and vocational.

It is no coincidence that Sweden and Switzerland, the most scientifically innovated of all nations per capita, had the highest literacy rates in Europe 200 years ago. Their excellence springs from the general standard of their education and culture. If their educational goals had been set only to meet technological objectives, they would have failed. Their particular skills are a consequence of rigorous levels of general education. I think the significant role played by the Scots in British economic history is also based on Scotland's high level of literacy.

The last thing I want to mention is that one of the difficulties that every nation faces is the problem of whether it spreads its expenditure in reasearch and development or whether it concentrates it in a particular narrow field. Whilst obviously it would be attractive to try to pick the winners and to try to get into key industries, it is extraordinary difficult to know in advance how things will develop. If we were to try to estimate what would happen in 20 years time, there is a fair likelihood that we would be wrong. Interest has been generated lately in the area of biotechnology. In February this year I had a long discussion at the Salk Institution at La Jolla near San Diego with Professor Francis Crick, who is universally conceded to have been the most important figure in the discovery of the principle of recombinant DNA which, has led to the implications of the biotechnological industry. Francis Crick made the point that he with James Watson and Muarice Wilkins, made their epic discovery, one the the greatest scientific discoveries in the last 200 years in 1953.

They shared the Nobel Prize for Physiology and Medicine in 1962, nine years later. But he said it was not until 1966 that it dawned on them the recombinant DNA had any kind of economic potential at all, and it was not for another 10 years after that-in 1976-that the matter was actively pursued. By 1981, although as yet there is no large scale production of biotechnology on the market, it is generally conceded by scientists and economists to be potentially the area of greatest economic growth for the decade. Yet, as I have said, the father of the whole enterprise, Francis Crick, was not aware of the situation and it was 13 years after the great discovery that he first understood that it might have considerable economic significance.

There are a number of other points that we can take up at the Committee stage. However, the Opposition applauds the fact that there is increased expenditure on research and development and the fact that there is some breadth in this area, it is not being couched in unduly narrow terms. We also think the Minister has been placed in an appalling situation by the activities of the 'Razor Gang'. We believe in government intervention, not wholesale intervention and not where it is not required. However, we endorse entirely the Minister's words, in his second reading speech, that there are a number of areas where the market does not provide adequately. Because research and development is carried out abundantly in other countries, there has been an extraordinary reluctance to spend money on it here, particularly in the private sector. The private sector carries the great burden of responsibility in this country.

My colleague the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) will be talking about the educational implications of cutbacks in research and development. One cannot just look at this Bill in isolation; one has to look also at what has happened in the universities with the cutbacks they have suffered, because that is where so many of the long term implications of research and development have their genesis.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is there a seconder to the motion?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Edwards Dr H.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just listened to a rather loud, very interesting but, in my judgment, biased and, to a significant extent, irrelevant speech by the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). It is impossible for me to deal with the speech point by point but I will make reference to some of the points he made. The honourable member constantly came back to the so-called razor gang, the Review of Commonwealth Functions. Amongst other things, he referred to the number of bodies in the Department of Science and Technology that are to be amalgamated. We on this side of the House make no apology for the review of Commonwealth Functions which has been undertaken and stress that there is not a single change affecting any of the Government's programs on pensions and other income security support measures. The thrust of that exercise has been to prune back the Public Service and to cut out unnecessary duplication with the States and private enterprise.

SPEECH.PARA: One other major thrust was to come to grips with some complex problems in the very field that attracted a lot of discussion by the honourable member- the field of higher education, with particular reference to colleges of advanced education which are involved with teacher training. The thrust of the Government's policy is to encourage them to amalgamate and to change emphasis precisely in the direction of technology and business studies. This is the type of change that the honourable member was talking about.

The honourable member had much to say about technology transfer. I suggest that the colonial mentality-he made several references to it-which he accused Australian business of having, and by implication this Government, exists very largely in his own mind. Of course, I am prepared to concede that Australia industry is dependent to a very significant extent of imported technology, but it is natural that a great deal of technology suitable for Australian conditions will come from countries with far larger and more sophisticated industrial bases than we have. Naturally, that is reflected in terms of the proportion of patents, to which the honourable member referred, which have overseas origin. What is important is that Australian companies should have a research and development capability to originate new technology and also to be in a position to adapt technology to suit local conditions and thereby benefit this country.

The honourable member made references to the situation which exists in Switzerland. I think it ought to be noted that in Switzerland 10 large multinational companies which have headquarters there, for a variety of reasons which are not applicable to Australia, account for 60 per cent of the industrial research and development carried out in that country. If one looks at the figures for gross expenditure on research and development as a result of GDP in, say, Sweden, Switzerland and Australia, one will see that in Sweden it is 1.8 per cent; in Switzerland it is 2.3 per cent and in Australia it is 0.9 per cent. I recognise that that is a comparatively low figure. However, if one makes some allowance for the fact that 60 per cent of Switzerland's expenditure is accounted for by those 10 large companies, one sees that the situation there is much more comparable to the Australian position. I make this point in passing because it is necessary to say something about the range of matters which the honourable member mentioned not directly related to the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Amendment Bill but I now wish to go back to focus the attention of the House on the Bill.

Notwithstanding a grudging approbation that came through at the beginning of the honourable member's speech and in the quieter moments at the end, the Bill does represent a substantial upgrading and enlargement of this whole program of industrial research and development incentive grants. The program is a very important component of the Government's overall industry policy. The Bill is necessary basically because the existing program expires on 30 June of this year. The purpose of the Bill, among other things, is to put in place a new five-year program to operate from that date. As an indication of the importance that the Government attaches to this measure, I point out that as recently as 1977-78 the amount of funding for it was some $14m and in this current 1980-81 financial year the amount is $54m. That is a four-fold increase within those three years. This has occured despite all the pressures placed upon the Government to contain overall expenditure-to which it is committed. I believe that is the best indication of the Government's commitment to this program. It is designed particularly to help the small and medium sized firms.

It is necessary to point out, in order to have the facts on the record, that the main focus of this program is in the area of 'project grants'. Project grants are paid to firms which have established research and development facilities in order to enable them to undertake significant projects of industrial research and development. The grants are prospective. An agreement is entered into between the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board and the company on a prospective basis. The ceiling for such grants has hitherto been limited to $500,000 a year in any particular case. It is a measure of the Government's commitment in this area that despite its firm resolve to reduce government spending overall and the results of the activities of the so-called razor gang, to give effect to the Governments commitment to foster development based on technological advance the Bill provides for the annual ceiling to increase from $500,000 to $750,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —But it is taxable.

—It is taxable, that is correct. The program also provides for what are called 'commencement grants' as well as projects of industrial research of a public interest character. These commencement grants are designed to encourage firms, particularly small to medium sized firms, whose research and development activities are only at an infant stage. Firms are encouraged to incur research and development expenditure on the basis that a predictable incentive payment in the form of a commencement grant can subsequently be sought to reimburse the firm for that spending, to the extent of 50 per cent of the amount incurred up to a maximum of $25,000 per annum. That is the maximum limit which applies to commencement grants on an annual basis at the moment. Now, under this Bill, that limit of $25,000 will be increased to $40,000. Again, that is indicative of the Government's determination in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of other provisions in the Bill. It provides for improved administrative arrangements by restructuring the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board to ensure that there is a more effective and faster decision-making process. Again, the scope of grants is extended beyond the mining and manufacturing spheres, to which hitherto they have been largely confined, to include industrial research and development related to some on-site activities in the building and construction industry. The Bill also provides that project grants may be payable for computer software research and development related directly to new products or to processes employed in manufacturing, mining and on-site building activities. The Government's intention is to encourage the application of new or innovative software techniques which are in line with the overall aims of the scheme. Those are the principal provisions of the Bill and they indicate the Government's firm intentions in this area.

To inject a personal note, I put forward the suggestion that from recent experience in my electorate it has become apparent to me that particularly in the case of the smaller firms, which may nevertheless have a pretty good idea, have made a significant invention, requiring research and development, one of the difficulties that occurs throughout the process of bringing a project to fruition is the cost involved in patenting the idea, especially the very high cost of taking out overseas patents. Overseas patenting can cost in the order of $20,000 to $30,000. That can represent a very significant cost for a smaller firm. Some people might argue that a patent is not part of this process, that a patent so to speak crowns a research and development project. In practice, the two go hand in hand. Of course, the possibility of achieving such a patent and reaping the benefits so conferred keeps the shoulder to the wheel, so to speak. I make the following suggestion to the Minister: It might be possible that a discretion in this matter can be introduced into the Act. If such a project goes on to become a significant commercial success, the component to cover the patent costs-perhaps even other components of these grants-could be repayable since in a sense the grant has made possible the project's commercial success.

Be that as it may I want to stress that this measure is a key component of the Government's overall industrial development policy. It is this Government's policy to foster a manufacturing industry in Australia which is more specialised that at present, larger scale, more technology advanced, more export orientated, energy intensive and resource based. Of course, the most significant thing that the Government has done in its pursuit of that overall objective is to establish-I should say re-establish having regard to the upsurge in inflation and costs during 1973-75-Australia's international competitive position. This the Government has done via its anti-inflation and exchange rate policies. By those policies Australian industry is enabled to compete more effectively against imports and to make sales overseas. Indeed in recent years manufactured exports have expanded very significantly. They increased by the order of 30 per cent in 1979-80 and that rate of improvement continued through to the end of 1980, which is the latest available figure. It is basic that we get the fundamentals right in regard to the international competitiveness of the Australian economy.

Along with that basic thrust of overall economic policy is a complex of measures which comprise the 'positives' of the Government's industrial development policy. I refer to the investment allowance, higher depreciation rates for plant and equipment and export incentives which, after having got things moving in the way I have suggested, are to be curtailed somewhat, as announced last Thursday. And to come back to the Bill, there are these industrial research and development incentives. These and other positive measures are the carrots, so to speak, of industrial policy. They go along with the gradual movement towards a lower and less complicated structure of tariff and subsidy protection. I emphasise the word 'gradual'. There is no 25 per cent across-the-board tariff cuts such as those which we witnessed in 1973 under the previous Administration. There is a gradual movement toward lower and less complicated tariff structure. In that connection I believe it is worth stressing that the average nominal rate of protection afforded to Australian industry has fallen by about 40 per cent over the last decade.

So while the basic task of the Government is to set the stage to get these fundamentals right and thus release the dynamics of the unplannable forces for production and development in the economy, these specific elements of industry policy to which I have referred are also important. This measure is putting in place for the next five years the program of industrial research and development incentives the rationale of which is as the honourable member for Lalor said, that the national returns, in terms of greater innovation and greater home-grown technological development, exceed the private returns. It has to be agreed that there is insufficient industrial research and development in this country. The fundamental purpose of these industrial research and development in this country. The fundamental purpose of these industrial research and development grants is to contribute in a very significant way to correcting that underinvestment. Technological innovation and the development of new and improved products are basic to industry efficiency, competitiveness, thrust and growth. A technologically advanced manufacturing industry with a capacity for innovation can contribute importantly to providing Australia's well-educated and growing work force with the opportunity fully to utilise its skills and talents. Accordingly, I commend this Bill which, as I said at the outset, very substantially upgrades and enlarges the program of industrial research and development incentives. I reject the amendment moved by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jacobi Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support with pleasure the amendment moved by the Opposition to the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Amendment Bill. This Government's attitude on research and development technology incentives, in particular the transfer of technology, is surely highlighted in this measure. It highlights this Government's lack of vision, lack of courage and lack of purpose. At a time when mineral resource exploitation is expanding a number of critically important questions have to be answered. The most important concerns the level and control of technology in mineral extraction and processing. It is this question which will determine the Government's capacity to provide the maximum employment opportunities and the generation of the highest levels of income from the exploitation of our resources. For the last 30 years the approach of Liberal Country Party governments has been to leave such matters to market forces. An interesting article in the Institute, dealing with the United States National Science Foundation report to the White House, states:

SPEECH.PARA: While market forces may ultimately relieve current and future shortages . . . we believe that the innovative capacity of American industry will be severely hampered in the interim.

Since the US can't afford to wait for the 'slow workings of the marketplace,' . . . the NSF, along with the Departments of Defense Energy, Education, and other agencies anticipating personnel shortages, can encourage qualified undergraduates to transfer into the field of the projected shortage, co-operate with industry to offer post-graduate industrial traineeships in fields with projected shortages of people with advanced degrees, and study how to better project personnel needs.
How does one test the needs in this country at the present time? A Senate committee report on research and development in Australia states:

Between 1973-74 and 1976-77, gross expenditure on research and development in Australia as a percentage of the Gross Domestic Product fell from 1.29 per cent of GDP to 0.97 per cent of GDP a reduction of 25 per cent.

The Government sector increased in importance as a source of funds, providing 77 per cent of the total in 1976-77 compared to 63 per cent in 1973-74. The Business Enterprise sector's contribution dropped dramatically, from providing 35 per cent of the total expenditure in 1973-74 to only 19 per cent in 1976-77.
Manpower employed in R & D-
Research and development-
by private enterprise fell by 40 per cent in 1976-77 compared to 1973-74.

I wish to return now to the theme that I want to advance today-the question of transfer technology and what happened in previous years. This policy vaccuum resulted in three basic deficiencies in the introduction and control of mineral extraction and processing technology. Firstly, over the last 30 years there has been very little development of technology in these areas in Australia. A minimum of downstream processing of minerals has taken place, giving justification to the description that this country is nothing more than a vast quarry. The recent report of the Australian Trade Development Council on mineral processing summed up the problem as follows:
