In comparison with other countries, Australia's industrial research and development performance rates very poorly in terms of both incentives provided by the Government and assistance to industry for research and development.

The second major deficiency resulting from this Government's abdication of responsibility has been a decline in our technical prowess, a shortage of skilled labour and a lack of technical support services to the mining industry. Professor Endersbee, President of the Institution of Engineers put his finger on the problem when he stated:

All these various projects will proceed at the latest level of modern technology, simply because that is the state of the art and the reflection of costs. But this also means that if Australian engineers, industries and workers are to participate in these projects we must have engineers and firms and skilled workers capable of operating at these top levels of modern technology. Do we have this national competence?

I believe we are losing ground. As an extreme example, we can see a warning in the situation that prevailed in the Middle East, where the international oil companies exploited the oil resources in that area for some time without regard for the people of the region, simply because of their limited technological capacility. I believe we are in danger of a similar loss of opportunities, simply because we are not sustaining and improving our national technological competence.

The Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) gets up in this place and talks about government policy. The Government closed two engineering colleges in Victoria. How can we expect this area to survive? Thirdly, the absence of government policy has resulted in little effective transfer of technology from foreign corporations to this nation's control. As a consequence, foreign corporations have retained the development of new and improved technology within their corporate empires outside Australia and Australian hands. One has to look only at the motor vehicle industry, as my colleague the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) said, to see what this means. The highly skilled design side of motor vehicle production which once existed in this country no longer exists. It did not suit the plans of General Motors-Holden's Ltd or other trans-national producers to retain these high technology areas within Australia. What are we left with? All we are left with is becoming a place for assembly of motor cars-nothing more, nothing less. The fact that this Government and State governments accept virtually without question the package deal foreign investment proposals offered by foreign investors is a national scandal.

In a study of a number of major projects involving foreign ownership during the 1960s Professor McKern found that foreign equity participation was welcomed purely and simply because of the proven ability of trans-national corporations to execute agreed programs and find secure foreign markets. Huge bodies of ore were committed virtually in perpetuity and the question of technology transfer was ignored by governments while problems such as foreign control of key domestic resources, environmental damage, resource depletion and the opportunity cost of alternatives foreclosed went over the head or between the ears of all governments. McKern found that even the officers of transnational corporations taking part in negotiations on foreign investment were surprised at the lack of concern shown by Australian governments and corporations about such matters. Among the reluctant bridesmaids to foreign investment Australia has been a willing harlot.

It is not difficult to find reasons why foreign corporations are anxious to impose package deals on this country. Under the proposals offered by corporations technology is held secure under the control of the corporation and is not disseminated further. The threat of future competition against the corporation is obviously overcome. Local processing and exports are limited to suit the foreign corporation's plants in other countries. Further, favourable transfer pricing between plants and nations to minimise local tax and royalty payments is available to the vertically integrated corporations. It has taken us a long time to get around to putting some order into section 136 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

The folly of ignoring questions of technology transfer is illustrated, as I have said before, in Australia's history in the aluminium industry and we ought to learn from it. When proposals to produce aluminium in Australia were first made after the First World War they had to be shelved because of the ease with which international aluminium cartels could destroy the new local industry. Even when the Second World War, and a world-wide shortage of aluminium, forced Commonwealth Government involvement in aluminium production, the design and construction of a plant were delayed by the refusal of Alcoa to provide any expertise at all. It was left to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation in co-operation with the British Government to develop the Australian designed Bayer-Hall process. An Australian Aluminium Commission was formed in 1944 and an extensive survey was carried out in that year.

We now have the same technology-the Bayer process-being the subject of three separate international transfers in three different direct foreign investment packages. That is, we paid for the technology three times over. Yet the same technology had been worked up and operated at full scale by the Australian Government before any of the transfers were made. Not only that, but it is clear that the technological base in each case now lies outside this country so that significant process development no longer occurs in this country. None of these three companies operating alumina refineries in Australia is either capable of transferring or is empowered to transfer that technology to another country, least of all Australia. It is possible, therefore, to argue that massive international transfers of technology which have occurred have effectively deprived Australia of that very technology.

The same sorry story could be told about mineral sands. Wartime development could have provided the basis of an industry producing titanium dioxide pigment. But after the war this development again was by-passed when foreign corporations brought the same technology into this country at a higher price. I suggest to the Minister-we cannot divorce this from the matter before the chamber-that under the foreign investment packages involved any further transfers of technology to other countries could be made only by a multinational parent. The option of a viable Australian industry leading world trade in this commodity was foreclosed. It was shut off. The tragedy of these foreign investment sellouts will soon be added to which the expansion of the aluminium industry to take advantage of our cheap energy resources. Because this industry comprises a handful of vertically integrated foreign corporations the returns to Australians from their fortunate position as members of an energy and resource rich country will be far below what it ought to be.

I suppose one could go on to develop the whole history of the Esso Australia Ltd involvement in the Rundle oil shale deposit. It clearly highlights the dangers of neglecting the technology transfer aspect of foreign investment. To my mind this was the critical issue of the Rundle shale oil deposit. The Government has in effect permitted what is the world's largest oil corporation to gain a stranglehold over Australia's most promising oil shale reserves. It is hardly surprising that the bullish propaganda of Esso at the time it moved into the Rundle shale should have dissipated into pessimism once its supremacy over the deposit was assured. That is not unusual; the company has done that for the last 30 years. The fact is that Esso and the world's other major countries are flush with profits from the huge escalation in oil prices. They are using their enormous cash flows to take control over mining companies and increase their holdings of key energy reserves throughout the world. We have no legislation at all in this country to block that; that is, we have anti-monopoly legislation. There is such legislation in England currently but none in Australia.

No guarantee whatsoever was given by Esso, and none was asked for by the Government, that the company was serious about proceeding to ultimate development before it was allowed to secure control of the resource. It was not even thought of. It was not even asked for. The use of technology by Esso as a weapon to bludgeon this Government into submission began when the feasibility study for Rundle was undertaken. Esso's costing of the Rundle project was significantly in excess of that undertaken by international consultants acting for the original Australian partners in the project. The Australian partners also claimed that Esso's estimates appeared to involve a lot of plant additives which were believed to be unnecessary and expensive. The point is that the Australian Government is not in a position to judge these allegations but Esso is using the fact that it put up $30m for the feasibility study to gain control over further oil shale leases adjacent to Rundle. Esso's aim is to slow down the development of shale oil while the price of oil internationally remains static. Meanwhile, it manoeuvres to gain control over as much of the world's shale oil deposits as possible. This went on in the United States Colorado Basin 30 years ago. It has been repeated in this country.

Z While technology transfers are firmly in Esso's grasp it has total control over how and when Rundle will be developed. Australia's national interest is now irrelevant to any decision on oil shale in this country, as the Government has learned to its great embarrassment. This Government is an amateur in a professional league. If we are to control our resource exploitation, we must have effective control, as the Norwegians, the British, the Venezuelans and the Mexicans have found, over the technology used in that exploitation. We must be prepared to put greater effort into the development of our own technologies and mineral processing methods. I think the greatest travesty of this Government since it assumed office in 1975 is that it has not spent sufficient money on the Bureau of Mineral Resources. If it had spent a few more million dollars on improving its capability Australia may have been richer to the tune of billions of dollars.

Another aspect of mineral research and development should be faced by the Government. With the rapid escalation in the depletion of the level of our natural resources, the reality which must be faced is that we will progressively be forced to derive many minerals from non-conventional sources, from very low grade deposits or, in the case of oil, from secondary or tertiary recovery levels. If our consumption remains constant we will reach this position with some minerals in the next ten years. No better example of this can be found in this country at the moment than the domestic oil situation. New technology required to exploit unorthodox sources will not be cheap. It will be extremely expensive. The need for research is urgent because the lead time in developing any new techniques in this area varies from 10 to 20 years. The necessary research and development could be funded by a levy on resource exploitation. The Treasury supports this proposal but this Government, because of the extensive mining lobby, refuses to implement it.

Unless funds are allocated for research and development we, along with most of the West, will face a severe shortage of materials. Those that are available will be available at steeply escalated prices. Areas where such research funds are vital are the exploration and exploitation of the sea bed, deep buried mineral deposits, methods to process low grade and conventional ores, reducing the energy requirement of current processes and the use of alternative materials. I suggest to the Minister that if your Government's policy continues in the next decade you will do nothing for this country in relation to technology self-sufficiency. You have put all your eggs--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I suggest that the honourable member address his remarks through the Chair. I would be very pleased if he got on with the Bill.

—The Bill deals with technology. Research and development are technology. That is what I am dealing with. In conclusion, let me say that if we fluff the chance that our fortuitous endowment of natural resources has provided, we will have only ourselves to blame. The Government will bear the burden of that. If we continue to leave it to others to provide the skills and knowhow for the development of our resources we must inevitably expect that the benefit of these resources will also be taken from us. It is with pleasure that I support the amendment.

—I must apologise to the honourable member for Hawker. I have been reminded that the amendment moved by the honourable member for Lalor broadens the scope of the Bill considerably. I hope the honourable member will accept my apology.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Dawkins Mr J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to contribute briefly to this debate to support the remarks of my colleagues, the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) and the honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi). I refer particularly to that part of the amendment which suggests that this House express its concern at the low level of government investment in research and development compared to technologically advanced countries. I refer specifically to the lack of support for basic research in universities. That is where most of the basic research is undertaken in this country. I emphasise the importance of supporting basic research as a vital prerequisite to the sort of applied research and development which this Bill seeks to encourage.

SPEECH.PARA: Since 1966 the Commonwealth has had a program of supporting basic research under the Australian Research Grants Scheme which is administered by the Australian Research Grants Committee. However, the amount of funding which has been made available through that scheme has deteriorated markedly. For instance, the amount made available in 1980-81, which was $16m, was less in real terms than the amount made available when the scheme was introduced in 1966. If we were to restore the amount to an equivalent amount in real terms to that which was made available in 1966 the next Budget would have to appropriate $22m as opposed to the $16m which was appropriated last year for this purpose. One of the organisations which has taken up this point is the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations, otherwise known as FAUSA. It is concerned that a number of its members who have viable and exciting projects which would otherwise be supported are not being supported due to the lack of funds made available to the ARGC for allocation mainly to the universities.

It is important to make the point that basic research has two parts, pure and strategic research. The Australian Science and Technology Council has estimated that of the research supported under the programs administered by the ARGC, 30 per cent are in the category of pure research and 70 per cent are in the category of strategic research. It is to some people difficult to justify in economic terms the importance of pure research. At the same time, it is terribly important to emphasise that it is fundamental that we support pure research as well as strategic and, of course, later applied research before we can have the important breakthroughs and discoveries which will make a real contribution to the economy of this country.

I emphasise to the Government and the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) that if they want sensible and effective research programs under their administration they must not ignore the very important role of the kind of pure research which is conducted in universities. They rely on the ARGC for support for basic research. That Committee is the single most important source of funds for basic research in Australia. I think it is an absolute tragedy that a decreasing contribution as a proportion of total federal outlays has been made to this very important area. Over the last 15 years it has fallen by almost 50 per cent. In its reports for 1980 and 1981 the ARGC has pointed to the effect of this decline. In 1980 the Committee stated:
The Committee . . . sees an urgent need to increase the real level of funds available to the ARGS. This urgency arises for two reasons
(a) The reduction in the average grant in real terms means that the Committee is unable to recommend sufficient support to enable the best investigators to achieve their research potential.
(b) The fact that an increasing number of investigators whom the Committee has assessed as proposers of good quality projects (112 in 1980), are being cut out completely from ARGS funds.
In 1981 the Committee indicated that the position was even worse. It stated:

The extent of the withdrawal of support for worthwhile projects can be gauged from the increased number of proposals judged by the Committee's external assessors to be of good quality which could not be supported. In 1980 there were 112 such cases; in 1981 this figure has risen to 296.

It is very alarming that the ARGC, which is highly respected throughout the academic community, having made its assessment of projects which are put up primarily by individuals and sometimes by teams for short term support, has been unable to support 296 proposals which it thought were worthy of support. I say again to the Minister: If the Government is going to miss out on the work of 296 legitimate investigations and research projects I cannot see how it can reap the true rewards from the sorts of proposals he is putting forward today in this legislation.

There is one other matter in this regard that I should refer to, and that is this: Before the election the Government indicated that it was going to provide special assistance for what I think it rather impertinently called centres of excellence. I prefer to call them centres of concentration because there is no way in which it can be said that one group of research workers is excellent because that implies that all the others working in that area are somewhat deficient. I do not think those sorts of assessments can be made and I certainly do not think this Government is in a position to make them. But I think it is legitimate to provide extra and special assistance to centres of concentration where teams working on more complicated and long term research projects can be supported over a longer period. The alarm which exists in the academic community-I think it is a legitimate alarm-is that the funds available for centres of concentration may come out of the funds which would ordinarily have been made available in other ways.

I think it is fundamentally important that there should be no diminution-in fact there should be an increase-in the amount of funds available to the ARGC at the same time as the centres of concentration, are being supported under this new proposal. If the Minister were able to say that that was the case and that the centres of concentration would not compete for funds with the ARGC, I think he would find his proposal welcomed with much greater enthusiasm in the universities around this country. I emphasise again that it is important to continue the sort of funding which the ARGC has been involved with because we cannot predict where important discoveries will be made. It may be that some groups, in particular universities, have made important contributions, but we cannot say that nobody else will make just as important or even more important contributions in other universities. Therefore, I think there is very important justification for continuing to support investigators and researchers on a project basis and on an individual basis and to encourage them to pursue their interests on the short term basis, which is what the ARGC is particularly concerned with.

I mention another matter which relates to this aspect. It is not simply a question of providing funds for researchers to continue their current work. The other important thing-my colleague the honourable member for Lalor has referred to this matter as well-is to ensure that we continue to have enough people who will be involved in research work. We must ensure that increasing numbers of people are going into universities and staying there to participate in this important research work.

The awful truth is that we have appalling levels of participation in tertiary education and in higher secondary education compared with those of some other countries. This situation is deteriorating. If we look at the Tertiary Education Commission report and at what has been happening in the last three years, there has been a phenomenal decline in the number of school leavers who have gone straight into tertiary institutions. Whereas three years ago 54 per cent of school leavers went straight on to some form of full time tertiary education, the number has now fallen to 42 per cent, at a time when we should be encouraging more and more people to be involved in full time higher education. Yet we have seen this decline. One of the reasons for this decline, which the TEC points to, is the lack of adequate student financial arrangements.

I do not want to get on to that aspect, except to say that the Government is now making a deliberate and specific assault on the major research body-that is, universities-around this country. The Government intends to apply fees to those people involved in post-graduate study in universities. The fact is that the major contribution to research work in universities in a manpower sense is in fact conducted by post-graduate students. There are about 20,000 full time and part time post-graduate students around Australia. We do not really know to what extent those students or new students will be discouraged from post-graduate studies as a result of these fees. It is clear however that many people will be prevented from carrying on this work, not because they are not good enough but because they cannot afford to, simply due to the fact that the Government is applying a quite inequitable and quite unjustifiable fee on the people who are primarily involved in basic research work in universities around Australia.

I want the Minister to realise that at least his colleague the Minister for Education (Mr Fife) seems to have partially realised the lunacy of this proposal because in a Press statement that he released on Sunday we see the first evidence of backsliding in relation to the Razor Gang's report. In relation to tertiary tuition fees, the report of the Razor Gang reads:

Tuition fees to be introduced in universities and CAE's for students undertaking degrees and diplomas subsequent to an initial tertiary qualification, except for recognised double degree or diploma combination.
Postgraduate students receiving Commonwealth Government Postgraduate Awards to be exempted from fees.

In the Press statement that he issued on 3 May the Minister for Education said that he had been misrepresented. He said that it was perfectly clear what the Government was doing in relation to tertiary fees. He said, inter alia, when talking about tertiary tuition fees:
Students in receipt of Commonwealth Government or university Postgraduate awards will be exempt.

There was no misrepresentation at all. It was perfectly clear in the beginning what the Government intended, but maybe as a result of some flash of brilliance on the Minister's part, on Saturday, 2 May-that may not be unrelated to the fact that the Minister on that day was at the University of Sydney and was button-holed by the Vice-Chancellor of the University, Professor Williams-the Minister obviously realised that the Government had made a serious mistake and to a very small extent tried to unravel the mess it had created. But that in itself will not be sufficient because both the Commonwealth Government and the university awards are granted primarily on the basis of merit, not on the basis of need. So we are going to have a lot of prospective post-graduate students-perhaps not the best but nevertheless promising-being denied an opportunity not only to further their education but also to participate in university research simply because this Government has decided to penalise them for wanting to continue in that direction.

I conclude by saying that the honourable member for Lalor is right when he says that we cannot look at this proposal in isolation from the basic research work which is being done in the universities. We particularly cannot look at it in isolation from the success or failure of the education system as a whole. I urge the Minister, if he is genuinely interested, and I believe he is-I think he is having an awfully hard time of it at the moment, being beaten around the head by this Government--

TALK.START.PARA: —What has the Government got against him?

—I do not know. Perhaps it is because he is from north Queensland; one never knows. I think the Minister is genuinely interested in this area but he will never succeed if he allows the other Ministers, particularly the Minister for Education, to undermine his efforts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This has been a very wide-ranging debate. The debate is really about the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Amendment Bill. The honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) mentioned the Bill in a very cursory way and then he went on to deal with a great number of other matters. The honourable member for Hawker (Mr Jacobi) and the honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) did not mention the Bill at all. I think you were very patient in allowing them to continue, Mr Deputy Speaker. Of course, their excuse was that an amendment had been moved and that they were talking to the amendment.
—Which I hope you are going to accept.

—Certainly not. The honourable member for Lalor has been yapping in a very loud voice but he has really produced no alternative policies. He has made no suggestions; his whole speech has been a knocking speech; he has produced no details of an alternative policy. Perhaps the Opposition does not have an alternative policy. It did nothing in this field when it was in government. This Government has encouraged industrial research and development. This Government has done a great deal to encourage new technology in Australia. The Opposition did nothing about industrial research and development in the three disastrous years it was in office. This Government is doing a great deal to help and encourage high technology industries in Australia. We have consistently supported industrial research and development.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Berowra (Dr Edwards) said that in the last three years the amount spent to support industrial research and development incentives with which this Bill is concerned has increased from $14m three years ago to $54m today. That is a very considerable increase. This legislation is good legislation. No Opposition members who spoke on this legislation complained about it in any way; they admitted that it is a good Bill. The honourable member for Fremantle (Mr Dawkins) spoke about the money spent on industrial research. The Australian Government has allocated about $180m to the Australian Research Grants Committee, the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council, the Tertiary Education Commission and universities-for marine science research. That is a considerable amount. That amount is much more than has ever been spent in this field in Australia. I think the Government deserves great credit for its realisation of the need to encourage high level research in Australia. Of course, there is an immense amount to be done. There are limited resources and those resources are being used in the best possible way. This is a good Bill. That has been admitted by all Opposition members who have spoken in this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Now tell us about the razor gang.
—The razor gang has nothing to do with this Bill I reject the amendments put forward by the Opposition as good talking points. They have little to do with the Bill. I commend the Bill to the House.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put-
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Barry Jones's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise one point that relates to the definition clause-clause 3-of the Bill. The explanatory memorandum to the Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: The effect of sub-clauses 2 (f) and 2 (g) is that computer software R and D will be eligible where it relates directly to the development of new products of, or new or improved processes employed in manufacturing, mining or on-site building or construction activities. However, where software R and D has been eligible under the commencement grant scheme, that eligibility is retained.

I would like the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) to explain why it is necessary to exclude the broader category of software production. The restrictions involved in sub-clause 3 (1) (f)' which seeks to insert the new definition of eligible software research and development, are far too narrow. At this stage we will not move an amendment but, depending on how the Minister answers the question, we may propose one in the Senate. I put it to the Minister that perhaps in the period between the Bill leaving this place and being introduced in the Senate he might reconsider.

Let me put this argument to him: There seems to be a strong case for a general eligibility for providing industrial research and development incentives grants to software development where appropriate. After all, the Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board will presumably have a discretion. It can pick and choose between applications. We think software should be regared as a significant form of enterprise per se. Software requires intellectual skill, it has considerable market potential and is relatively labour intensive. Great Britain, for example, is not doing particularly well in the computer hardware area, but is successful in the computer software area. Why should there not be a broad capacity to include software where, in the opinion of the Board, it is warranted? If the Board can exercise a discretion as to what it provides grants for, that seems to be perfectly satisfactory. There is very likely to be a considerable development in the volume of software that will be required throughout the 1980s. I point out to the Minister that most packaged software in Australia is imported. This, again, is an area where we are suffering from a considerable technology imbalance. I would suggest to the Minister that he delete from paragraph (f) of sub-clause 3 (1) the words 'software for computers or for similar equipment'. He might also delete paragraph (g) as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems that the honourble member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) does not really understand the purpose of this Bill. The original legislaiton was restricted to research in both manufacturing and mining. We have extended the scope of the legislation to on-site building. We do not wish to expand it beyond that at the moment because the amount of money is limited. We believe they are the three most important sections in which we should be encouraging industrial research and technology. Software which is realted to these three areas is eligible. If we opened up a whole new field which the Bill is not intended to cover we would find that similar amendments would be sought in all other areas. It would open up the Bill to any sort of industrial reasearch and development. We wish to restrict the operation of the Bill to these three major areas.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another point. Most software development is development. It involves a very small amount of research. This is a research and development Bill. The Australian Industrial Research and Develepment Incentives Board, when assessing applications, takes into account both research and development. In most cases software development does not contain a purely research element. Therefore the Government decided that this was not the best area in which to support the software industry. I must say that I agree with the honourable member that the software industry is a very important industry in Australia. I think it employs about 12,000 people at the moment. It is growing very fast. The industry does have problems in getting venture capital. We are looking at that. I propose to have a meeting with representatives of the software industry as soon as it can be arranged to discuss how the industry might be assisted in areas in which it is having real problems.

The Government considered very carefully this question raised by the honourable member. It decided that the Bill was not the most appropriate way in which to assist the software industry if it needs assistance. The industry is doing very well at the moment. However, there are areas in which it is experiencing problems. The Government will try to assist the industry in this respect after consultation with the industry itself.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Mr B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer given by the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) is an extremely disappointing, and perhaps not properly thought-out. First of all I point out that the definition of 'industrial research and development' in the Industrial Research and Development Incentives Act 1976 is broad enough. It states:

SPEECH.PARA: 'Industrial research and development', in relation to a company, means systematic experimentation or analysis in the field of science or technology carried on by the company, or procured by it to be carried out, in Australia with the object of-

(a) acquiring knowledge that may be of use for the purpose of devising or developing new or substantially improved material products or new or substantially improved processes for or in connection with the production or use of material products . . .
Then it states:
(b) applying knowledge for the purpose referred to in paragraph (a) . . .

What we have in this Bill is a narrowing of the principal Act, which was broad enough, by confining software incentives in effect to mining and construction operations. The position seems to be absolutely indefensible. One might say: 'Ah well, it might require too much money and it might be far too broad'. The answer is to say to the Government: 'What is your Board doing?' The Australian Industrial Research and Development Incentives Board, after all, receives applications. If it considers an application and says 'We do not think a grant is merited, we do not think there is enough evidence for it' it can reject the application. We could say to the Board: 'Oh yes, once upon a time under the 1976 Act you would have included a broader variety of software'. Now we are told that although the Government is enlarging the range of industrial research and development broadly, in this area it is cutting down. If software development is needed for construction or mining, it is in. If there is any alternative form it is out. The Government is not even giving the Board the opportunity to express a choice as to whether something ought to be included or not. This seems to me to be absolutely arbitrary.

I suggest to the Minister that instead of coming out with what for him is an uncharacteristically peremptory reply he might give some consideration to this and in the period between now and when the Bill is transmitted to the Senate examine if the present wording is too narrow. He might read the definition of what is meant by eligible software research and development in conjunction with the definition of industrial research and development that is in the parent legislation.

TALK.START.PARA: —(Leichhardt-Minister for Science and Technology) (5.50)-Under the previous Act software could be funded only when it was related to hardware development. This Bill has broadened the area of eligibility. The Bill provides for the extension to certain categories of mining, manufacturing and onsite building operations. That is a considerable widening of the Act. It is not as much as the software industry wants but under the legislation, the industry will now be eligible for grants in those areas-manufacturing, mining and onsite building operations.

—I wish to make the point, in contradistinction to what the Minister for Science and Technology (Mr Thomson) has just said, that software research and development has been eligible under the commencement grant scheme.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The software industry continues to be eligible. Where it was eligible under the commencement grants scheme it will continue to be eligible.

SPEECH.PARA: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr Thomson)-by leave-read a third time.
Debate resumed from 9 April, on motion by Mr MacKellar:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not quite sure of the procedures here but I understand that the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) has an amendment to move to the Quarantine Amendment Bill 1981. The Opposition wishes to move an amendment also. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the maintenance of efficient and comprehensive quarantine arrangements is vital and that any transfer of remaining operational responsibilities to the States would jeopardise this and therefore should be opposed.'

The Opposition moves this amendment because since the Bill was introduced the Government has brought into the House a statement on the review of Commonwealth functions. In referring to quarantine the review stated:

The Government will also explore with State Governments the appropriateness and feasibility of transferring to the States the remaining Commonwealth operational elements of the administration of quarantine. That would leave policy matters in relation to quarantine with the Department of Health for people and the Department of Primary Industry for animals and plants.

I want to refer to two matters in respect of that statement. First of all the Bill says nothing about splitting quarantine arrangements between the Department of Health and between the Department of Primary Industry. The Opposition is very much opposed to transferring further operational aspects of quarantine to the States. People are already well aware of deficiencies pointed to by, for example, the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources in, for instance northern Australia. We believe it is a rather poor show when the review of Commonwealth functions statement directly reflects on a Bill before the House. If the statement is not in fact in opposition to the Bill then certainly it downgrades the importance of it. We all realise that if the review goes ahead the Department of Health will hardly have any functions to perform.

The report on the review of Commonwealth functions of the razor gang indicates that the function of quarantine was not reviewed. The Government in its razor gang report did not look at the best, the most efficient, the most effective or safest quarantine system or service. It simply looked at ways and means of foisting functions on to the States, doing away with some functions or selling off any functions that happen to pay. In very few cases did the razor gang look at the functions themselves. For example, the committee did not look at what was best for soil conservation, what should or should not be done, or whether there should or should not be a national program of soil conservation. It simply looked at ways and means of foisting functions on to the States. It did not look at soil conservation per se just as it did not look at quarantine per se. It did not look at what was best for quarantine. The razor gang's report simply is ideology masked as fiscal responsibility. The razor gang's report is really the ideological outpourings of a frugal and mendacious government. The Minister in his second reading speech said that part of the measure before the House was-
to give effect to outstanding recommendations for legislative change put forward by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources in its report on the adequacy of quarantine.

The Government does that but many other recommendations in the report are not picked up. In the razor gang's report many recommendations are not looked at in terms of the Quarantine Amendment Bill. The Minister also said that the Bill is a reflection of the Government's strong commitment to an efficient quarantine service. As I said earlier, I think that the razor gang's report does not look at what is best for an efficient quarantine service but simply at foisting off quarantine functions. I seek leave of the House to incorporate the recommendations in Hansard because they are good and well thought through recommendations.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
CHAPTER 10
Recommendations
The order of the following recommendations does not indicate any priority or order of importance.
The Committee recommends:
The Quarantine Act

1. that the Quarantine Act be amended as a matter of priority to eliminate the problems in relation to the effect of granting pratique, and lack of powers of Animal or Plant Quarantine officers as detailed on pages 53 and 54;

2. that action be taken to amend either the Quarantine Act or the Aboriginal Lands Act to guarantee the legality of quarantine operations, while fully protecting the rights of the Aboriginal occupants of the land; (page 54)
3. that the Quarantine Act be amended to provide legislative support necessary to handle contemporary quarantine situations which are not currently covered by the Act; (page 55)
4. that a complete redrafting of the Act be undertaken as a matter of priority; (page 58)
Location of Quarantine within the Commonwealth's administrative arrangements

5. that an Australian Agricultural Health Service be established as an independent service within the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry, and include the existing Animal, Plant and General Quarantine Branches of the Department of Health, the Bureau of Animal Health and the proposed Plant Protection Service; (page 65)

6. that the new Agricultural Health Service, the Quarantine Service and the Plant and Animal Health Service be headed by officers with technical qualifications relevant to their responsibilities; (page 66)

7. that more resources be made available to the Plant and Animal Quarantine services generally with the specific objects of increasing public awareness of the purpose and necessity for quarantine, of providing more thorough quarantine surveillance at air and sea ports and enabling the Quarantine Service to carry out tasks which at present are not done adequately; (page 64)
Administrative arrangements relating to quarantine
8. that in future a comprehensive functional breakdown of receipts and expenditure be maintained in respect of quarantine activities; (page 9)

9. that consultative committees be formally incorporated into the operation of the General, Plant and Animal Quarantime Branches so that industry and producer groups have the oportunity of providing regular comments and suggestions to the Department in respect of quarantine policy and operational procedures; (page 11)

10. that the Chief Quarantine Officers' conference be given a formal basis under section 11 of the Quarantine Act and that the provision of consultative machinery to give access to industry groups and organisations be developed; (page 11)
11. that Quarantine Officers be given the same powers of search as Customs officers; (page 12)
12. that a separate quarantine check be incorporated in the existing customs and immigration checks; (page 12)
13. that international representation relating specifically to quarantine should be the responsibility of the Quarantine Service; (page 13)

14. that the Department of Transport provide quarantine facilities at all first port of entry airports and that this requirement be incorporated in the basic design and construction of all future first port of entry airports; (page 14)

15. that technical committees on quarantine be established with neighbouring countries and that establishment of such committees with Indonesia and Papua New Guinea should be a matter of priority. Overseas aid programs should be extended to both involves greater numbers of Australian veterinarians and plant scientists, and to give them practical experience in handling exotic diseases such as foot and mouth disease and to allow representatives from the same disciplines to train in Australia; (page 14)
General quarantine
16. that Quarantine officers be given similar powers of search to Customs Officers and that a separate quarantine check of passengers be instituted at ports of entry; (page 18)

17. that some aspects of the coastal surveillance program be reviewed immediately, particularly in regard to the training of observers, the need for staggered flight times and the provision of the necessary facilities to respond to surveillance sightings; (page 21)
18. that the Quarantine Act 1908 be amended to give the Quarantine Authorities discretionary power to confiscate, destroy or otherwise dispose of abandoned vessels as a quarantine measure; (page 18)
19. the proclamation of Torres Strait as a quarantine area or zone; (page 23)
Plant quarantine
20. that the Quarantine Division improve its supervisory and consultative procedures to ensure that quarantine requirements are applied uniformly throughout Australia; (page 28)

21. that the effectiveness of the present inspection method for cut flowers be tested in a research project which would carry out a thorough search and dissection of a representative sample of flowers from all sources of supply and which should be carried out over a period of one or more years and at different times of the year; (page 28)

22. that the systematic survey and listing of weed species present in Australia be given increased emphasis and that the noxious weed list currently prepared by Plant Quarantine be brought up to date at regular intervals; (page 29)

23. that entomological research with the aim of compiling reference collections of potential endemic and exotic pests should be co-ordinated and monitored by Plant Quarantine or, if established, the proposed Plant Protection Service; (page 30)
24. that a program to determine the extent of these weed and disease organisms be a continuing feature of plant quarantine precautions in Australia; (page 34)
25. that the existing collation of plant research information by Plant Quarantine be continued and that manuals and indexes of pests and diseases be brought up to date regularly; (page 34)
26. that research on the wide range of plant sciences be encouraged and increased in all sectors; (page 34)

27. that public education on plant quarantine emphasise the reasons for Australia's strict plant quarantine laws and that publicity material be distributed to all international travellers and intending migrants travelling to Australia; (page 34)
Animal quarantine
28. that the Queensland and Federal Governments produce a joint plan embracing Customs, Immigration and Quarantine to control movement in the Torres Strait area; (page 37)
29. that the Commonwealth initiate arrangements with the Queensland Government to prepare for all aspects of an outbreak of screw worm fly; (page 37)

30. that Quarantine should select a separate sample of incoming passengers, using a similar sample size to the Bureau of Customs, and carry out searches specifically for breaches of quarantine; (page 38)

31. that the Department of Science and the Environment acting in consultation with the Quarantine Service and industry groups be responsible for producing and maintaining a list of prohibited and permitted fish species for use by the Customs Bureau and the Quarantine Service; (page 39)
32. that a comprehensive procedure for the importation of aquarium fish be developed including:
(i) licensing of overseas exporters to guarantee standards of health and cleanlines of consignments;
(ii) pre-import identification of fish, i.e. all consignments to carry a clear description and illustration of contents; fish to be of a minimum size or age;
(iii) licensing of selected private aquariums which meet required standards as post-entry quarantine facilities, where fish may be examined more thoroughly than is possible at present;
(iv) development of procedures in these facilities to ensure safe disinfection and disposal of water in which fish are transported;
(v) Quarantine authorities to train officers in identification of fish species and recognition of diseases. If necessary officers with the required skills should be employed for this function;
(vi) regular inspection of quarantine facilities to ensure their security and the observance of regulations; (page 39)

33. that the Bureau of Animal Health or, if established, the proposed Australian Agricultural Health Service co-ordinate research into exotic diseases, acting as a central reference point which can bring together results of research already underway and where necessary commission research aimed at producing a comprehensive picture of Australia's disease status; (page 40)
34. that detailed contingency plans be discussed publicly allowing full debate and involvement of those affected by the plans; (page 41)
35. that the Bureau of Animal Health take the initiative in organising exercises to test the efficiency of contingency plans; (page 41)
36. that the Bureau of Animal Health undertake a study of all aspects of compensation policy for exotic disease outbreaks and that the study be made public; (page 42)

37. that the control and eradication of feral animals, particularly pigs, is an area where the Commonwealth should be actively involved both through research undertaken by CSIRO and in providing the impetus and partially funding national eradication campaigns; (page 42)
Quarantine facilities

38. that if maceration/sterilisation proves to be as effective as is expected from the work undertaken to date then no more incerators be constructed and that when existing incinerators are due for replacement macerator/sterilisers be installed; (page 45)
39. that in future enclosed greenhouses be the minimum requirement for licensed plant quarantine premises; (page 45)
40. that the licensing of private premises as post-entry fish quarantine facilities be introduced; (page 47)

41. that further investigation be undertaken into extending the licensing of laboratory facilities as quarantine premises and the relationship and access of research establishments to the high security facilities of the new Australian National Animal Health Laboratory; (page 47)

42. that access to a portion (say 50 per cent) of the Cocos Island Animal Quarantine Station should be offered to recognised Commonwealth and State government animal research establishments, and that an Expert Committee on Import Priorities be established to apportion the facility between those research establishments; (page 48)
43. that access to the remaining portion of the facility be by strict order of application; (page 48)

44. that the completion of the National Animal Health Laboratory project receive high priority and that the Government ensure that there are no further delays in construction due to budgetary or other constraints; (page 50)
A. M. THOMAS Chairman

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister and the House. The Senate Standing Committee which examined the adequacy of quarantine procedures wanted a strong Australian quarantine service. The Government senators on that Committee-Senators Thomas, Maunsell and Teague-unanimously agreed that Australia needs a strong quarantine service. The recommendations for the organisation of this new structure for an Australian quarantine service appears at page 66 and 67 of the report. It is quite obvious from that report that the members of the Committee, after a searching inquiry, do not want more quarantine functions to be foisted on the States. They want to see a strong Australian quarantine service. They propose an Australian quarantine service covering animal, plant and health services under the aegis of an organisation to be known as the Australian Agricultural Health Service within the Department of Primary Industry. In other words, this would mean an upgrading of the present situation. Again it is quite clear that that searching examination by the Senate resulted in a proposal for a strong Australian quarantine service.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Labor Party has no objection to the concept of putting quarantine procedures within the Department of Primary Industry. Administrative arrangements are nowhere near as important as trying to get the best and most efficient quarantine service. We are opposed to the remaining quarantine operational powers to the States, as the Razor Gang recommended. The Senate Committee report quite clearly showed just where the deficiencies were, particularly in northern Australia, where some arrangements involved quarantine inspections by private contractors as a 9 to 5 operation. The Senate Committee reported that some inspectors had been dumped on beaches and left for 24 or 36 hours. There are all sorts of problems with the States in handling some aspects of quarantine. It is downright irresponsible, in the Opposition's opinion, to hand any more facilities and operational aspects of quarantine over to the States.
Sitting suspended from 6 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps I should inform the House what the Quarantine Amendment Bill is all about. The broad purpose of the Bill is to incorporate the Cocos (Keeling) Islands into Australian quarantine arrangements so as to provide a secure off-shore quarantine station, to extend quarantine powers and activities provided for in the Act to remove the liability of the Commonwealth to pay compensation for imported livestock and certain other classes of animals destroyed in accordance with the Act where those animals have been in quarantine since importation. Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner I informed the House that the Opposition has no objection to this Bill. The only reason it has moved a second reading amendment is that it objects to the implications of what is contained in the razor gang's report.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill draws together changes resulting from the decisions to establish an off-shore quarantine station on Cocos (Keeling) Islands, which is expected to be completed in September of this year; the 1979 findings of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources in its report on the adequacy of quarantine; and various other measures which the Government considers necessary to continue Australia's geographic isolation from many of the worst human, plant and animal health risks found in nearby and distant countries. Mass international air travel, Australia's participation in large volume international trade and the unauthorised landings in Australia of refugees and others have contributed to the growing quarantine risks Australia faces. In economic and/or social terms the establishment in Australia of particular diseases such as foot and mouth disease, rabies or oriental fruit fly could be disastrous not only for the individuals immediately concerned but also for the community at large.

In terms of interrupted production and trade, the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) stated in 1980 that an outbreak of foot and mouth disease would result in a loss of $2,500m in rural output in the first year alone. In June 1980 the Government announced a national quarantine publicity campaign intended to inform the one million Australians who travel overseas and the 800,000 visitors who arrive here each year of the need to co-operate with quarantine regulations. That commitment by the Government gave me and the Opposition a clear indication that it regards quarantine as a national responsibility. We congratulate and encourage the Government in that. But this is a time when the country is being scoured by children and parents engaged in the hunt for some 250 gerbils and hamsters, due to the failure of interception procedures by our quarantine service. People are calling for the reactivation of the Army Veterinary Corps to deal with an outbreak of exotic diseases. It is very appropriate that the Parliament should devote time to a critical but constructive discussion about Australia's quarantine procedures.

I wish to devote my remarks to three areas: Firstly, the difficulty of the problem of completely quarantining Australia from the entry of that which is undesirable; secondly, the fact that we have not had more outbreaks of exotic diseases is due more to good luck than to good management, although I would say that on the evidence it is hard to prove that because we have not had much of a problem with such outbreaks; and, thirdly, the question of administrative arrangements and the need for Australia's quarantine service to be located within the Department of Primary Industry. I am leading for the Opposition in the debate because my major concern is in regard to the Bill and its relationship to the primary industries rather than human health.

As an aside to the three main points I will be addressing, I want to make some reference to the debate on whether we should have the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory and whether the quarantine station at the Cocos (Keeling) Islands is really necessary. I hope I understand the technological arguments that put both those facilities under a cloud if looked at scientifically, taking into account the progress likely to be made in the next few years. One of the first speeches I made in this place, as the member for Macarthur, was on the need for a maximum security animal health laboratory. I have been critical of the Fraser Government for its tardiness in not proceeding with the construction of the laboratory as quickly as possible.

In recent outbreaks of vesicular disease in pigs it has been seen that we are still dependent on overseas diagnostic facilities, and the chills that pass down the spine of Australia's livestock industry every time an outbreak occurs would be lessened if we had more experts and facilities on the spot. I believe the ANAHL has a place, and will have a place even given advanced technology. In particular, the production of non-infective synthetic vaccines is the technology that gives people reason to say that we do not need the laboratory. I think we very definitely need the laboratory, particularly to meet the need for diagnosis, research, training, the quality control of vaccines and the need for scientific exchange. There is a range of lesser roles that it could carry out.

I am not so sure about the life or the utility of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands facility but there still seems to be an argument advanced that semen and ova imports can be carriers of a number of viruses. If one looks at the functions of the Bureau of Animal Health it is apparent that the ANAHL will be the focus of activity and the major facility at its disposal. It may be a negative argument, but even if technology does overtake the need for the laboratory in its original form, I believe such a facility will readily be able to be used for other scientific purposes such as research and training.

As I have mentioned the Bureau of Animal Health and the ANAHL, it may not be a bad time to itemise the responsibilities of the Bureau because it will fit very much into Australia's quarantine arrangements and into the whole area of the prevention of exotic diseases coming into Australia. As well as providing the Commonwealth Government's meat inspection services the Bureau of Animal Health provides a professional and technical advisory service on all matters relating to animal and poultry health, reports on the effects of animal health and breeding, undertakes research and investigation into epidemiology, operates a national disease recording system, supervises livestock export health testing, provides technical advice and representation at national and international meetings, provides the secretariat for the Animal Health Committee and the Cattle Tick Control Commission, co-ordinates major national animal disease programs, co-ordinates exotic disease contigency planning, provides advice on standards of export meat inspection and operates veterinary services within the Australian Capital Territory. Itemising the role of the Bureau of Animal Health provides another very strong reason for putting all these matters under discussion into the Department of Primary Industry. The human part of quarantine is no longer as important as it once was.

I return to the three matters to which I said I would mainly address myself. I think the amendments contained in this Bill should be used to tighten considerably quarantine restrictions at major points of entry of people. However, the problem still remains of people entering Australia unchecked-for example, the refugees or boat people, or fishermen landing on isolated stretches of coast for short periods. I am talking about the problems of actually having a 100 per cent quarantine service. It is a massive task to do anything about unchecked entries and it is very much a case of catch as catch can. But I would say that there seems to have been no assessment of the costs versus the benefits of the actions we are taking. There is a need for a government to make that assessment and to make the results public. As it is, I often have the feeling that I am not quite sure what is happening or whether the measures taken are adequate. A moment ago-the Minister for Health agreed with me-I said that it is a common view that it is more by good luck than by good management-

TALK.START.PARA: —I did not agree with that.

—This is what the Minister agreed with: On the past record that can not be proved because we have done very well. As the threat gets larger-I think it is a growing threat-we have to be constantly vigilant in this area. Another problem that will remain concerns viruses borne by non-human carriers such as the wind, birds and insects. Page 36 of the report of the Senate Committee on National Resources on the adequacy of quarantine refers to this matter when it mentions the problem of the screw worm fly. The report reads:

SPEECH.PARA: In the field of animal quarantine probably the most immediate known threat is the introduction of screw worm fly from Papua New Guinea. This fly is a threat particularly to the cattle industry-it lays its eggs in open wounds . . .

I will not go on with that since we have all just had dinner. Anyhow, it is hard to stop the flies flying across the border. It is a particular risk. Again, preventing entry is an impossible task. The Government needs also to develop a system which will ensure early detection and isolation of any viruses which do enter Australia and which are a threat. It needs to have worked out a strategy for the control of disease if an outbreak occurs. Again, this strategy should be made public. The compensation provisions of any strategy would also need to be worked out carefully and made public. Producers need to have their economic viability restored. For example, in a recent case in Tasmania the compensation paid did not cover the replacement cost of the destroyed property. We must acknowledge that there will be gaps in any quarantine system, but we need to be aware of what the gaps are and to know that Australia has a second line of defence ready to be implemented in the event of an outbreak of disease. Finally, we need to recognise that, because of the export orientation, livestock production in Australia is much more vulnerable to the adverse effects of exotic disease emergencies than is the case in most countries. For example, the discovery of foot and mouth disease in Australia would disrupt the export of 90 per cent of meats normally exported, and some reaction could be expected even against Australian wool, despite the technical evidence relating to the virus being unable to survive in wool.

In am trying to stress that this is a very serious matter. I have already given some qualification of this view, but I repeat that, to date, Australia's quarantine system has operated on a basis of good luck rather than good management. For example, in a keynote address to an exotic disease emergency seminar held last year, the director of the Bureau of Animal Health pointed out that our national luck in avoiding most major exotic disease influences might be wearing a bit thin, as the last five years had seen a series of eight exotic disease incidents and scares affecting various livestock-based industries. The Minister stated in his second reading speech:
The Bill is a reflection of the Government's strong commitment to an efficient quarantine service.

To achieve this efficient service, the Government's strategy is as follows, firstly, to establish a high security animal quarantine station on the Cocos Islands, at an estimated cost of quarantine of about $15,000 per animal, and to extend the application of the Quarantine Act to take in the Cocos Island. Secondly, and I quote from the Minister's speech:
. . . to make . . . changes to overcome deficiencies experienced in the administration of the Act and make it more responsive to modern situations.

One of those changes is to remove the liability of the Commonwealth to pay compensation for imported livestock destroyed in accordance with the Act where the animals has been in quarantine since importation. The Government's attitude is that that is an insurable risk, and again I can take quotations from the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources which back the Government in that regard.

One of the major deficiences of the existing quarantine system relates to the administrative arrangements. This is ignored by the Government in its proposed amendments to modernise the Quarantine Act. The Quarantine Act currently is administered by the Commonwealth Department of Health, with that Department assuming overall responsibility for the administration of not only human but also plant and animal quarantine. One glance at a chart of the organisational structure of the quarantine system indicates the unnecessarily cumbersome procedures created by this allocation of responsibility. For the plant and animal quarantine services the line of authority moves from the Commonwealth Department of Health to the State departments of agriculture, which then effectively run the services. Only the human quarantine service functions totally within the Department of Health.

Since World War II the thrust of our quarantine system has shifted significantly away from human diseases towards plant and animal diseases. This reflects both a greater understanding of plant and animal quarantine problems and changes world wide in the human disease situation. Quarantine in Australia is now primarily concerned with preventing the entry of agricultural pests and diseases and not human disease, as was the case when the Quarantine Act was introduced in 1908. At the point of entry humans are now more important as carriers of animal and plant diseases than as carriers of human diseases. Exotic human diseases are rarely discovered at the point of entry because they tend to appear later, when the traveller is out in the community. An efficient and effective quarantine system is vital to the continued prosperity of Australia's rural industries.

I conclude on this note: The outbreak of any new animal disease in Australia could result not only in the loss of a significant proportion of our livestock but also in a very serious and possibly complete reduction of opportunities to continue trading in overseas markets, which currently take the bulk of Australia's livestock production. Because of its export orientation, Australia's livestock production is particularly vulnerable to the adverse effects of exotic disease emergencies, and I have already given some figures on that. In response to a recognition that it is Australia's industries that stand to lose the most from an in- efficient quarantine system, in recent years there have been a number of suggestions that the Commonwealth's administrative arrangements for quarantine should be reorganised to reflect the changed priorities which I have just set out. The suggested rearrangements were put forward mainly in the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources, but other reports have dealt with this matter. The rearrangement referred to in the report relates to a formal link between agricultural quarantine and other Commonwealth responsibilities for agricultural matters.

The Labor Government initiated a proposal for a unified quarantine service to be operated solely by the Commonwealth. It is not so much the Bill before the House but the so-called razor gang report which seems to want to put it almost entirely into the State sphere. A second proposal was put forward in 1977 by the Australian Agricultural Council that animal and plant quarantine should be given to the Department of Primary Industry. In early 1978 the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) advised that there would be no change in the existing arrangements. As I have already pointed out, the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources inquiry into the adequacy of quarantine concluded that an Australian quarantine service located in the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry should be created. True to the Prime Minister's word, the Quarantine Amendment Bill does not incorporate at that recommendation.

At the outset of these brief comments I said that we are not concerned very much about the administrative arrangements, except to say that the arguments are very strong. We are very concerned by what we read in the razor gang's report about handing over further functions to the States. We believe that the most important thing for Australia is to have a first rate quarantine service. Instead of the razor gang looking with an accountant's pen approach at how it can foist a few functions onto the States, we should be looking first of all at what is the best quarantine service for Australia and working out what the administrative arrangements should be. I believe that the Senate Committee looked at that. It proposed another structure that did not diminish the Commonwealth's role but seemed to be much more sensible. Now that the razor gang's report has come down, I hope that the Minister in his reply to the various points made in the House will take up this point. Will the quarantine arrangements be the main concern of the Government or is it simply and coldbloodedly trying to work out some way of getting rid of the quarantine service and making the States pay for the officers involved in quarantine surveillance? It is for those reasons that I moved my amendment, and I will not read it again. It is before honourable members.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak later.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), who was once the member for Macarthur, made the point that, when he was the member for Macarthur, in one of his early speeches in this place he made reference to the need for an animal health laboratory to be established at Geelong. My second or third speech in this House was a little similar in that I referred to the need for a maximum security quarantine station. As I had been a director of the largest artificial breeding co-operative in Australia I had a considerable interest in the subject of animals and I have maintained that interest. I commend the Minister for Health (Mr McKellar) on these amendments to the Quarantine Act. Together with the 1979 amendments, they indicate that great progress has been made by this Government in updating the Quarantine Act to make it more appropriate for our present circumstances.

SPEECH.PARA: I also want to commend the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources for its report on the adequacy of quarantine procedures. That has been quite a catalyst in the updating of necessary legislation. The Minister pointed out in his second reading speech that this legislation covers several distinct sections of the Quarantine Act. The Cocos (Keeling) Islands Territory quarantine arrangements need to be made appropriate prior to the arrival of the first shipment of cattle from North America which I understand will be in November of this year. Those arrangements provide additional powers for quarantine officers, remove compensation for animals which have to be destroyed at a quarantine station and generally implement the remaining recommendations of the Senate Committee which the Government considers it can actually implement.

The Cocos (Keeling) Island Territory generally must have adequate quarantine regulations if there is to be an effective working of the high security quarantine station. I believe that is a very appropriate part of the amendments. The additional powers which this legislation gives to quarantine officers will give them the same powers as Customs officers with the exception of the power to order a body search. Officers should now have adequate power to apprehend and control animals and plants which may be brought to Australia either legally or illegally by ship or other vessel. I particularly congratulate the Minister on his decision to amend the Act to require the masters of all ships and aircraft travelling to Australia to advise all those on board of Australia's quarantine requirements. There has been a conscious effort over the last few years to inform Australians and those on flights entering Australia of the reasons for our Quarantine Act and to inform them of the requirements on flights into Australia. Generally the more that people are told the more that people will co-operate.

Until now information for those flying into Australia has been passive; that is, by pamphlet. A considerable step forward is an authoritative announcement by the captain of a vessel which is far more positive, effective and certain. There are two weaknesses in the system at the port of entry I want to refer to and draw to the Minister's attention. I believe adequate power already exists to overcome these two weaknesses. The first concerns the purchase of a souvenir overseas which is made from plants or animals, the entry of which will not be permitted for quarantine or endangered species reasons. Recently I dealt with a case of this nature in which people tried to bring back stuffed tortoises from the Philippines. I was advised that travel agents have booklets which give to those leaving Australia details of what they should or should not bring back. Unfortunately, quite often the person going overseas leaves Australia without being given such a booklet. I suggest to the Minister that the most likely person to purchase such a souvenir is an Australian tourist. If that booklet could be given to tourists together with their boarding pass-in other words it is forced into their hands at the time of departure when they are more likely to read and consider that sort of thing rather than relying on the travel agents giving them this booklet-this would have a beneficial effect. If my understanding of the presentation of that booklet is not correct I would welcome the Minister's correction.

The second and more serious problem with which I wish to deal is the passive and casual way in which people entering Australia and proceeding through Customs direct themselves to the quarantine section and the seemingly equally casual way in which those quarantine officers question those people. There is a widespread belief among passengers that the best way to beat Customs and avoid a baggage search is to get into the quarantine line because once they get into the quarantine line they are safe from Customs and can bring in all the illegal or over the limit goodies that they want to bring in. The Senate Committee report recommended that quarantine officers be given powers of search and that a separate random sampling technique for quarantine purposes-separate but similar to the random searches for Customs purposes-be initiated. This is a sensible suggestion. As quarantine officers have this power a random quarantine search additional to the self-declaration procedure should be introduced. It would please me to hear the Minister state whether that procedure is already in operation. On my recent return from Japan I saw no evidence of it at the Sydney airport. If it is not being used at present I believe it is essential that this procedure be instituted if we are to have any effective quarantine procedure for entry to this country.

Those who are put in the quarantine line, whether it is because of self-declaration or random sampling, should be required randomly to have a Customs search to overcome this widespread feeling that in order to avoid Customs one should put oneself into the quarantine line by stating that one has been on a farm somewhere. A further Senate Committee recommendation to which I wish to draw the attention of the Minister-I realise it is not his responsibility but it is most important in the prosecution of quarantine violators-is the Committee's reference to the fact that Australian surveillance aircraft had an unfortunate habit of flying along the coast at the same time every day. While they followed this procedure everybody knew the time at which this took place and adjusted their entry or exit from this country accordingly.

TALK.START.PARA: —And watches.

—I believe some of them were even that regular. I hope that now-as this was pointed out some time ago in that Committee report-that problem has been overcome by some form of staggered or random flying. I would welcome the Minister's comment on this point. The related issues of development of the Cocos quarantine station and the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory at Geelong at last have become a reality or are on their way to reality after years of discussion and debate. The quarantine station at Cocos is about to commence. The laboratory at Geelong is well under construction. These two centres were the subject of some controversy recently at the cattle council seminar on quarantine. The point was correctly made in reports on the seminar which I have read that after talking and planning for many years it is questionable whether these facilities are now appropriate or even necessary. Professor Morris, as reported in various newspapers, challenged their relevance and value.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) has pointed out that the Geelong laboratory is redundant because of synthetic vaccines.
