However, my understanding of the report in the newspaper is that Professor Morris ignored a major function of the laboratory at Geelong which is the diagnosis of foot and mouth disease in cases such as the Tasmanian scare and the New Zealand scare. Irrespective of vaccines of any type, until the laboratory at Geelong is operating we will require the material to be sent to the Purbright laboratory in the United Kingdom and will experience time delay problems. Following upon that is the necessity for the development of particular strains of vaccines. This could be done more appropriately and quickly in this country if an outbreak ever occurs. The honourable member for Werriwa referred to the bad geographic position of the Cocos facility and the developments with semen and ova transplant technology et cetera. He pointed out also that semen can carry foot and mouth disease, bluetongue and other diseases of tremendous danger to this country. At least in the period ahead our best protection will be by obtaining live animals through Cocos.

Honourable members might remember the problems associated with the choice of the site for the animal quarantine station. It had to be sufficiently far away from the Australian mainland to be free of insect carriers et cetera. This brought with it the problem of under-utilisation because of costs. The geographical problem together with increased oil prices mean that transport costs to get an animal to Cocos are very high unless there is a full load. There would be problems also with the viability of bringing numbers of animals from a particular country or region and the fact that there is no backloading from Cocos. Putting aside the transport costs, I was reassured by the Minister's statement that due to the way in which the station is constructed and being managed the 1973 estimates of operational costs will still apply. That is quite an achievement. I understand that due to this problem of transport costs the first consignment of cattle from Europe has been cancelled. There does appear to be a need for a co-ordinated transport operation to make, if we like, the best use of the station as possible. Perhaps, the Australian Registered Cattle Breeders Association could act in some co-ordinating capacity for the stud breeders groups or the commercial groups.

It is recognised that the Cocos (Keeling) Islands station probably will have sporadic use. Initially there will be utilisation from North America and western Europe. Then there will probably be another period of greater activity once Geelong opens for those breeds from Africa and elsewhere which are not considered safe to bring in at the present time. I am pleased that earlier problems with the priorities committee and disputes between stud breeders and animal scientists on the question of priorities and use of the Cocos Islands have been satisfactorily overcome. I support the legislation and acknowledge the work of the Minister and the Department and after so many years the commencement of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands station.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: —Australia is one of the few countries that are virtually free of serious animal plagues, plant pests and disease. This could very well be because of the position of the country, because we are an island continent. That has given this country great advantages in the past. One of those great advantages of being an island continent no longer exists. We must realise that there have been changes in quarantine in that human disease is no longer the threat that it was when legislation on quarantine was first introduced. Exotic human diseases are rarely found at ports of entry because of the speed with which people are able to travel from place to place. Many factors have led to a changing philosophy in human quarantine in recent times. Medical science has advanced and, whilst quarantine is still vitally important, for humans it does not any longer have the same characteristics as quarantine does for animals.

SPEECH.PARA: The Quarantine Amendment Bill is almost totally related to animals and plants. In supporting the amendment moved by the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin), I am concerned at the changes that will take place with the implementation of the Lynch razor gang report-the Review of Commonwealth Functions. The Government appears to be hell-bent on shifting responsibility to the States and to others to carry the costs of the burden. The Senate Standing Committee on National Resources considered in its report:

That in meeting the new challenges facing quarantine steps should be taken to improve the status of the quarantine service, and to increase public awareness of, and respect for, quarantine requirements.

I am sure that when that report was brought down the Senate Standing Committee was not intending to increase public awareness in the way that it has been in the last couple of weeks. I quote from a couple of reports in newspapers from Victoria. There were reports in newspapers from all over Australia. On 30 April 1981 the Sun had a headline: 'Womble hunt for thousands'. The article read:
The hamster hunt along the eastern Australian coast took on a new twist yesterday when it was learned up to 22,000 'wombles' could be involved.

Here we have a situation in the recent past-in the last week or two-where the quarantine measures of this country, the very nature of the health of human beings and of animals, have been placed at risk. On 29 April 1981 the Age stated:
Quarantine officials have seized more than 250 pet hamsters and gerbils in Melbourne, Brisbane and Caloundra which they believe could be infected with rabies and meningitis.

Rabies is a disease that this country is free of. Yet, we have a situation where we have these creatures in this country at the present time. They have been brought in illegally. That shows that somewhere along the line there has been a very bad breakdown in our quarantine situation.

I refer to a method that apparently this Government has decided to use to overcome this problem. I refer to a joint Press statement by the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) and the Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Moore). This apparently shows a new way of how we will protect this country with quarantine measures. The Press statement is headed: 'Children and parents asked to find hamsters'. The statement reads:

It is estimated that approximately 600 of the animals are at present in Australia. The Ministers said investigators had learnt that hamsters had been offered for sale in Queensland, New South Wales and Victoria in the guise of cartoon characters known as 'Wombles'.

A few questions need to be answered as to how these creatures were able to get into the country. Why were they able to spread so widely before anybody realised that the whole future perhaps of agriculture in this country had been placed at risk as well as the fact that rabies could be spread throughout the country? I think the Minister should clearly answer in this debate the question as to why those wombles-as they are called-were able to get through the system. It shows a very poor weakness in the system and the way it works at the present time.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are laughing about it.

—They may laugh, but it is a very serious situation. I am sure that the public of Australia is taking a very serious interest in this. The messages I have been receiving show this. Luckily the public is doing this. Maybe we will find all the animals before they start to breed because they breed like rabbits. We know how many rabbits there are around the country.

SPEECH.PARA: I refer again to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. It stated:

The creation of an Australian quarantine service located in the Commonwealth Department of Primary Industry would reflect the changing priorities of quarantine and effectively link quarantine to the overall agricultural health responsibilities of the Commonwealth.

Whether the policy section of the Australian quarantine service is located in the Health Department or the Primary Industry Department is not the crucial issue. There may be good reasons for a decision to move the service to the Department of Primary Industry for administration benefits. However, what is important is how the quarantine is managed. To me, the alarming fact is that this Government, by its obsession with cutting out spending which can be publicly accounted for and by transferring responsibilities to private enterprise, is placing agriculture in this country at risk. I quote again from the Minister's second reading speech. On page 6 he stated:

During coastal surveillance operations, a number of unauthorised landings in Australia have been reported. In the main, these breaches of quarantine legislation have been by foreign fishing vessels. These quarantine breaches by small craft in remote areas of Australia pose grave threats to the introduction of major exotic diseases.
Maybe they also allow wombles to get into the country. The Minister continued:
Foot and mouth disease, Newcastle disease and rabies are some of the diseases from which Australia is free but which are all well established in adjacent countries.
We would not think so from some of the actions of this Government. The Minister continued:

Much of our northern coastline of this country is backed by economically important livestock areas which are also abundantly populated with feral animals and insect vectors capable of transmitting any introduced exotic disease.
These are all very important statements. The Minister went on:
For this reason any reports of an authorised landing evoke a quarantine investigation of the landing place and appropriate measures to minimise the possibility of disease introduction.

The Minister mentioned coastal surveillance. Here I think, we are seeing where the greatest weakness is: This Commonwealth Government, this Fraser Government, does not want to take its full responsibility. First of all, coastal surveillance is done now by private enterprise. It is done on a tender system which means that the people who are doing the surveillance are cutting costs according to their budgets as much as they possibly can because they have to make a profit.

That tender system leaves a very large weakness in the whole system. It is open to infiltration. The staff who work for the private companies cannot be vetted by anybody in any public position. If this function were done by a navy, army, air force or some government body there could be vetting of the staff. As we know, surveillance is done on the basis of a five-day week. It is not done at weekends. Everybody in Darwin knows just when the planes are flying. It would not be very hard for the staff of an organisation to let those who wanted to import things into Australia know when to do so. The Government is letting the country down by not taking its full responsibility, by handing this matter over to private enterprise. Looking after the coastal surveillance of this country is not a private enterprise job. The planes fly set routes. Everybody knows what the routes are. Ask anybody in Darwin and they will soon say just when the planes are flying. It would not be very hard to bring in a boat load of wombles but we would need only a few because they breed like rabbits. I would like the Minister to tell us clearly how this legislation will improve our quarantine situation in any way at all. In the next paragraph of the Minister's second reading speech, he said:
Quarantine actions of this type have highlighted serious practical deficiencies in the relevant enforcement and penalty provisions of the Act.

It is fair enough that we should tighten up the Act, because it has weaknesses. But we have to catch the culprit before we can take him to court. If the surveillance system is to work on a roster of eight hours a day or consist of a run down the coast and back which everybody knows about I do not think that we will be using this Act very often to prosecute many people. They will very easily dodge the surveillance system. That is a very poor situation for the Government.

I have a few questions that the Minister can perhaps answer for me when he replies to the second reading debate. In the Senate Committee's report reference was made to the need for facilities for poultry as well as animals on the Cocos Islands. I would like the Minister to let us know what is going on in that regard. Another question relates to an incident which has occurred in the last few days. A B52 bomber has landed in Darwin. Are those aircraft subject to quarantine? If so, will the officers of his Department who have to go on board to fumigate the aircraft be notified if the bombers are carrying nuclear weapons? I would also like the Minister to tell us his attitude to the possibility of people entering Australia directly from Bali being treated as though they had been on a farm and having their shoes placed in disinfectant. The number of people coming to Australia from Bali could have very dangerous implications for Australia's quarantine laws. Australia's favourable disease status is of vital importance to its overseas trade in agricultural products. If we need proof of that we have only to look to the other side of the House to see who will be speaking in this debate tonight. Two members of the National Country Party, not the Liberal Party, will be speaking.

Freedom from major exotic diseases, is a pre-requisite for access to many markets which are of vital economic importance to this country. We have only to recall the range of restrictions imposed on Australia's exports as a result of the bluetongue scare in 1977-78. Freedom from exotic disease also enables many agricultural industries to minimise their costs of production. Being free of disease is a great asset for this country. I think it is the responsibility of the Federal Government to see that it stays that way. In recent years there have been a number of suggestions that the Commonwealth administrative arrangements for quarantine should be reorganised. The Labor Government of 1972 to 1975 initiated proposals for a unified quarantine service operated solely by the Commonwealth. The reason that the Opposition has moved this amendment this evening is that it is concerned that the Government seems hell-bent on switching functions to the States and not picking up its own responsibilities. Exports worth $5,000m depend on the Government's taking up its responsibilities in respect of quarantine. Let us consider the seriousness of what could happen if we had a plague of hamsters and gerbils running around the country like rabbits. Our total quarantine situation could be placed in jeopardy. Those animals would travel, breed and spread disease. The so-called Fraser federalism or razor gang proposals do not equate with a sensible approach to quarantine. An industry with exports in excess of $5,000m should be able to rely on Commonwealth support. It should not be fragmented and handed to private enterprise or broken up in such a way that there is no security. Another Bill relating to the beef industry will be introduced in this session. That industry has been handed $118m in concessions over the last three or four years. If the Commonwealth can make handouts to the industry for political purposes, surely it can make money available to guarantee the future of the industry. Money needs to be invested by the Commonwealth to guarantee the agricultural industry and the health of the people of this country. It is a shame that this Government is prepared to opt out of its responsibilities. I solidly support the amendment moved by the honourable member for Werriwa.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cowan Mr D.B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like briefly to support the Quarantine Amendment Bill and to compliment the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar) on bringing it before the House. I appreciate that the Opposition has moved an amendment to the Bill but, broadly speaking, we are all in accord with one thing, and that is that we must jealously guard the stock and the people of Australia in our quarantine measures. The amendments in the Bill before the House are principally concerned with tightening up the Act. They give to the officers concerned greater powers in relation to inspections. I am vitally concerned with the operation of the Cocos (Keeling) Islands quarantine station. Over the years we have witnessed our beef and dairy cattle breeders importing large quantities of semem. We appreciate that we are unable to import livestock from most of the primary producing countries. This legislation will enable us to do so.

SPEECH.PARA: We cannot let this Bill pass without emphasising its very great importance to the primary industries of Australia. It tightens our quarantine measures and gives the people of Australia an awareness of their responsibilities in relation to them. We are virtually free of the major diseases that are present in most other countries. Those diseases are very close to our shores, not so much in Papua New Guinea, but within a couple of hours by air and a day or so by ship. We are trying to keep out exotic diseases such as bluetongue and foot and mouth. We cannot afford to be careless.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot hand over responsibility to the States.

—The honourable member should not interrupt. The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) spent most of his speech not only criticising the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) but also talking about the gerbils that we have been reading about in the Press of late. If Opposition members opposite were to concentrate on agricultural, as the honourable member did only towards the end of his speech, there might be some substance in what they say.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress that this country has a very long coastline. From Geraldton to Cairns, is only half the coastline of Australia. It takes tremendous surveillance to protect us from ships and people coming into Australia. I do not agree with the honourable member for McMillan, who maintained that surveillance is not being conducted in a proper manner. Certainly, we would all like to see greater surveillance of the Australian coastline, whether it be in the north or the south. My information is that these surveillance flights are staggered. It is the Government's policy that they be carried out by private enterprise in most cases. That is a better way to carry out this task because these private enterprises have the aircraft and the facilities to do it. I do not think we can expect our armed forces to carry out this necessary work around the entire Australian coastline. The Government is concerned about the number of boats under 45 metres in length landing on the shores of Australia with people from other lands on board. They land here without letting us know before hand. I appreciate that under this Act there are quarantine measures carried out on their arrival but as far as we are concerned they are not adequate.

We feel that it is important that this Act is tightened up. The Government appreciates the responsibility it has to look after the quarantine of this country. I think that the honourable member for Werriwa (Mr Kerin) said that if foot and mouth disease broke out in Australia it would cost us $2,500m in the first year. There is no need to emphasise that this is basically a primary producing country and that we have to protect and assist in the building up of our national herds and plant life. We must not forget that a growing number of tourists visit Australia yearly, and that greater numbers of these are coming from countries to our north. I am very pleased that the Minister has indicated in the Bill that more information will be available to people entering Australia both by plane and ship of the quarantine measures we are conducting.

There is one particular matter appertaining to quarantine that I would like to stress this evening. Last Thursday night I spoke on the adjournment debate about the dangers one can see in relation to the disposal of garbage from visiting ships, appreciating the fact that these ships carry with them food from their countries of origin. I stressed the point then that in the Newcastle area one can generally see at any time anything between a dozen to 40-odd large container ships anchored off the harbour. If one goes to Wollongong, Port Kembla and, I dare say, other ports around Australia, one will find the same situation. I have been informed that the quarantine measures ensure that the garbage is sprayed before it leaves the ships. These ships that are at anchorage at various ports around Australia and those traversing our coastline are tipping garbage into the sea. That garbage is landing on our shores. I know that there are wild pigs and wild dogs in the Newcastle area because it is adjacent to bush land which runs to the forestry land in the areas of the Great Dividing Range. These pigs and dogs are able to get through to the coast and, if exotic disease were contained within the ships' garbage, it would certainly be spread around the Australian countryside.

I was informed only this afternoon that it is the feeling of the quarantine authorities that the garbage found in these regions is basically from the Newcastle area and not from the ships. This is hard to believe because only the other day the shire council concerned informed me that it believed after inspecting the area that the majority of the garbage came from the boats that were anchored off-shore. I stress that point because I believe it is very important that we are aware of this problem.

I suppose that ships are basically the means by which we can expect diseases and animals to be brought into Australia. When I speak of animals I mean poultry. There have been reports that poultry has been landed on the shores of Australia from some of the fishing vessels from the East that have been fishing off-shore. Naturally these vessels are hard to detect. Although quarantine measures are conducted on container ships which are tied up at the wharves in any of the ports of Australia, there is a possibility that unless a close inspection is made, rats and other animals from the ships will trot off onto the wharves, get onto the trucks and distribute themselves around the farmlands and cities of Australia. We have to be aware of these things. I can assure honourable members that any measures that this Government can take to strengthen this Quarantine Act will be very important to the primary producers of Australia. They look to us to take the maximum measures that we possibly can to ensure that these measures are taken.

I said something earlier concerning the Cocos (Keeling) Islands quarantine station. As the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) said earlier, the station will be open from approximately November. I know that this is welcomed particularly by the breeders of pure bred animals within Australia. Previously semen imported from America had to come through great Britain and to comply with its quarantine regulations. It was required to remain in quarantine for two years before it was allowed to come into Australia. Although the Cocos (Keeling) Islands station at this time does not actually have the facilities for the quarantine of semen, it certainly does have the facilities for the quarantine of animals. The breeders of this country will be able to import beef stock, dairy stock and horses from the best breeds throughout the world. With artificially inseminated semen being available we have been able to improve the herds and we will certainly be able to do more so in the future.

When the Minister is replying I ask him to say something about the future plans of the Department of Health so far as the quarantine of AI semen from overseas is concerned, both for the dairy herds and for the beef herds of Australia. I think many of our growers are interested to know just what the future will be in this respect. As I said earlier, this Bill contains most important amendments to a very important Act and certainly gives to the officers of the Department concerned every assurance on the tightening up they need. It brings the responsibility to the State, and rightfully so. It is a matter of philosophy as to whether the Commonwealth should control these things, and whether it should be the only body in this field. Certainly it is the duty of the Commonwealth to initiate the legislation. But we believe that the experts in the various departments of agriculture in our States are the people who understand on the farm agriculture and the measures that have to be taken to protect it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are wrong. That is not why the Government is handing responsibility to the States.
—The honourable member wants to get his facts right. I am afraid he is not correct on these things. I welcome this Bill, as I am sure do the bulk of Australians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scholes Mr G.G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Quarantine is too important a matter to be the subject of small party debate. Some very serious concern has been shown in this House about its administration and effectiveness. I have to challenge the suggestions of the previous speaker, the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), that the present scrutiny of the Australian coastline is satisfactory. It is anything but satisfactory. Substantial proportions of the Australian coast are policed in the most cursory manner. I understand the difficulties associated with extending that policing in any form. I want to make one request of the Minister for Health (Mr MacKellar), and that is, that he makes a clear statement of the Government's intentions under the razor gang's recommendations of handing quarantine facilities over to the States. If it did that it would be a disaster for primary industry in Australia because the States are neither competent nor capable of carrying out that function, nor would the State governments expend the funds necessary to do it properly. The honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) would probably confirm this, but in Victoria and New South Wales there are quarantine safeguards regarding fruit fly. At Yarrawonga there are two bridges over the Murray River with approximately the same distance-physical, not political-between them as now exists between me and the honourable member for Murray. One bridge is manned from nine until five and the other is not manned at all. So those who do want to bring in a case of oranges or some other goods--
—Or apples!

—No, not apples, oranges. We fixed the apples. They have to get across the sea and the Commonwealth inspects them. Quite seriously, there is no real quarantine facility nor capacity. Those who often walk down the concourse at Melbourne airport will be aware that the last time it was manned for quarantine purposes was in about 1966. One is asked to comply with regulations on an honour system. Quarantine is important. The problems which this Parliament experienced over a number of years largely arose out of the Tourmer case but also out of the maladministration which was disclosed in the numbers of inquiries which took place into that case. They indicated quite clearly that the Commonwealth must handle the quarantine laws in Australia. It is not a matter which can be left to some political, theoretical position. It is real. Damage that would be done from any back-off would also be real. In the past the quarantine laws have not been administered as well as they should nor as tightly as they should. That is not the fault of any government. We have had problems over a long period with quarantine. It is a difficult matter.

SPEECH.PARA: I ask the Minister to assure the House that the Commonwealth intends to accept its responsibilities to protect Australia from the dangers of breaches of quarantine. I do not agree that the policing of the Australian coastline is satisfactory. I wish to raise a question which was raised by the honourable member for McMillian (Mr Cunningham). A civil aircraft landing in Australia is sprayed for insects and all other materials. I do not intend to labour the point, but I want to know whether military aircraft are subject to the same quarantine provisions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank all of those who took part in the debate this evening. I believe, as all speakers have said, that this is a most important matter. The Government is committed to a strong and efficient quarantine service. That is demonstrated by the comprehensive Bill before the House which must continue to play an effective and major role in Australia's social and economic well-being. We are all concerned to ensure that the quarantine service is strong and effective and that it does protect Australia's plant and livestock industries as well as our health. I assure the House that no decisions will be made by the Government which would weaken the quarantine service or compromise the quarantine controls on which we, as a nation, rely so heavily.

SPEECH.PARA: The report of the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources which has been mentioned by various speakers was welcomed by the Government. This was made abundantly clear in the Government's response which was tabled in another place in September 1980. This response, I remind honourable members, indicated acceptance of substantially all of the Senate Committee's recommendations. The Senate Standing Committee on National Resources strongly endorsed the long-established practice of delegation of animal and plant operational quarantine functions to the States. The Committee states in the summary of the report that:
The delegated role of the States in undertaking the operational role in respect of plant and animal quarantine has been very successful and should be continued.

We, on this side of the House, do not have the contempt for State governments and State administrations which is very evident in the contributions which have been made by honourable members opposite. But in view of that point it must therefore be regarded as totally responsible and in accordance with the spirit of the Senate Committee report to examine the feasibility-I underline that statement, to examine the feasibility-of extending an arrangement which the Senate Committee so heartily endorsed. I would also like to make brief reference to page 59 of the Standing Committee report which states, in respect to delegations to the States that:

. . . the advantages of State involvement are numerous-particularly access to expert local knowledge, co-operation in policy making, and uniting operational responsibility for quarantine and disease control within the States.

I remind the House that, as stated in my second reading speech, the amendments contained in the Bill, taken in conjunction with the amendments effected in the Quarantine Amendment Act 1979, do meet the specific concern raised by the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources which is appropriate to quarantine legislation. Some other matters were raised by honourable member. The honourable member for Werriwa mentioned a number of matters. After his speech he asked me what would happen in relation to avian genetic material. I can assure him that the matter is under active consideration at present. It will not be going to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands quarantine station. We are looking at a mainland station for quarantine requirements in relation to the importation of avian material.

I am grateful to the honourable member for Murray (Mr Lloyd) for his contribution to the debate. He injected a note of perhaps unintentional levity when he spoke about staggered and random flying. I hope that it was not too staggered or random in the surveillance of the Australian coastline. I take the point that he was making. We do not need to have and we do not have the situation in which planes are undertaking surveillance of the Australian coastline at the same time each day. The point is well taken and was well taken some time ago and has been very much understood and catered for by the arrangements which are presently in place. He mentioned also the question of random checks of people coming into Australia through airports and particularly those who claim to have been in contact with farm animals or farm material. In fact, random checks are made of all passengers coming through Australian airports. So we are alive to the situation which has been mentioned by the honourable member for Murray and we seek to overcome any procedures which would allow a person or persons to try to get around our quarantine procedures.

The honourable member for Werriwa said that it is only by good luck that Australia has been so successful in relation to quarantine matters. If it is only good luck that we have been successful then we have had good luck for a long time. I think the runs on the board are such that we can truthfully claim that the quarantine procedures are, in fact, working remarkably well. The honourable member for McMillan (Mr Cunningham) was concerned about animals he called wombles. Like so many people in the Australian Labor Party he has been reading a lot of fairy stories lately. There are no such things as wombles. They exist in people's imagination. In fact, there are animals called hamsters and gerbils. He is worried about them breeding like rabbits, but, in fact, they breed a little bit more quickly than rabbits We are extremely concerned about this question of hamsters and gerbils. There has been no breakdown in quarantine arrangements. It is easier for persons operating outside the law to hide a hamster, which is being sold as a womble, in Australia than it is to detect it. It is a fairly small animal after all. It is unrealistic to expect that any quarantine system could exclude all risks at the point of entry. What is essential is that once a risk is detected there is a rapid follow-up to overcome that situation.

We have received information which suggests that the joint Commonwealth-State control program has been extremely effective in apprehending-if one can use that term about these small animals-or in bringing to light the majority of these animals. I stress that our task is to respond quickly and effectively to any disease situation which does arise. This has been done and is being done. Further events are in the pipeline which, I believe, will add to the success of the campaign which has already been undertaken.

The honourable member for McMillan also raised the question of B52 bombers, and that point was echoed later by the honourable member for Corio (Mr Scholes). I would just like to assure these honourable gentlemen and the House that B52 bombers are subject to quarantine regulations and are routinely disinfected. we are not going to abandon our quarantine procedures lightly or inadvisedly. In fact, and I make this point again, the quarantine procedures have been extremely successful over the years and we will ensure that we keep those successful quarantine procedures.

I am grateful to the honourable member for Lyne (Mr Cowan), who has had extensive experience in this area as a State member of parliament. I am quite sure he would not agree with any of the denigratory remarks about State governments which emanated from the Opposition side of the House. The honourable member for Corio talked about the question of handing over quarantine requirements to the States. I have outlined the situation which applies and I think that that situation is a totally responsible one. It is one which has at its heart the continued operation of an effective quarantine organisation.

The honourable member for Werriwa raised the question of the location of the administration of the quarantine system. Of course, the administrative arrangements are a matter for the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). However, I point out that there are close links between human health, human quarantine and agricultural quarantine. Essentially, these links exist because people, goods, materials animals and plants and the vessels or aircraft in which they arrive and travel are possible avenues of diseases of humans, animals or plants. It is a fact that unfortunately many diseases are transmissable between animals and man by a variety of means. The factors I have outlined demand co-ordination of policies, operational strategies and procedures between all the branches of quarantine and that need is catered for in a simple, all-embracing Quarantine Act. I believe it is very well catered for under the current arrangements.

I do not think it is fair to say, as has been implied by the honourable member for Werriwa, that we have only been lucky. I think great credit is due to those people who over the years have operated the quarantine service in Australia. That is in no sense a complacent statement. I am as much aware as anybody of the dangers of the introduction into this country of exotic plant and animal diseases and human diseases. As long as I have responsibility for the quarantine service I will be doing all I can to prevent any such introduction.
Question put-
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Kerin's amendment) stand part of the question.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.
Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) In clause 15, page 6, line 25, omit ''and''.
(2) In clause 15, page 6, after paragraph (b) insert the following word and paragraph:
''and (c) by adding at the end thereof the following sub-section:
''(2) The master of an overseas vessel arriving in Australia or the Cocos Islands shall not, except by reason of stress of weather or for other reasonable cause, cause or permit the vessel to be-
(a) beached in Australia or the Cocos Islands, as the case may be; or

(b) moored, anchored or otherwise secured in waters on the landward side of the low-water mark around the shore of the continent, or an island, forming part of Australia or of an island forming part of the Cocos Islands, as the case may be,
otherwise than at a port.
Penalty: $5,000 or imprisonment for 2 years.''.

Section 20 of the Quarantine Act makes it an offence for the master of an overseas vessel arriving in Australia to enter any port other than a port which has been declared to be a first port of entry. Clause 15 of the Bill seeks to extend those provisions to the Cocos (Keeling) Islands. The further amendment would insert an additional paragraph (c) in clause 15 of the Bill to extend the provisions of section 20 to make it an offence also for the master of an overseas vessel to beach the vessel or to anchor or moor the vessel above the low water mark around the shore of Australia or the Cocos (Keeling) Islands, excepting from stress of weather or other reasonable cause. This amendment would ensure the detention and forfeiture provisions provided in clause 38 of the Bill would adequately cover all unauthorised landings in Australia or the Cocos (Keeling) Islands that present a quarantine risk. I commend the amendments to the Committee.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report-by leave-adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Mr MacKellar)-by leave-read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Mr Acting Speaker, I wish to make a short amendment to an answer that I provided to the House earlier in the day. I answered a question asked by the honourable member for Hotham (Mr Kent) in relation to Aboriginal health centres, womens refuges and the family planning program. I feel that my reply in relation to the family planning program may have been a little unclear. Therefore, I would like to clarify the position of the program under the new health funding arrangements. Whilst it is true to say, as I said, that the family planning program comes within the Community Health Program it is also a national program and therefore will not be funded through general revenue grants. This program will continue to be directly funded in the next financial year by the Commonwealth Government. As stated this afternoon, womens refuges will be funded in future throught the general revenue grants. A statement on Aboriginal medical assistance will be made to this House at a later time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 30 April, on motion by Mr Howard:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Willis Mr R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Bill seeks to amend the Census and Statistics Act to give effect to some of the recommendations on privacy in the census made by the Law Reform Commission some two years ago. The Government, through the Treasurer (Mr Howard) commented in November 1979 on these recommendations. The Bill gives legislative effect to those parts of the recommendations which the Government sees fit to adopt. The principal amendments involved are designed, to make clear that Australian Bureau of Statistics staff-collectors and interviewers-involved in the census are bound by the secrecy provision of the Act. It ensures that former officers of the Bureau are bound by the secrecy provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill substantially upgrades all penalties, as the Law Reform Commission recommended although it did not recommend any particular level of penalty to be applied. In fact, the increases in penalty are quite substantial. For failure to supply information to a census collector, failure to fill in a census form or refusal to answer all questions asked by Bureau officers the penalty is increased from $20 to $500 which is a very substantial increase indeed. For unauthorised disclosure of census information by Bureau officers or for supplying false information on a census form or in answer to a census officer the fine is increased from $100 to $1,000 or six months gaol or both. These large increases in penalty are obviously designed to ensure that in fact we have a census which accurately reflects the real situation in the nation. It seeks to ensure that we get full compliance by the population with the census and that the information provided is accurate and correct.

However, the increase in fines is very considerable and has given the Opposition some concern. We have decided not to oppose the legislation, bearing in mind the extreme importance of ensuring that the census is in fact very accurate and able to be relied on. However, the Law Reform Commission recommended in another report a general review of penalties applying in all Federal law make them consistent. In report No. 15 of the Law Reform Commission entitled 'Sentencing of Federal Offenders' recommendation 24 called for a sentencing council to be established to consider standardising penalties for federal offences. At present there are no clear standards for setting penalties; it is simply a rule of thumb. This is clearly not sufficiently specific to provide a rigorous, fair and equitable basis for setting penalties.

The Bill fails to give effect to some of the recommendations of the Law Reform Commission on privacy in the census. I wish to refer to two of those recommendations which have not been adopted by the Government. The first of those is that census returns should be kept in the Archives with access, for most purposes, prohibited for 75 years. The second is that the precise wording of census questions should be included in regulations so they can be debated by Parliament. The second recommendation is one which does not concern us so much. I think it is regrettable that the Government did not adopt it, but the Opposition is not particularly upset about the fact that it is not in the legislation. I note that in a statement made by the Treasurer in November 1979 it was indicated that perhaps at some future date, for the next census, the Government would adopt this recommendation.

The other recommendation is of more importance. It is that returns should be kept in the Archives with possible access to them for medical purposes within 75 years. The fact is that at present Australia does not keep the census form returns. We simply destroy them. Up until 1971 we kept the census forms for the previous two censuses but in 1971 the Government decided to destroy all previous census records, and after the 1971 census had been processed the records for that census also were destroyed. In 1976 the census was, of course, only half processed as an economy measure-an absurd economy if ever I have seen one-and then all the returns were destroyed. So, we have had a history in the last decade or so of not keeping our census records, of destroying the census returns and the only records of censuses are those which are compiled on the computer tapes and in the documents published from the original census returns.

Idenified census returns would be of obvious benefit to historical, genealogical and sociological research because they would provide a unique snapshot of the Australian society at the particular time when the census is taken. I do not think it needs elaboration from me to see that in future years it may be of great benefit to researchers to be able to go back to the original documents and analyse them to get a much better idea of society at the time than would be available from the tabulations made by us now. In fact, the idea of keeping the census forms in the past-when we kept them-as I said, for the two previous censuses up until 1971-was to enable us to make further cross-tabulations after the original cross-tabulations had been made if it seemed sensible to do so later. Of course, in future years when we may wish to make those cross-tabulations in respect of years past we will not be able to do it because we will have destroyed the records. Obviously it would be of benefit for us in that regard but also, and probably much more importantly, it would be of benefit for researchers in the historical, genealogical and sociological areas to be able to make those researches. I am here talking of many years hence.

It has also been pointed out by the Law Reform Commission that census returns can be of great benefit for environmental medical research. It mentions in its report an example of the way in which that environmental medical research can be assisted by identified census returns. The evidence to which it refers was given to the United States House of Representatives Sub-committee on Census and the Population in 1975. On page 38 of the Law Reform Commission report on privacy and the census, it states:

The evidence examined by the House Committee included examples of the medical research uses to which census information might be put. A simple example is provided by the difficulties associated with proper location of cancer concentrations ('hot spots') in the United States.
The Commission then quotes the United States House of Representatives committee report, which states:

For some 'hot spots', the explanation is widespread pollution by industry; for others, direct hazards on the job. Other 'hot spots' are difficult to interpret for several reasons. One reason that demonstrates the need for census data relates to the extreme mobility of the U.S. people. The latent period for cancer is known to be long; that is, in man, ten to thirty years may pass from the time cancer is induced by an agent to the time it appears clinically. If a twenty-year-old man had lived for years under the carcinogenic plume of a smelter, then moved to Los Angeles and, five years later, died of lung cancer, Los Angeles would be credited with a case of lung cancer. Under present regulations, his earlier residence-the one more relevant to the cause of his cancer-would be unknown. Census data may help resolve this difficulty.
The Law Reform Commission continues:

In a similar manner, identified census information might supply crucial information in the study of the relationship between cancer, on the one hand, and occupational hazards and hereditary factors, on the other. One prominent cancer specialist went so far as to say that 'it is only by relating medical information on individuals to census information that proper epidemiological studies can be undertaken'.

It is quite obvious from that quotation from the Law Reform Commission report and from the other evidence which is given in the report that environmental medical research could be greatly assisted by access to identified census returns. Yet, here we are in this country destroying our census returns as soon as we have processed them in the way that we do, by putting them on to computer tapes and also by publishing various reports.

Because of the great potential benefit of identified census records for these purposes, the Law Reform Commission recommended that they be left in the Archives with access forbidden for 75 years except for medical research purposes, when such information could clearly be of assistance, and made available on a strictly controlled basis to protect privacy. It recommended that the Director-General of Archives be given discretion to allow access for approved medical research within the 75-year period. In regard to that recommendation, the Law Reform Commission states:

The Commission recommends that the Director-General of Archives should be given discretion to allow access for approved medical research within the 75-year period. In all cases, access should be subject to such terms and conditions as to use and disclosure of the information as the Director-General lays down. In the case of access within the lapse period, unauthorised disclosure to third parties should be totally prohibited. A breach of the conditions laid down by the Director-General should be punishable as a serious offence, in the same manner as unauthorised disclosure of census information by an officer of the Bureau. In this manner, the confidentiality of identified census information should be ensured.

That recommendation seems very reasonable. It seems to be a fair balance between the important aims of protecting the privacy of the individual and of enabling socially beneficial research to be conducted. At present we simply cannot ensure that socially beneficial research can be conducted in the future, because the identified information is destroyed. However, even if one objects to any access being allowed for any purpose within a 75-year period, surely it is not unreasonable to keep the records and allow access after such a period.

We should realise that our practice of destroying census records is not normal in other countries. In Canada, the United States and the United Kingdom, all census forms are preserved. In New Zealand, every second census is retained indefinitely. In the United States, census forms are made available for historical, genealogical, sociological and medical research after 72 years. There have been various recommendations that for medical purposes the access should be available sooner than that. In the United Kingdom a similar situation applies but after 100 years. Here, we simply destroy our records. Certainly this guarantees privacy but it destroys a unique opportunity for future research. In our view it is not necessary to destroy census records in order to ensure privacy. Accordingly, we agree with the Law Reform Commission recommendation. I move as a second reading amendment:
That all words after 'That' be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:

'whilst not declining to give the Bill a second reading, the House is of the opinion that the Bill is deficient in that it fails to give effect to the recommendation of the Australian Law Reform Commission's Report 'Privacy and the census' that indentified census information should be held in Archives with access forbidden for 75 years, except for strictly limited access for purposes of medical research'.

It is not surprising that a Government which is so uncaring about preserving valuable research material should also be uncaring about gathering statistics to enable worthwhile contemporary research to be conducted and about information relating to the workings of our society being made available. The Fraser Government has shown its lack of concern in this regard in various ways-for example, by processing only half of the 1976 census so that it was not a full census at all but simply a large sample and therefore subject to sampling error. Since many other research exercises are based on census material, if the census material has some error then the error which can occur in the subsequent research is exacerbated. A very serious destruction of the accuracy of census records occurred at that time in order to save $2m. An amount of $2m is an awfully small portion of total expenditure. To destroy the accuracy of the census to save such a small amount was, in our view, a disgusting activity by the Government.

The Government has also shown its lack of concern for ensuring full information by refusing to allow the Bureau to conduct various planned surveys. One of those was the consumer finance and expenditure survey which was planned when this Government came into office. This would have provided invaluable material. This Government has forced the Bureau of Statistics to abandon statistics on foreign ownership and control so we will not know from now on-we have not known even for the last couple of years-to what extent our industry and resources are foreign owned and controlled. The Government does not want us to know the extent to which we are foreign owned and controlled.

More recently, we have seen the razor gang's decision that 27 series of statistics be discontinued and another 29 be reviewed. Of the 27 to be scrapped there are certainly quite a few which are fairly inconsequential. I do not want to be seen to be going in to bat hard, for instance, in relation to the survey on rock lobsters which are in cold storage in Western Australia. I do not find that particularly helpful but perhaps some people in the community regard that as an important series. I do not object vehemently to the scrapping of a series such as that or a series on eggs set and chickens hatched.

Some are more important. For instance, included in that 27 series to be scrapped are five series relating to real estate: Transfers and conveyances and mortgages or real estate mortgages of real estate in Victoria, real estate transactions in New South Wales, land for housing in New South Wales and sales of land and houses in New South Wales. We simply do not have enough information in this country about real estate. To be scrapping series on real estate is, in our view, not wise or sensible. It is also interesting to note in the group of series to be discontinued is one on the production of minerals and mineral products. I find it amazing that at a time when we are moving into what we are told is a resources boom the Government is scrapping the collection of statistics on minerals and mineral products. It seems an absolutely extraordinary series to scrap. I would have thought it was a very important series to continue to compile. The same comments could be made about the series on forestry and workers compensation.

In the group of 29 series which are to be reviewed, there are many which I believe to be worthwhile. For instance, the survey of selected private pensions funds seems to me to compile very important information. There is not nearly enough information available at present about pension funds in Australia. To be scrapping one of the few sources of information which we have in this area seems extremely unwise. The agricultural census is to be reviewed. The agricultural census, surely, is important. I would have thought that all members of the National Country Party would have been very concerned to ensure that an agricultural census was retained. Apparently they are quite happy to see it scrapped and to know much less about the agricultural industry. The life insurance series is to be reviewed. Life insurance is surely an important aspect of our society. We should know what is happening in this area. We will not know to anything like the degree that we should what is going on if life insurance statistics are no longer compiled.

Then we have the labour costs survey. The labour costs survey is to be reviewed by this Government. The Government insisted that the Bureau undertake a labour costs survey last year. The Bureau was anxious not to rush into such a survey although, as I understand it, it was not unwilling to undertake such a survey eventually. The Bureau did not want to be pushed into it because it had not had time to prepare properly for it. It was forced by the Government to rush into that survey during the latter part of last year without being able to refine its questionnaire and without being able to undertake a pilot survey, with the result that the survey has been an absolute shambles. As I understand it only some 30 per cent of the returns are useable. An enormous number of complaints were received from businesses about the difficulty they had in following the questionnaire and so on. This was all because the Bureau was pushed into conducting the survey by the Government. Presumably the Government wanted to get information which it thought it could use against the unions in national wage cases. Now, having forced the Bureau to undertake a survey in a hurried and highly unsatisfactory way the Government has announced that it will review that survey.

The fact is that we need much more information that we have at present. Ralph Nader was right when he said that information is the currency of democracy. Governments which hide information from their people lose the right to be able to claim that they are democratic governments. In our view, very important statistics about our society are not being made available to the Australian people. Unless they are made available to the Australian people we cannot know what is going on, nor can the Government properly conduct the affairs of the nation if it does not fully understand the nature of society and the economy which it is administering. It is extremely important in our view that we have a greatly increased list of statistical series and collections.

I mention some of those statistics which we regard as being important to collect because they represent enormous gaps in our statistical collections at the present time. One of these is integrated economic censuses and surveys which are required annually for all industries. We need to know what is happening in each industry. Another is employment statistics by industry and occupation. We need detailed information on employment levels by industry and occupation at least quarterly. The previous source on employment levels, civilian employees, is no longer published. I understand that it is compiled by the Bureau but the government will not allow the Bureau to publish the figures. This is an extraordinary situation. The reason the Government will not publish them is that the figures coming out of this series do not show anything like as large an increase in employment as those figures coming out of the labour force series. Therefore, this series was scrapped. We do need these figures to be provided on a basis that I have mentioned; that is, by industry and occupations and at least quarterly. We cannot simply rely on information which is available from the labour force surveys.

In regard to unemployment, we need details of unemployment on a monthly seasonally adjusted basis instead of having to rely on the labour force survey as it is at present. It would be useful also to have the figures published on a regional basis. That information is not supplied at present. I now refer to the ownership of wealth. There are no statistics in Australia on the ownership of wealth. We need information on the amount, distribution and type of assets which individuals and families own so that we can see how our society is structured-how equal or unequal the distribution of wealth in this country is. Surely it is of importance to governments and the nation at large to know that kind of information. The same situation applies with respect to income distribution. Statistics are required annually on the level and source of income, family type and number of dependants, particularly in respect of pensioners and beneficiaries. We need statistics on household expenditure. The last survey was conducted in 1975-76. We need data to be collected on a more regular basis than every five or six years. I think no survey is underway currently. Certainly, it would be desirable to have such information annually.

I now refer to the consumer price index. Most other Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries publish a consumer price index every month. Australia publishes its consumer price index every quarter. We are one of the very few countries that do not provide monthly consumer price index figures. We have to wait for three months to find out what our inflation rate is, whereas other countries can monitor that movement on a monthly basis. In regard to labour costs, we need statistics on non-wage labour costs which are required to assess the effects of changes in employment conditions. We need statistics on industrial accidents and absenteeism. Uniform statistics need to be collected on time lost through industrial accidents. There is no uniformity in the current statistics. Statistics are required on working days lost through absenteeism. We need statistics on occupational skills. Statistics are required on occupational skills possessed by the labour force. I have already mentioned foreign ownership and control of our industry and resources. The absence of those figures is an absolute scandal. It is absolutely essential that those figures are compiled.

Comprehensive statistics on capital raised in Australia and capital raised overseas by Australian corporations are required. Present statistics are restricted to listed companies and, therefore, are inadequate. We need complete statistics on the amounts borrowed by levels of government and types of borrowings because current information on government borrowings is not adequate. We need to know the level of government debt and interest liability of all sections of government. With regard to government finance, we need statistics on the operations of statutory authorities. Little information is available about statutory authorities at present. It would be desirable to have the national accounts on a State basis so that we can monitor how each State is performing economically. We simply cannot do that at present on a gross domestic product basis. We have to use other estimates. It is very important to have comprehensive statistics on house and land prices by regions.

I mention those figures as being what we regard as important gaps in the statistical series presently published by the Government. Doubtless there are other series which would also be of importance. I believe this is an area which, although it is not likely greatly to excite the Australian public, is of great importance to the Australian nation. If those of us who are interested in analysing what is happening in the society do not have that information we simply cannot know what is going on in this country and the Government cannot conduct the affairs of the nation properly because it simply does not know exactly what is happening in the economy and the nation over which it presides. If Australia is to be a democracy the Opposition believes it is terribly important for that information to be made available on as full and as comprehensive a basis as possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cameron Mr D.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The comments which I wish to make tonight will be somewhat different from those made by the honourable member for Gellibrand (Mr Willis) who took the opportunity of this debate to make wide-ranging references to the recent report of the committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions. I make the observation that perhaps one of the greatest documents of understatement that can come before this Parliament is that which is read by a Minister and is described as a second reading speech. If one were to examine the contents of the second reading speech of the Treasurer (Mr Howard) when he introduced the Census and Statistics Amendment Bill last week one would hardly understand the scope of the changes to be brought about by these amendments to the Census and Statistics Act 1905. I am not for a moment being critical of that Minister because this is common to most second reading speeches. However, I believe that I am entitled tonight to reflect on almost a decade of campaigning for alterations to the procedures which have been used in the past in the collection of information for a census. When I realised that this Bill was coming on for debate this evening I asked for some quick research to be done on my own efforts to bring about changes. The Brisbane Telegraph of 1 July 1971 reported me as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . people were entitled to absolute protection of personal information.

That was in relation to the 1971 census. I went on to make some other references. The Sun Herald of 4 July described my campaign as 'fiddlesticks'. The Courier-Mail of 7 July reported me as saying that I would:
. . . try to bring about changes in the method of census collection.
During the 1971 census I led what might be described as a minor revolt in terms of some of the requirements which were being foisted upon the public.

TALK.START.PARA: —Take your hands out of your pockets.

—If that is the most that the honourable member for Griffith has to offer he is not even a shadow of the former honourable member for Griffith. At that time I was accused of being disruptive. When one looks at the penalties which this Bill carries-a citizen who refuses to provide all the information supporting the form can be fined as much as $500-one can see that it will take a lot of inflation and many years before a person such as myself would dare to suggest to people that they buck the system. I notice that the Law Reform Commission report observes that a census penalty has never been invoked. Therefore, I pose the question: Why should we raise the penalty from $20 to $500 if it is never applied? I notice also that the Law Reform Commission notes that the actual census form never contains a reference to the penalty. I wonder why we have to adopt these procedures of introducing penalties which are probably more akin to the penalties that might be applied to criminal charges of some consequence. I do not believe we should spend too much time indulging in history but I do not think it is inappropriate for me to refer to some of the insensitivities which exist from time to time in government. Often the Australian Bureau of Statistics is only doing the biddings of the government of the day.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember a survey commissioned by the Labor Government in 1975 which was called a household survey. A personal diary which contained 25 pages was given to people to detail in which areas their money was spent. There was also a 48 page expenditure questionaire and an income questionnaire of 13 pages. Those surveys had the audacity-I carefully selected that word-to request that people state the exact amount of their tax refund. They were even asked how many cheques they wrote in the previous month. They were asked also to provide the names of members of the family who had lent them money. That was bureaucracy gone mad. It is little wonder that at times people are apprehensive and suspicious of forms thrust into their hands for the purpose of the collection of data. I remember that in 1975-this shows how changes come about-the Bureau of Statistics conducted a survey into unreported crimes. It was even interviewing prostitutes and the like, but no one could get a copy of the questions that were being asked. How times change! Only a few weeks ago, as a member of this Parliament I was presented with a sample of the 1981 census form which is only weeks away. Even though it had 'In Confidence' and 'Sample Only' stamped across it, at least we were given an opportunity to see the form. That it was too late to do anything about the contents, is another matter altogether.

When the 1976 census was conducted I was well satisfied that the game was going to be played properly, that envelopes were to be provided for those who objected to having to leave their completed forms, which contained all their private information, in a letter-box or meter-box or under a doormat. These people were to be provided with envelopes in which to put the completed form and were to leave it at a pre-determined place for the collector to pick up. At the time the census was under way in Queensland, I discovered that thousands upon thousands of these envelopes were stored away in boxes in some government building or storehouse in the city of Brisbane. Again, I cut loose. Whilst I do not derive any satisfaction from disruption, it is not improper to recall that the census collectors took another 10 days beyond the time which had been anticipated to collect all the forms. Once again, I was subjected to abuse, et cetera, for my quaint ideas.

The House will see that for me there is considerable satisfaction in seeing this Parliament tonight legislating into the Census and Statistics Act on a permanent basis corrections to some of those things which I saw as being a risk to personal privacy. This Parliament is again indebted to the work of the Australian Law Reform Commission and to Mr Justice Michael Kirby and those who served on the Commission during the preparation of report No. 12, which deals with privacy and the census. I also wish to commend the attitude which now prevails in the Statistician's office. Although it may have taken years for it to become more-is the word sensitised?

TALK.START.PARA: —That will do.

—For the Statistician's office to become more up to date in terms of the recognition of the changing values of society and the right of people to command privacy, it is obviously making a major effort to comply with the wishes of the community. Indeed, when one looks at the way the people reacted in 1976 in refusing to answer some questions, as reported at page 13 of the Law Reform Commission's report, it was obvious that changes had to be made. I sincerely hope that this time we will not see any reason to object to the census once it is under way and that, for the first time since about 1966, Australia will have a census carried out without public objection.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again I commend the Law Reform Commission for its job. I commend the former Attorney-General, Mr Ellicott, now Mr Justice Ellicott, for his reference to the Commission. I hope that this little piece of history will not be lost or forgotten. No doubt the message is that many of us in this place sometimes will stand alone in the pursuit of a cause, but after a number of years success can be forthcoming if the cause espoused is of value and of worth. I notice that the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) and the honourable member for Wills (Mr Hawke) are both in the Parliament at the same time. I appreciate their listening to my contribution. I recognise that this unusual display of unity by that duo is not in appreciation of my comments. Obviously something of note is about to happen.
Debate interrupted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Prime Minister from making a statement to the Parliament forthwith concerning the manner in which he has unfairly and deceitfully deprived the States of $70m and to justify his discreditable behaviour in leaking details to the Press on this matter with the aim of humiliating the State Premiers.

There has been an extraordinary series of events in the last few days but more particularly in the Parliament this evening. A series of Press conferences has been called by, respectively, the Treasurer (Mr Howard) and the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser). They are aimed at in some exculpating these two gentlemen from behaviour which, at best, can be described only as sordid.

What the Government has done through its tactics is to deprive the States of $70m to which they are justifiably entitled. It is clear that the Premiers Conference should be recalled not so that justice can be established to the State Premiers or to the State governments as such, but so that the proper entitlement of the people of the States can be provided by the national Government. What the Prime Minister did in arranging on Monday night through the Treasurer, because he approved the Treasurer doing it, to give a background briefing to the Press-we would call it, less euphemistically, a leak-and in doing it himself yesterday, was not so much to give technical details of how savings were made but to sneer and jeer at the Premiers, to humiliate the State governments.
Motion (by Mr Sinclair) put:
That the Leader of the Opposition be not further heard.

DIVISION.DATA.PARA: Mr Deputy Speaker-Mr P. C. Millar

ROW.ENTRY: Mr Morris-Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. Is it in order for the Treasurer to absent himself from a division without a pair having been granted?
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER-There is no point of order.
Mr Killen-Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order. A member of this House who raises a point of order with frivolity and facetiousness, and clearly so, should be named by the Chair.
Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER-The Chair is not presuaded that the honourable member for Shortland was of mischievous intent.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is the motion seconded?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bowen The Hon L.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) has cheated the Premiers of $70m--

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair) put:
That the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith be not further heard.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair) put:
That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the motion (Mr Hayden's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —It being past 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the House do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Am I supposed to speak on the adjournment?

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Well, I have never before had such a big audience when speaking in the adjournment debate. I want to talk about Campbelltown. Last night the town planner for the Campbelltown City Council which is in my electorate--

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —This is not a very funny matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members interjecting--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members will resume their seats.
—I will sit down as the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Hayden) wishes to speak.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hayden The Hon W.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have seen the rather undignified circumstances once again--

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Mr Sinclair) put:
That the question be now put.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question put-
That the House do now adjourn.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the affirmative.
