PROCTEXT.PARA: The following notices were given:
Mr Nixon to present a Bill for an Act to amend the Wool Industry Act 1972.
Mr Nixon to present a Bill for an Act to provide for the granting of proprietary rights to persons originating new plant varieties, and for related purposes.
The following papers were deemed to have been presented on 6 May 1981, pursuant to statute:
Family Law Act-Regulation-Statutory Rules 1981, No. 96.
Public Service Act-Appointment-Department of Social Security-D. J. Mallet.
Seat of Government (Administration) Act-Variation of plan of lay-out of City of Canberra and its environs, dated 6 May 1981.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Co-operative Farmers and Graziers Direct Meat Supply Ltd

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 31 March 1981 (Hansard, page 1090), the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) asked me a question, without notice, about the present situation with regard to the Commonwealth's guarantee of $4.5m of a $9m loan from Barclays Australia Ltd to the Cooperative Farmers and Graziers Direct Meat Supply Ltd (CF & G). I responded by outlining in a general way the considerations which led to the Government's provision of that guarantee but said that I would further inform him as to the precise situation.

ANSWER.PARA: The Commonwealth guarantee, together with the Victorian Government guarantee for the remaining $4.5m of the loan, was aimed at assisting CF & G to meet its receivership obligations and to trade out of its financial difficulties so that the farmer ownership of the facility could continue. The CF & G abattoir is a large and modern meatworks whose slaughtering capacity represents a significant proportion of total capacity in the Melbourne metropolitan area. It has demonstrated its capacity to operate profitably on the basis of reasonable throughput.

Since 1978, however, the CF & G abattoir, like many others, has experienced a sharp reduction in throughput as a result of a severe reduction in livestock numbers in southern Australia. Eventually the abattoir had to cease operations as the Cooperative's shareholders were not prepared to provide the necessary additional funds to enable it to survive in the circumstances of a depressed meat processing industry.

Messrs J. M. Poulton and D. A. Crawford of Peat, Marwick, Mitchell and Co were appointed Receivers and Managers of the Cooperative in December 1980. The Receivers are at present attempting to sell the abattoir at the best available price. Whether and to what extent there might be a call on the Commonwealth's guarantee will depend on the price achieved for the sale.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: Has the Department of Veterans' Affairs and the United States Veterans Administration had frequent exchanges of information concerning various chemicals sprayed in Vietnam during the war there; if so, can the Minister state (a) how many liver biopsies has the US Veterans Administration conducted on US Vietnam veterans, (b) whether those biopsies showed levels of arsenic to be present; if so, what levels of arsenic were present, (c) whether any other chemicals were shown to be present in abnormal levels, and, if so, (i) what those chemicals were and (ii) what the levels at which they were present at the time of those biopsies were and (d) when those biopsies were conducted.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Thomson The Hon D.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Under arrangements with various government agencies in the United States the Australian Department of Veterans' Affairs has been provided with details of research studies being carried out in the U.S. on possible health effects of herbicides and their contaminants. The details which have been provided make no specific reference to studies involving liver biopsies on U.S. veterans.

It is understood that a registry has been established by the Veterans Administration in the U.S. to document base line medical information on individual veterans who are concerned about possible health effects resulting from exposure to herbicides in Vietnam. The information in the registry is derived from answers to a questionnaire, a physical examination and a set of baseline laboratory tests. As at December 1980, data from approximately 12,000 veterans had been entered into the registry. It is understood that a task force has been established to examine various aspects of the registry in order to evaluate its current and future usefulness.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Holding Mr A.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 26 November 1980:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the article in the Committee for Lead Free Petrol Newsletter No. 6 of July 1980 headed Lead in Food Survey.

(2) Has (a) he, (b) his Department or (c) any agency under his control made any examination of the recent study of lead levels in Melbourne by Dr Frank Burden of the Chemistry Department, Monash University; if so, have the findings of Dr Burden's study been confirmed.

(3) Is any Federal or State Department or agency continuously monitoring environmental lead levels in any or all of Australia's 11 largest cities where the 1976 census showed 69.69% of the population (9,698,200) to be living; if so, (a) which Departments or agencies are carrying out the monitoring, (b) what is the (i) frequency, (ii) type, (iii) nature and (iv) location of that monitoring and (c) are the results of that monitoring publicly available; if so, from where can they be obtained.

(4) Has his attention also been drawn to the article headed Whoops-Only Testing on page 4 of the newsletter referred to in part (1); if so, can he say whether Victorian Country Roads Board measurements have shown the average for a month was 5.6 micrograms per cubic metre (nearly 4 times the Environment Protection Authority standard) and the highest daily average was 8.1 micrograms per cubic metre.
(5) Can he also say whether the Country Roads Board has ceased monitoring lead levels near freeways or other major roads.

(6) Has his attention been drawn to the article Lead as an Occupational Health Risk in the newsletter referred to in part (1); if so (a) can he say whether the United States of America Occupational Health and Safety Administration has set a maximum level of 60 micrograms per 100 millilitres for blood lead, (b) similar levels in Victoria are set at 80 micrograms per 100 millilitres, (c) workers exposed to lead in Victoria are not considered as being lead poisoned until their blood lead levels reach 120 micrograms per 100 millilitres and (d) 70% of workers in Victoria who have been found to have excessive lead levels, were found to exceed the level again after treatment.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) Yes. Dr Burden's study has been examined by officers of my Department, and it was, in fact, one of the documents considered during the revision of Metals-in-Food Standards.

As to confirming the results of Dr Burden's study, there has been no follow-up study done on fruits and vegetables as carried out by him. Dr Burden's study compared lead levels in fruits and vegetables grown in Melbourne suburbs with those available from retail outlets. Data are available, however, on an Australia wide basis from the NH & MRC Market Basket Survey. This survey shows that lead levels in those fresh fruits and vegetables sampled were below 1 mg/kg. Approximately 95% of samples showed lead levels of less than 0.5 mg/kg.
(3) Information supplied to my Department by the Department of Home Affairs and Environment indicates that:
(a) Atmospheric lead is regularly monitored by the following State/Territory authorities:

State Pollution Control Commission, NSW, Environment Protection Authority, Victoria, Department of Local Government, Queensland, Department for the Environment, South Australia, Department of Health and Medical Services, WA, Department of the Environment, Tasmania, Capital Territory Health Commission, ACT.
(b) (i) A sample is taken over a continuous 24-hour period repeated at intervals of six days. This is a recognised standard and has been adopted by many countries including Australia and the USA.

(ii) and (iii) Monitoring is carried out by using an instrument called a high volume sampler which draws a measured quantity of air through a filter. The deposit on the filter is then weighed and chemically analysed.
(iv) Monitoring sites include the following:
New South Wales-Sydney-Lane Cove, Rydalmere, Silverwater, Sydney City, Randwick (previously Kensington Station) Port Kembla, Wollongong, Stockton, Albion Park, Warrawong.
Victoria-Melbourne-Science Museum, South Caulfield, Alphington, Port Melbourne.
Queensland-Brisbane-Hamilton, Petrie, South Brisbane, Wooloongabba, Normanby, City.
South Australia-Adelaide-West Terrace, Thebarton, Port Adelaide.
Western Australia-Perth-Wellington, Murray Street, William Street, Adelaide Terrace.
Tasmania-Hobart*-Murray Street, Liverpool Street, University.
* Stations now discontinued.
ACT-Canberra-Woden, Civic.
(c) Results of monitoring are publicly available from the following:
(i) State Pollution Control Commission, Union Carbide Building, Liverpool Street, Sydney, NSW 2000
(ii) Environment Protection Authority, 240 Victoria Parade, East Melbourne, Vic. 3002
(iii) Air Pollution Control Division, Department of Local Government, 484 Adelaide Street, Brisbane, Qld 4000
(iv) Department for the Environment, Ansett Gateway Building, 150 North Terrace, Adelaide, SA 5001
(v) Department of Health and Medical Services, 60 Beaufort Street, Perth, WA 6000
(vi) Department of the Environment, GPO Box 1396P, Hobart, Tas. 7001
(vii) Capital Territory Health Commission, PO Box 825, Canberra City, ACT 2601
However, I suggest that any further details required in relation to this should be addressed to my colleague, the Minister for Home Affairs and Environment.
(4) and (5) My attention has been drawn to this article. The question on the activities of the Country Roads Board should be directed to the responsible Victorian authorities.

(6) Yes. My attention has also been drawn to this article, in which there seems to be some confusion. The United States of America Occupational Health and Safety Administration has set a maximum blood lead level of 60 micrograms per 100 grams, not 60 micrograms per 100 millilitres as stated in the Newsletter. However, again the specific issues raised are the responsibility of the Victorian authorities.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Darling Mrs E.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 24 February 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What did the Attorney-General mean when he stated in his address to the first meeting of the Human Rights Bureau at the University of Sydney on 28 November 1980 that the establishment of a ministerial meeting on human rights among ministers of all governments was a very important link if the Commonwealth is not to apply its legislation to the States.
(2) Who are the members of the Human Rights Bureau and whom do they represent.

(3) Is the Attorney-General able to state whether the Queensland Government has been included on a list of governments violating human rights and civil liberties, compiled by the State Department in the United States of America; if so, has this matter been raised at any meeting of the Human Rights Bureau and if it has not been raised will the Attorney-General do so at the next meeting.

(4) If the Queensland Government does not propose any change to laws relating to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders and to laws governing freedom of assembly and procession, does the Attorney-General intend using the authority invested in the Commonwealth Government by the external affairs power to encourage States to amend their legislation in conformity with international covenants to which Australia is a signatory, such as the United Nations Charter on Human Rights, and the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Viner The Hon R.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The meeting to which the honourable member refers was the first consultation between the Human Rights Bureau and national non-government organisations in the human rights field. In his address to that meeting the Attorney-General referred to the operations of the Meeting of Ministers on Human Rights which is a consultative body of Commonwealth and State Ministers responsible for human rights. All Governments, Commonwealth, State and Northern Territory, have responsibilities and interests in the field of human rights and the Commonwealth Government has adopted a policy of working with the States in matters of mutual concern. The Ministerial Meeting is the forum to which human rights matters affecting Australia are discussed.
(2) The Human Rights Bureau was established within my Department on 5 August 1980, and is staffed by officers of the Department. The Head of the Bureau is Mr Peter Bailey, O.B.E.

(3) The United States Department of State submits an annual report to the United States Congress called 'Country Reports on Human Rights Practices'. The latest of these reports, which was published on 2 February 1981 contains a summary of human rights practices throughout the world. The part of the report which deals with Australia summarises Australian law and practice under a number of headings. The report makes no criticism of the human rights position in Australia.

(4) The present Government's attitude to use of the external affairs power is well-known. Under the policy of co-operative federalism adopted by the Government, the Commonwealth and the States work together on matters of shared jurisdiction and interest. In matters of human rights the Meeting of Ministers on Human Rights is the appropriate vehicle for such consultations.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Cadman Mr A.G.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 4 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did his Department recently purchase 12 Vickers Air Transport Isolators specifically for transport of patients suffering from viral haemorrhagic fevers from remote areas to Fairfield Infectious Diseases Hospital, Melbourne, Victoria.
(2) If so, what was the cost to the community of the purchase of these pieces of equipment.
(3) Where are the units maintained.
(4) On whose advice as being a specialist in the field of Medical Air Transport did his Department rely in deciding on the purchase of this equipment.
(5) Is he able to say what other countries (a) have purchased similar equipment and (b) decided not to purchase the equipment after investigating the equipment offered.

(6) Is he also able to say on what occasions, world wide, the isolators have been used for the transport of patients who actually were suffering from viral haemorrhagic fever; if so, what was the outcome of that transport.

(7) Has a special isolation unit been constructed in the heart of Melbourne at Fairfield Infectious Diseases Hospital to house any patients transported in the isolators; if so, what was the cost to the community of construction of this facility.

(8) On whose advice as a specialist in infectious diseases did his Department rely in its decision to transport highly infectious diseases from geographically remote areas into a major population centre such as Melbourne.

(9) Is he able to give an assurance that the isolators are secure and that there is no possibility of leakage during (a) working of the isolator, (b) transport to the aircraft, (c) flight, (d) unloading of the aircraft and (e) transfer to Fairfield Hospital.
(10) Are steps taken to ensure that decontamination of equipment is secure; if so, what steps, and does this include decontamination of (a) road transport vehicles and (b) aircraft.
(11) Have the air carriers been informed of the necessary steps for decontamination and that these may even require incineration of their aircraft.
(12) Have the air-crew and their trade union been fully informed as to the possible consequences of a leakage occurring in flight.
(13) Are air transportable isolators available which could be transported to the patient in order that the patient could be nursed without transport.
(14) Are the viral haemorrhagic fevers as explosively contagious as first thought; if not, what justification can be given for the transport of these cases.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes. The purchase was made in 1979.
(2) The purchase price of the units was $334,268.
(3) Air transit isolators (ATI) are located at the following places:
Sydney (North Head Quarantine Station)-2
Brisbane (Royal Brisbane Hospital)-1
Darwin (Darwin Hospital)-2
Perth (Queen Elizabeth II Medical Centre)-2
Adelaide (Northfield Wards, Royal Adelaide Hospital)-1
Canberra (Central Hospital Services Complex, Mitchell)-1
Melbourne (Fairfield Hospital)-3
Routine maintenance is carried out by local bio-medical engineers. Readiness of the ATIs is ensured by an inspection team from Fairfield Hospital officially examining each ATI every six months.

(4) The acquisition of ATIs was approved by Government as a precautionary measure against the viral haemorrhagic fevers (VHF) which have been identified in recent years in Africa. In recommending this measure to Government, the Department of Health was aware that similar systems for the management of these diseases were being implemented at that time in the United States, Canada, Great Britain, Holland, Japan and Germany. Advice was sought from experts in Canada, South Africa, the United States and the United Kingdom. Before purchasing the isolators, the Department exhaustively tested a prototype specially brought from England for the purpose. Incorporated into the specification for the supply of the units in Australia were a number of modifications the need for which emerged from the Australian trials.

(5) (a) I am informed that the following countries have a mix of ATIs (long journeys), ambulance stretcher transit isolators (short journeys) and static isolators at one or more centres-Canada, Holland, South Africa, United States, U.S.S.R. The following countries have a mix of ambulance stretcher transit isolators and static isolators at one or more centres-Great Britain, Belgium, Germany, Denmark, Japan.
(b) I understand that New Zealand decided not to purchase such equipment.

(6) Statistics to answer this question are difficult to obtain. The isolators in Great Britain undoubtedly have the greatest use. The only two published uses of isolators of which my Department is aware are:

November 1976-Africa-a case of VHF (Ebola) was transported in an ATI from Bumba to Kanshasa, Zaire by Fokker Friendship aircraft. The patient and transit isolator were subsequently transferred to a US Air Force C141 'Starlifter' for transport to Johannesburg, after which the patient was transferred to a static bed isolator. The patient recovered.
June 1977-Canada-A six-year old boy who had recently returned from West Africa was suspected to be suffering from a VHF (Lassa).
The boy was transported from Toronto to Ottawa using a transit isolator. Lassa fever was not identified and the boy recovered.
(7) An eight-bed high security ward in under construction at the Fairfield Infectious Diseases Hospital. Estimated costs are as follows:
$ Building construction 2,104,000 Equipment purchase 103,000 High security laboratory extension-
Building construction 430,000 Equipment purchase 150,000

The capital cost of the ward and laboratory is being met by the Commonwealth. When not required for use by the Commonwealth for quarantine purposes, the ward will not lie idle but will be operated by Fairfield Hospital as an infectious diseases ward as an integrated part of the Victorian State health service. When required for quarantine purposes, the ward will be evacuated of patients and, by bringing into operation special air-conditioning systems, activating special alarm systems, automatic door closers, et cetera and the sealing of some doors, the ward can be quickly converted for high security use.

(8) Information available to my Department indicated that the bulk of international opinion favoured prompt transfer of VHF patients to a central specialised facility for containment of the disease and its treatment. The reported air evacuation in 1976 of a case of VHF from Zaire to Johannesburg in South Africa prompted inquiry into the practical use of an ATI. South African authorities recommended, in the light of their experience, adoption of the Canadian approach. Contingency plans developed in Australia to allow secure transportation of a case of VHF from geographically remote areas to a containment centre in a capital city are in line with these and other approaches in a number of developed countries. The Queen's Memorial Infectious Diseases Hospital at Fairfield in Melbourne catering for the infectious component of Victoria's hospital system was chosen because it is unique in Australia for its total commitment to the management of highly infectious diseases, and has the capability to cope with the problems of VHF.

(9) (a) to (e) Absolute assurances cannot be given. However, in close consultation, Commonwealth, State and Fairfield Hospital officers have developed plans for the operation and maintenance of the air transit isolators. Continuous training in the operation of the units is undertaken by doctors, nurses and maintenance engineers. All conceivable problems, including leakage, have been examined and contingency procedures developed and practised. Each six months a training flight is undertaken simulating an emergency airlift of a patient. Training flights have been held as follows:
29 May 1979-Familiarisation exercise
13 December 1979-Melbourne to Hobart and return
30 May 1980-Melbourne to Sydney and return
8-9 March 1981*-Melbourne to Adelaide and Perth and return
* Deferred from December 1980 due to airlines industrial problems.
The above arrangements and exhaustive prior testing of the ATI design and capabilities have reduced any risks associated with their use and transportation to minimal levels.

(10) (a) Yes. Procedures for the decontamination of road transport vehicles are included in the 'Handbook on Measures to Control Marburg Virus Disease, Ebola Virus Disease and Lassa Fever' issued by the Department of Health in November 1979. The procedures are based on those adopted by the United Kingdom in 'Memorandum on Lassa Fever' issued by Her Majesty's Stationery Office-1976.
(b) Any decontamination of an aircraft will be carried out in accordance with procedures set out in a World Health Organisation publication-'Guide to Hygiene and Sanitation in Aviation'.

(11) Air carriers have been issued with appropriate sections of the publication mentioned in (10) (b) above. Incineration of the aircraft would not be required; decontamination procedures as set out are more than adequate.
(12) On 17 November 1978 a meeting with representatives of the following unions took place at Fairfield Hospital:
Australian Federation of Air Pilots
Federated Clerks Union
Australian Licensed Airline Engineers Association
Australian Airline Flight Engineers Association
Transport Workers Union

The air carrier, its insurer, Fairfield Hospital and the Departments of Transport and Health were also represented. All present were fully informed of the Government's proposals and their implementation. No objections have been received.

(13) If a patient suffering from, or suspected to be suffering from, VHF is too sick to be moved, a static isolator held at Fairfield could be taken to the patient for management of the patient until he is well enough to be moved. Experience has shown that the patient could be infectious for up to 38 days. Transfer of the patient in an ATI to the high security facilities available at Fairfield must therefore be undertaken as soon as possible. Overseas experience has shown that it is not practical to manage a VHF patient in a static isolator for long periods.

(14) VHF are explosively contagious in situations where appropriate facilities and expertise in management are lacking. VHF, for which contingency plans for management and containment have been developed, are endemic to Africa. These fevers emerge spasmodically, spread very quickly and have a very high mortality rate. They have an incubation period of 3-17 days. As a result, a person infected with the disease could have left Africa and be located anywhere in Australia when the disease becomes apparent. The safeguard of the health of the Australian people and the prevention of the spread of these diseases are paramount in the planning and facilities in hand. With the adoption of the Australian contingency plans the main hazard of contagion is not envisaged to the public but rather to medical personnel in their attendance and nursing of such patients and from examination of infected material such as blood and urine for diagnostic and therapeutic indication. The Fairfield Centre is the only Australian unit which will be equipped to the standard to provide safety to medical personnel in the performance of these duties. Expertise also exists at the Fairfield Centre to ensure that the high levels of containment required can be maintained.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Klugman Dr R.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 10 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to allegations that practitioners of orthomolecular medicine are ordering many estimations of body fluid chemistry.
(2) Is the scheduled fee for each quantitive estimation of most substances $24.
(3) What is the estimated total cost to (a) the Commonwealth and (b) insurance funds of such large-scale pathological testing.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
(2) The Schedule fee for one of the items of service that may cover many of the estimations of substances is $24.

(3) This information is not available. It is believed that the practice of orthomolecular medicine could include many pathology tests, of which one service namely Items 1345 and 1346 (specialist and non-specialist respectively), may cover many. However, the purposes for which pathology tests are rendered is not recorded. Accordingly, the number of occasions that Items 1345/1346 are rendered would not necessarily relate to orthomolecular medicine. However, the approximate full year incidence of services itemized under Items 1345/1346 has been estimated at 340,000. At current (1 November 1980) Schedule fees and benefits, the Schedule fee cost would approximate $7.5m and Commonwealth medical benefits would approximate $2.3m. Due to the differing levels of health insurance cover, I am not able to provide details of the level of funding by registerd medical benefits organisations. If it is assumed that eligible persons are covered for the basic fund benefits, the fund benefit cost would approximate $3.4 million.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Institute of Marine Pharmacology at Dee Why, New South Wales

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Hodges Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 11 March 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to the announced closure of the Roche Pharmaceutical Company's unique Institute of Marine Pharmacology at Dee Why, NSW.
(2) If so, have reasons for the Institute's closure been advanced to the Government or has the Government had talks with, or sought information from, the company regarding the decision.

(3) Have approaches been made to the Government by the company for financial support to subsidise the research centre; if not, will he investigate the matter with a view to providing financial assistance to the venture.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.

(2) The Director of the Institute wrote to the Department of Science and Technology on 14 January 1981 advising that the Swiss parent company had decided to close the Institute by 30 June 1981. Officers of that Department have subsequently had preliminary discussions with the Director of the Institute. I also understand that discussions have been held with members of the Australian Science and Technology Council.
(3) Consideration is being given to the question of what action, if any, the Government should take on this matter.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lloyd Mr B.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) When will the Cocos Island quarantine station commence operation, and how many of each type of animal will be accommodated at it.
(2) When will the first dairy and beef cattle, sheep, goats, pigs, and any other animals arrive at the station, and from which countries will they come.
(3) From which countries will animals be allowed before the Geelong laboratory, Vic., is operational, and when will that occur.
(4) What will be the quarantine period for these pre-Geelong animals.

(5) How many of each type and breed of animal have been booked into Cocos Island quarantine station prior to the opening of Geelong and, of these, what percentage is for private stud breeders, and what percentage is for Government Departments, universities, etc.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: MacKellar The Hon M.J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Cocos Island quarantine station will commence operation in late November 1981, when the first shipment of cattle from the USA and Canada will arrive. The station has been designed with capacity to accept 120 adult female cattle or comparable numbers of other sexes and species. It is estimated that up to 500 sheep or goats could be accommodated or a similar number of pigs.

(2) Dairy and beef cattle will enter the station late this year in the initial shipment from the USA and Canada. Conditions have also been prepared to enable the importation of cattle from western Europe. Conditions to allow importation of pigs from the USA, UK and parts of western Europe in mid-1982 following the initial cattle importations are being developed. The importation of sheep and goats is still under preliminary consideration. Sheep and goats present specific problems in relation to 'slow virus diseases' which make the preparation of conditions under which importations may proceed a lengthy and complex operation.

(3) Prior to the opening of the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory (ANAHL) in Geelong, animals will only be accepted from countries with a known disease status. These countries include the USA and Canada, western Europe, the UK and Japan. Animals from certain other regions such as South America, South Africa and Asia will not be considered until after ANAHL becomes operational.

(4) Quarantine periods for imported animals will vary depending on species and country of origin. The quarantine periods on Cocos Island will vary between 3 and 5 months for cattle and pigs. Sheep and goats will require lengthier periods but it is not possible at this time to be specific due to the problems associated with detection of slow virus diseases. The quarantine periods on Cocos Island will follow quarantine periods in the country of origin.

(5) To date, applications from potential importers have only been sought for cattle from western Europe, Canada and the USA. Initial planning was for a shipment of cattle from western Europe to precede the cattle from the USA and Canada. However, construction delays and lack of firm demand have meant that cattle from the USA and Canada will be first. Applications for approximately 90 cattle from the USA and Canada have been received by my Department, all being from private breeders.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Council of Egg Marketing Authorities of Australia

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Kerin Mr J.C.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Primary Industry, upon notice, on 1 April 1981:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Does the level of the Council of Egg Marketing Authorities of Australia levy vary from State to State; if so, by how much and what has been the amount for each State during the last 3 years.
(2) If the levy has varied, how can this be reconciled with the provisions of the Constitution.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Nixon The Hon P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The rate of levy imposed under the Poultry Industry Levy Act does not vary between the States, but is uniform as required under the Constitution. The total of amounts collected from each State over the last 3 years are as follows:
Note: (a) Australian Capital Territory is treated separately from New South Wales.
(b) Hens kept for commercial purposes in the Northern Territory of Australia have been prescribed as a class of hens which are exempt from the levy imposed under the Act.
(2) Not applicable.
